39460565.review:
If you love the older point n click adventure titles (Zak McCracken, Maniac Mansion, Monkey Island, Indy etc), and don't understand how it got derailed with nonsensical puzzles- then get back on track with Thimbleweed Park!

Nostalgia may take the reigns with TP's oldschool graphics, but it was more the writing, comic timing, puzzles, and setting that made me understood what I yearned for all these years.

It had me hooked to the end.

An only "flaw" I could think of, is that there was no need for so many playable characters.  It seems that the team could've learnt a thing or two of how DOTT played out-  eg. Ray and Reyes- there was no need for two separate playable characters - it may have been interesting if they'd have been a single entity (as a team), but I hardly ever used Ray, but used Reyes instead due to his oddly awesome voice.

BUGS:  There were occasional sound glitches for me on my PC setup (ASUS Xonar)- Voices would go quiet and then only come from my left speaker (varies) - but nothing that was game-breaking.

Pros
- Excellent pixel art, presentation, and setting
- Colourful characters with unique personalities and backgrounds
- The same team that built classics such as Zak and Maniac Mansion
- Great hint helpline IN-GAME (so you won't be stumped for too long!)

Cons
- No need to use all of the characters

Rating : 9/10

39226097.review:
Its Full Throttle without the production values mixed with Day of the Tentacle without the time travel. Is it good? Yes! Does it reach greatness? No... Is it "open world"? Nope!
I sorta fell for the open world gimmick. That's the dream, an open world adventure game. Any game that advertises that I HAVE TO SEE IT. Hopefully i'm part of a very niche market so I never waste too much money, Sadly there should be more adventure games, so I'm not complaining. And this is a GOOD adventure game. As good as in the golden years of LucasArts, so it's worth it, a good old romp in a time capsule, without bikes or mad scientists.
The game, without a doubt, misses both. Unless you're an older gamer and understands the refernces, you'll be missing out half the experience. If you're a f nerd, you'll be all right. 
It's adventure game for an old generation by the old generation. If you've never played Full Throttle or Day of the Tentacle, get those first. They're harder, but theyll make this game a whole lot easier and less cryptic. 
Graphics? Good. Not great, everything makes sense, but it shows that the open world thing didn't work out: the characters look great, but the backgrounds, though detailed, are just too flat and uninteresting. This 2D aspect should have made it easier to just link stuff together, but this game, as it stands, is not a sandbox, there's nothing to do besides solving puzzles. I suppose that the LucasArts adventure directive, that you can never die, just doesn't go well together with sandboxes. 
That's not to say that the art direction isn't good, it's fantastic. Given this game's self imposed limitations, some parts look awesome: the parts with depht. Some settings are presented in perspective, and they really stand out. Also, some of the details are beautifully designed and well thought out. If the whole game was like that, it would've been great.
The sound design is amazing, though. Fantastic voice acting for wonderfull characters. Incredible music: nice, moody and jazzy, sometimes whimsical, which adds to the game's atmosphere. Sound effects are just right as they should be.
The very soul of this game lies in its sense of humor, and the fact that it doesn't takes itself too seriously, though it takes it too far by the end. No spilers here, just saying that it should've had a more satisfying ending. It's not bad, it's just... not great.
And that's the sad conclusion, this game could've been great, it almost touched greatness, yet it's just good. There's just something missing... maybe a bike or a mad scientist. Though it features a scientist, he's just not mad enough. This game went too far, but not far enough. That's the overall feeling about it, it's not great, it's not mediocre, it's just... good. Too well behaved. Too wholesome. Old adventure games had this dark sense of humor, this one just feared taking things too far.

39132206.review: THIS VIDEO GAME DID NOT FULLFIL MY HOLES

39102400.review:
PROS

1) It's really a nice touch when the characters can't voice their thoughts because they don't have the inner strength to do so. "I'm too scared or ashamed to say or do that" -> this is really interesting design and worth exploring further.

2) There were some surprising and dramatic moments that, contrary to convention, made it seem that your characters are vulnerable and not invincible. Unfortunately, there are only two of those moments, and they are not enough to change the rest of the game.

3) Good facial animation, lyp sync, lighting, and wonderful art. (We don't count Garry Winnick's shitty art that can't blend in with the good art made by the real artists). Anyway, if you see something badly drawn (inventory items, secondary characters, the world map) that has jarring colours, boring shapes, lack of volume and material definition, you know it's drawn by Winnick. Still, his stuff is under the sanitary minimum so the real art done by Mark Ferrarri and Octavi Navarro remains good overall. 


CONS

1) None of the freedom, consequences and living NPCs that Maniac Mansion and Zak McKracken had. 

2) Bad writing that heavily relies on parody and "jokes" as an excuse for how weak the dialogue is. (Shows you how weak Ron Gilbert's writing and storytelling is by modern standards).

3) Mediocre, but difficult puzzles (in the second half of the game). Solving them doesn't feel satisfying (I'm saying this as someone who solved every single one fairly). They're just not interesting or meaningful even though they are better designed than the ones in Broken Age.

4) Nihilistic, disappointing, meaningless and shallow story. I've seen other stories deal with the same subject and they are much stronger both morally and philosophically. Here... it's cringeworthy.
Can be considered a spoiler, but you should better read it. All this work to make a gameworld and characters that inhabit it... and then tell the player - [SPOILER] actually, this isn't real, this is just a videogame, it's all fake, you have wasted your time. You invested in this world emotionally, but it's all worthless. 
Oh, and by the way, because these characters aren't as real as you, and because their existence is limited within the game constraints, it's better for all of them to just die and for their fake world to burn. This is how the murderer in the story also justifies his murders, but then this same nihilistic motivation is used by the main protagonist. And then you're told - oh, wait, even that's not possible, you can't really destroy the gameworld and that's sad. That's the level of philosophical and ethical maturity the author has. Disgusting. [/SPOILER]
Last, but not least, this is a total violation of the contract between player and creator. You trust that the creator won't suddenly say "Oh, I'm tired of all this, you know what, fuck it" and throw his story in the trash. I can't understand what thought process made Gilbert and the others to believe even for a moment that such a choice is going to be okay.

Anyway. I'm finally done. I don't think I'll support another Ron Gilbert game ever again. I'd support something else by David Fox, though, but sadly, I don't think he'd make another "Zak McKracken" (that is, another living and breathing adventure that doesn't follow the bad convention established by Gilbert in Monkey Island - convention, followed by everyone else until the genre got completely stuck in the mud with the static, boring, unresponsive characters and unconvincing worlds that this type of design generated).

I will play some more modern and old adventure games though, to remove the bad taste.

39101784.review:
It's a great puzzle+comedy adventure game, and I hope they make many more. It's not in the same league as masterpieces of fiction such as I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream, or The Longest Journey, but it's certainly at the top of the league of puzzle+comedy adventure games, giving me more enjoyment than Full Throttle, Day Of The Tentacle, and almost all of the other SCUMM games.

One thing to note: The Casual difficulty doesn't just make the puzzles easier, it also cuts out about 1/3rd of the game's content, leaving many plot threads unexplained. Unless you're going for every achievement (takes ~18 hours, vs ~9 for one full playthrough on Hard), I'd recommend you only play on Hard. There's a very good built-in hint system if you get stuck, but most of the puzzles are at just the right difficulty level that you won't need to use it often.

38806370.review:
I have been disappointed by almost every attempt to revive the point-and-click genre via Kickstarter, but [i]Thimbleweed Park[/i] bucks the trend.  It's so good I wish I'd funded it.

The game should appeal to anybody who grew up playing adventure games: the graphics are reminiscent of the original [i]Manic Mansion[/i] (but now with more pixels!), and the amount of lateral thinking required by the puzzles is spot-on.  The stories of its multiple playable characters -- each of whom have their own inventories and location restrictions -- are woven together very well, and the ability to switch between them at will provides a great in-game way to "go do something else" when encountering a roadblock.

I haven't played anything else since I booted up [i]Thimbleweed[/i], and any time I wasn't playing I was working through potential puzzle solutions.  I cannot recommend it highly enough.

My [b]only[/b] issue with the game is that it contains an option to enable "in-jokes" that is (in my opinion) quite poorly labelled.  As a result, I played the entire game with all references to [i]Manic Mansion[/i] and [i]Monkey Island[/i] [b]disabled[/b] by mistake.  Who wants that!?

38804697.review:
I really liked this one myself, but it's the strange good game that is worse than the sum of its parts. It has amazing craftmanship, both in puzzles, dialogue, and pure technical implementation of a traditional 2d adventure game. This focus on the microdecisions that make each sequence and each puzzle so delightful have a flip side: The overarching story development is closer to those of adventure games of old, instead of the tight, story first, puzzles later designs that you see in games that are closer to walking simulators: The ending and the overall story are afterthoughts, not unlike in a lage majority of old Lucasarts/Sierra adventure games.

When looked through that prism, Thimbleweed Park stands out as a really good old game: If this had been released in 1994, we;d see them as one of the best, if not the best games of the era. It's about as heartefelt a  love letter to the old days as I can think of. An evolutionary dead end, but such an amazing, enjoyable dead end.

I compare it to Mario Odyssey: I can't concieve anything more Mario than Mario Odyssey. So amazing at what it is, that it's almost a genre and formula ending. So good at what they do that the games leave me full. Thimbleweed Park makes me not want another Lucas-style adventure game ever. After this, one has to just aim for something new. 

If you were looking for a more modern game, just built by some old masters, you will be sorely disappointed though. This is no Gone Home, no Edith Finch, and no Firewatch.

38267888.review:
Si vous voulez (re)vivre une expérience années 80, où le jeu vous était donné sans aide, sans vous prendre par la main, avec votre seule jugeote comme guide, alors ce jeu est fait pour vous.
Retrouvez cette ambiance du Point n'Click déjanté des Lucas Game, où les énigmes se résolvaient avec une logique implacable, l'une de ces logiques où après vous être torturé la tête pour résoudre l'énigme, vous vous disiez : "AAAAAAAH ... MAIS OUI ! C'est logique ... mais je les hais quand même."
Oui ... cette logique logique. Pas alambiquée, totalement premier degré, tellement premier degré que vous devez faire un effort mental pour accepter la réalité des créateurs de ce jeu. Mais qui pour autant, continue de vous frustrer, autant que de vous amuser. Thimbleweed Park, c'est cela. Des énigmes pas si c***, et une ambiance très nostalgique allant entre X-Files et Twin Peaks, tout en vous concotant une résolution surprenante et moderne, et surtout tendance.

Thimbleweed Park, l'un de ces jeux que l'on aime voir naître, car ils nous rappelent, ou nous évoquent une époque révolue, mais toujours chère à nos coeurs.

38225619.review: This game offers a really fun classic point-and click experience. It has a rich story full of mystery, excellent voice acting and humor, and the art style is really vibrant and eye catching. I wish there were more games like this!

Se riesci per un attimo a dimenticare dove sei ed immergerti nei grattacapi di Thimbleweed Park potresti riscoprirti bambino, con gli stessi dubbi di un tempo, provando a riprovando a trascinare gli oggetti fra loro perchè ti sei incastrato! E sono quindici minuti fai avanti ed indietro per le schermate 2D.

Dico la verità, non mi ha entusiasmato, è scivolato via, ero piu' perso nei miei ricordi di punta e clicca che concentrato sulla trama, intrigante e divertente, ma niente di stravolgente, Peccato, forse, perchè mancava solo quel qualcosa di eclatante per completare il tuffo nel passato. Personalmente adoro la grafica 2D.

Consiglio l'acquisto agli appassionati di punta e clicca e Gamers ormai "antichi" come me con alle spalle una marea di avventure grafiche.

38129013.review:
I was a kickstarter backer for this game, but only got around to finish it recently. I am completely satisfied with the result: thimbleweed park really does feel like an improved version of my favourite classic LucasArts adventure games.

The game manages to look really beautiful despite using pixel graphics and the puzzles are mostly quite logical. I did get stuck a total number of 3 times, but only because I took a long break playing it and forgot some important details. Therefore I recommend to avoid taking such breaks and finish it over a weekend. Still even if you get stuck, the in-game hint line can really help you out without spoiling too much.

Some people complain about the "annoying in-jokes" (most of which can be turned off in the settings) and the meta ending. I can see how the ending could be disappointing for some, but since it is kind of another extended in-joke and I was fine with them, it was good enough for me.

All in all, I had a lot of fun, so if you have any interest in classic adventure games make sure you play this one.

The characters are interesting and ransom the clown is downright hilarious!   This is a gem, instant classic in my book.  If you’re into point and click adventures this game will not disappoint.

38060038.review:
The game looks and sounds great, and the puzzles are challenging. It feels as if years of developing point-and-click adventure games has culminated in a truly polished product. However, the ending was godawful. It's as if every single popular game since Drawn to Life has pulled a cop-out fourth-wall breaker. One Shot, Undertale, and similar games all have the presumption to try and become a personal investment on the players' part, yet there's no justifiable reciprocation for this, since the game developer doesn't actually know you. They haven't built a personal relationship with you. They're merely infringing on your personal space with this creepy metaphorical feel-copping. Harry Potter readers will probably remember a line the deceased Dumbledore gives toward the end of the series, something along the paraphrased lines of "Just because it's in your head doesn't mean it's not real." Solipsism. It's actually not quite so bad with Thimbleweed Park, but it is a trend that tired rapidly and feeds on the sad cult of celebrity people still shamelessly buy into. It's a fun game to play, it's just that the pay off is as worthless as watching through Lost. Rebuttals will likely quote that it's about the journey, but as I've just stated, the journey through the game is enjoyable. It's just, you really end up only spinning your wheels the whole time. 

The call-ins and books from the Kickstarter backers were pretty sad, although a much-needed break from sitting through eleven-hour credits sequences crediting every sap who paid a dollar before any work was put into a product. Still, the content these complete strangers provided ranged from shameless self-advertisement to squalid, out-of-context and outdated memes that dishonor the integrity of adventure gaming. It lends itself to strict criticism on account of the disclaimer provided in-game that the providers are responsible for their own content. 

Fun game. The self-references became ham-fisted after a while. We should be pretty tired of Ron Gilbert's opinions and incessant rebuttals by now. I'd rather pay for a game, not every Steam developer's blog entries regarding the latest hashtags.

Thimbleweed Park hat all meine Erwartungen erfüllt.
Ich habe ein fesselndes Point&Click-Adventure à la "Day of the Tentacle" erwartet und genau das bekommen.
Der klassische Pixel-Look wirkt durch atmosphärische Lichteffekte lebendig und erstaunlicherweise auch für meine HD-verwöhnten Augen zu keinem Zeitpunkt störend - im Gegenteil - dadurch kam der Charme des Spiels erst so richtig zur Geltung. Die Steuerung und Mechaniken des Spielprinzips dürften jedem bekannt sein, sodass ich hierzu keine Worte verlieren muss. Die Geschichte ist spannend, hat Witz und die verschiedenen spielbaren Charaktäre sorgen für jede Menge Abwechslung. Die Rätsel sind anspruchsvoll und ganz im Stil seiner berühmten Vorgänger. Hier ist die kreative Einbettung einer Hilfestellung via Hotline (die man im Spiel anrufen kann) zu erwähnen, wodurch Frust vorgebeugt wird.
Alles in Allem ein perfekt umgesetztes Spiel, wofür ich 5 von 5 Sternen vergeben würde.

Классический квест с закосом под квесты сьерры онлайн 90-х. Общая концовка, лично для меня, была очень неожиданной и приятно удивляющей, очень тонко. А вот локальные, для каждого персонажа как-то смазанны, начиналось все бодро, а концовки по персонажам дописывали на колене. 
 В целом, игра очень понравилась, для ностальгии самое-то (в игре так же множество отсылок к старым квестам, иногда даже целые локации). Пару раз все же застрял по невнимательности и из-за обилия предметов, некоторые из которых и не нужны (еще одна фишка сьерровских квестов), а некоторые сыграют только далеко потом, но такие моменты затыка бывают в любом квесте. Благо тут есть телефон подсказок, один раз пришлось воспользоваться, наступив собственной гордости на горло. Однако, так бы я и больше 30 часов наиграл, ибо уже тупо ходил по кругу. 
Любителям квестов, а особенно тем, кто в 90-е застал это обилие сьерровских игр - однозначно рекомендую.

37735047.review: Thimbleweed Park ist im wahrsten Sinne des Wortes, das Beste aus den 80ern und 90ern mit der Technik und Erfahrung von heute :) Wer den verrückten LucasFIlm Humor mochte (Monkey Island oder Day of the Tentacle), die verqueren Charaktere, die kniffligen Rätsel und sich über einen modernsierten 8-bit Look freuen kann, der liegt hier verdammt richtig. Auch die Story is überaus gelungen, sie ist mit zahlreichen Anspielungen und Referenzen gespickt und einem doch überraschendem Ende. Zugegeben, das Spiel dauert nicht ewig, wie andere Adventures halt auch. Aber manchmal geht es um Qualität statt Quantität und da kann Ron Gilberts Team voll abliefern. Wer noch nie ein Adventure gespielt hat... sollte auch zugreifen. Das scheint mir ein toller Einstieg in die Wellt des Point-und-Click-Adventures.

37690869.review:
I really didn't expect to like Thimbleweed Park as much as I do. I keep Kickstarting Ron Gilbert projects almost out of charity, like, when you buy an old friend a beer.

The mechanics are straight up SCUMM but there's some really interesting wrinkles created by managing multiple characters simultaneously--the combinatorics make you have to stop and think about the different puzzles instead of just trying every combination when you're stuck.

PROS: great puzzles, well-woven story, interesting mechanics, speed walking is pretty rad, a lot of amusing references to old SCUMM games.
CONS: Ransome the Clown can be annoying, probably even more so because it censors his potty mouth with BEEPING, but he mellows out a bit as the game goes on, you can't seem to skip dialogue which can be annoying when you trigger the same bit a second or third time.

I wish they had taken it a bit more seriously. The game is good, the story is rich and the graphic feels good, so bravely old way. Yet I can’t help but thinking they put so much irony in it because A. it’s just a tribute to old LucasArts games, and B. they don’t expect you to really like this out-of-fashion video game genre in a serious way.
Too many self-references and metafiction expedients to break the 4th wall, which of course were also LucasArts adventures signature, but I’m saying too many. And the quotes as well, way too many quotes (not just mild references) to 90s games. I mean quotes spoken out loud. This constant dripping in the game narrative end up basically saying: “Do you remember how fun it was? Oh but how young and stupid we were!”.
I don’t know, maybe it’s just me. Anyway, the game is fun to play, well conceived and hard at times. Buy it! You ungrateful old fogy.

37160944.review:
"Willkommen im Jahr 1987!", begrüßte mich das Zeitreisemobil. "Endstation - bitte alle aussteigen!", fuhr es fort und schloss ab mit: "Thimbleweed Park heißt Sie Willkommen!".

Jaja... als meine Zeit mit dem Amiga in jungen Jahren begonn, waren all die schweren schier unknackbaren P&C-Adventures vom Schlag Maniac Mansion, Zak McKracken, wobei das gnädigste seiner Art noch die Indiana Jones Teile waren. Aber langsam, aber sicher brach schon damals für mich eine neue Zeit auf - die Ära der Adventures mit kompaktem Aktionsmenü, das quasi nur noch "Gucken", "Nehmen" und "Verwenden" sowie "automatisch in Ansprechen" umgewandelte Aktionen - quasi kontextsensitiv - anbot. Monkey Island 3 war so ein Kandidat... und seither sind direkt verwendbare "Verben" wie "Gehe zu", "Schaue an" und "Nimm" Museumsschaukunst, die mir so schon lange nicht mehr vor die Füße kam - bis Thimbleweed Park erschienen ist.

Aufgrunddessen wurde vermutlich der große Nostalgiefaktor bei vielen Kickstarter-Backern perfekt angetriggert, die (erwartungsgemäß) diese Pionierjahre als "goldene Zeit" archiviert haben. Aber kennt ihr das, wenn ihr das einstige "makellose goldene Werk" noch einmal viele Jahrzehnte später anzockt - und all die Erinnerungen an der eiskalten Wand der Realität zerschellen? Wenn ihr merkt, dass ihr all die Fehler und Nervigkeiten verdrängt habt, die ihr schon damals kacke fandet? Oder all die Verbesserungen dieses Spielegenres bis heute als selbstverständlich hingenommen habt und ihr sie gar nicht mehr in Relation mit den damaligen Unzulänglichkeiten seht? Oder euch bewusst macht, dass ihr euch selbst ans "Heute" angepasst habt und es nun mal gewohnt seid, dass heute "Komfort" mehr auf der Tagesordnung steht?
Ich für meinen Teil bin mir sicher, dass "Thimbleweed Park" bei vielen sehr viel besser abschneidet als es heute noch "state of the art" ist. Klar will es das auch nicht, aber das wischt ja die Fehlerchen nicht rein. ;)

Warum es trotzdem ein großartiges Spiel ist und was mich so stört, folgt jetzt: Erst einmal haben wir die grandiose Pixel-Grafik, die natürlich nicht so farbarm und platt wie damals bei MM oder ZmK aussieht, aber schon sehr reduziert daher kommt, aber genau dadurch seinen Charme hat. Die Geschichte fängt solide an, lässt uns sehr behutsam in das kleine Dorf und die Geschichte reinfliegen, gibt uns noch nicht die ganze Stadt zum Erkunden frei und stellt auch noch nicht die ganze Palette an abwechselnd steuerbaren Charakteren zur Verfügung - denn ja: Es gibt später eine Map mit Schnellreisefunktion zu allen möglichen Orten - die Karte ist also nicht ganz klein und ja, ihr steuert insgesamt 5 Charaktere gleichzeitig - alle mit ihren individuellen Dialogoptionen, Rätseln, Eigenschaften usw. - und meistens können sie genauso überall hin wie jeder andere, sich Items austauschen usw. Es kommt also nicht nur das Thema "9 verschiedene Verben" auf euch zu - sondern auch noch eine große Spielwelt, viele redundante Laufwege sowie viele Möglichkeiten mit den entsprechenden Figuren des Rätsels Lösung auf die Schliche zu kommen. Das ist nicht ganz unkomplex.
Gut gelungen ist aber, dass die 9 Verben alle via Shortcut nutzbar sind, sodass man auch mal Brute Force testen kann. Aber nicht immer ist klar, was gerade zu tun ist - und mit der Möglichkeit auch noch ein gigantisches Telefonbuch zu integrieren, wo man ingame auch diverse Nummern zur Rätsels Lösung anrufen muss, macht es nicht immer sofort klar wie es weiter geht.

Die Story schien mir zwei-aufgeteilt zu sein - aber in sich mit ihren liebevollen Charakteren, witzigen Dialogen und vor allen Dingen gesellschaftlichen sowie Retro-Seitenhieben - natürlich auch in sich selbst (Referenz zu Entwicklerlegende Ron Gilbert, Maniac Mansion, Artstyle, Retrospiele, Nerdkram usw.) wundervoll unterhaltsam. Leider fand ich das Ende recht abrupt, aber im Zweifelsfall dennoch "passend". Kann man sich als Retrofan definitiv antun und als Fan kann man nicht, sondern muss man sogar - doch unterm Strich bin ich froh, dass diese altbackene Steuerung, teilweise zu optionsreiche Spielwelt größtenteils der Vergangenheit angehört und stimmigen Rätseln sowie einem befriedigenden Spielflow gewichen ist - und dieser trägt für mich den Namen "Daedalic" :)

36634201.review:
(This is from my blog - Kayas Arcade as a part of my 52 games in 52 weeks challenge)
https://www.facebook.com/Kayasarcade/

Week 18
19/52
Thimbleweed Park
Platform: PC
Time: 12-13 hours ("Hard") 
Genre: Point and click Adventure 

Thimbleweed park is a kickstarted project by Ron Gilbert and Gary Winnick (Creators of Maniac Mansion and Monkey Island). 

You have to solve a murder, and your characters each have a mission they need to work on, on the way. It's all set in 1987 with great pixelart, funny puns, cool references and as always is the humor on point. 

I really loved this game. I'm and old Point and click adventure fan, so this game was a "must-play" sooner or later. I'm so happy that I got through it, it was a great experience from the beginning to the end. So many great details... And I laughed, I laughed a lot.

The way they interacted with the player was so fun.

It really fulfilled all my expectations. 

I won't spoil anything, but this game had one of the best endings I have played for a while. I can easily recommend this game if you are into the genre.

36517621.review:
"A Thimbleweed Park, un cadavere è l'ultimo dei tuoi problemi".

Così ci viene annunciata la nuova perla ed avventura grafica punta e clicca, dei creatori di Maniac Mansion e Monkey Island, Ron Gilbert e Gary Winnick.
È stato commesso un omicidio, la popolazione di Thimbleweed Park è diminuita, a capo delle indagini ci saranno gli agenti federali Angela Ray ed Antonio Reyes, due dei personaggi giocabili.

In totale sono cinque, i personaggi giocabili di Thimbleweed Park, infatti abbiamo la possibilità di vestire anche i panni di Ransome il *bip* clown, Delores la sviluppatrice di videogiochi e Franklin il fantasma.
Ognuno di questi personaggi ha il suo arco narrativo e sarà fondamentale per proseguire nella storia del videogioco, infatti saranno i soli a poter interagire con alcune ambientazioni in un determinato momento.
Lo stampo della classica avventura grafica è rimasto, in basso a sinistra abbiamo a disposizione una tabella con dei verbi, a destra è presente l'inventario di gioco, differente per ogni personaggio giocabile.
Lo scopo è quello di investigare l'ambiente circostante utilizzando la tabella dei verbi, componendo delle frasi in base alla situazione, interagendo con oggetti e/o persone.

Come ci insegna Maniac Mansion, anche in Thimbleweed Park, alcuni enigmi possono essere risolti soltanto da alcuni personaggi.
Prima di portare a termine questo titolo, ecco possibile proseguire con la storia con tutti i personaggi, così da vedere il progredire della rispettiva storia. Una volta completato il gioco è possibile rigiocarlo cercando di compiere determinate azioni, in determinati momenti, con differenti personaggi, in modo tale da scoprire un nuovo filone narrativo da un punto di vista diverso rispetto al precedente.

Abbiamo a disposizione due modalità di gioco:

Casual: per i principianti ed inesperti delle avventura grafica, avranno a disposizione meno luoghi da esplorare e meno enigmi da risolvere.
Difficile: per chi, come me, è cresciuto anche con le avvenute grafica LucasArts/Lucasfilm Games.
In entrambe le modalità di gioco non è presente la morte del personaggio, d'altronde non stiamo giocando ad un titolo Sierra.

Pronti a giocare? Daje!

La prima cosa che si nota, giocando a Thimbleweed Park, è l'utilizzo di un motore grafico che ricorda decisamente lo SCUMM, che Gilbert ha programmato da zero basandosi sul codice "Squirrel" di Alberto Demichelis.
Grazie a Mark Ferrari, ex collega LucasArts, ci viene proposta una pixel art impeccabile, stiamo giocando ad una vecchia avventura grafica ma con un impatto grafico moderno, il risultato non può che essere esaltante.
Fattore immancabile, per un'avventura grafica di questo tipo, è la presenza costante di situazioni surreali, grottesche e piene di comicità, più di una volta Thimbleweed Park vi strapperà un sorriso o una sonora risata, soprattutto con l'avvento di Ransome il *bip* clown!
Il tutto è condito da numerosi enigmi da risolvere e matasse da sbrogliare, ammetto di aver avuto non poche difficoltà a completare questo titolo, ma esplorando ogni pixel e sbattendoci parecchie volte il grugno, alla fin fine si riesce a venirne a capo.
Prima di congedarmi vi lascio il link del gioco sulla piattaforma Steam, perché secondo me, a prescindere se siete degli amanti del genere, Thimbleweed Park va assolutamente giocato, lo inserisco tra i migliori videogiochi a cui abbia mai giocato.

Le moins qu'on puisse dire sur Thimbleweed Park, c'est qu'il est atypique et marquant.

Pour les fans de Lucas Games de la première heure je le recommande absolument car il est totalement dans la lignée de Maniac Mansion, Monkey Island et leurs autres point & clic cultes. 
Graphiquement le jeu tout en pixel art est vraiment beau et très détaillé avec une ambiance retro super sympa. Les personnages sont tous  drôles et attachants à leur manière et j'ai beaucoup aimé toutes ces références à des séries cultes des années 90 comme X Files ou Twin Peaks.
Il y a deux modes de jeux, un mode "casu" ou facile qui rend les énigmes plus simples (ou qui en retire tout simplement), et un mode plus difficile qui rend le jeu plus long, ce qui peut offrir une certaine rejouabilité. La bande son est aussi vraiment cool.
Si vous aimez les point & clic et les jeux avec un côté retro je ne peux que vous le conseiller.

36200884.review:
Maniac Mansion’ın yapımcısı Ron Gilbert ile Gary Winnick'ten eski amacera oyunlarının şanına yakışır türden, gerçek bir klasik.

1987 yılında, Thimbleweed Park adlı küçük bir kasabanın hemen dışında gizemli bir cinayet işleniyor. Bunun üzerine Ray ile Reyes adında iki özel ajan güya bu olayı çözmek için olay yerine geliyor. Güya diyorum çünkü aslında ikisinin de kendilerince başka amaçları var ve ceset falan umurlarında değil. Hoş, kasabadaki kimsenin umurunda değil. Onlara daha sonra son derece küfürbaz bir palyaço olan ve bir lanet sonucu makyajını asla çıkaramayan Ransome; LucasAr… pardon… MmucasFlem’de oyun tasarımcısı olmak isteyen ve Commodore 64 uzmanı genç kızımız Delores; bir başka gizemli cinayete kurban giden ve kızımızın babası olan hayalet Franklin katılıyor. Toplamda 5 karakter birden yönetiyoruz, evet. Ve bazı bulmacaları çözebilmek için 2-3 tanesinden aynı anda faydalanmamız gerekebiliyor. 

Oyun “modern” macera oyunlarının aksine birbirleriyle son derece alakasız eşyaları en olmadık yerde kullanmanız beklenmiyor sizden; her bulmacanın kendi içerisinde bir mantığı var. Hangi nesnelerle etkileşime girebileceğimizi bir bakışta anlayabildiğimiz gibi, TAB tuşuna bastığımızda da ekrandaki nesneler hemencecik göz kırpıyor bizlere.

Thimbleweed Park’ta Maniac Mansion başta olmak üzere eski LucasArts oyunlarına ve 80’ler kültürüne dair tonlarca gönderme, espri ve malzeme mevcut. Yeri geliyor kendinizi dönemin popüler filminden bir sahneyi hatırlamaya çalışırken buluyorsunuz, yeri geliyor eski dostlarınızdan biri en olmadık anda ekrandan size el sallayıveriyor. Bazen de bir duvar yazısına bakıp kahkahalarla gülebiliyorsunuz. Oyun tam bir sürpriz yumurta çuvalı! Çünkü sadece Maniac Mansion’ın yayınlandığı yılda geçmekle kalmıyor, onunla aynı evrende yer alıyor. Mesela kasabadaki restoranı işleten Sandy ve Dave direkt olarak MM’daki karakterlerimizden ikisi. Delores’in malikânesi de aslında sarkaçlı saatiyle, mutfağıyla, buzdolabındaki ketçabıyla ve kütüphanesiyle Doktor Fred’in malikânesi.

Kütüphane demişken, Mansion Mansion’da (evet, adı cidden bu) yer alan kitaplara mutlaka göz atın derim. Kickstarter destekçilerinin yolladığı iki sayfalık metinlerden oluşan bu ciltlerin HEPSİ okunabiliyor ve bazıları cidden çok eğlenceli başlıklara ya da metinlere sahip. Toplamda 1056 kitap var! Onunla yarışan tek şeyse Voodoo büyücüsünün (Voodoo’suz bir Ron Gilbert oyunu asla düşünülemez) 2000’den fazla kitaba sahip olan kütüphanesi. Buradakilerin içine bakamıyorsunuz ama yine destekçiler tarafından önerilen isimleri gerçekten de muhteşem: Voodoo’nun 50 Tonu, Acemiler İçin Ruhunuzu Satma Rehberi ve Insult Sword FightingTM Rehberi gibi acayip komik şeyler var. 18 saatlik oyun süremin 1 saatini bu kitaplara bakarak harcamışımdır muhtemelen.

Bir de 3000 kişiden oluşan telefon rehberi var tabii. Sayfalarının arasında hem oyunda aramanız gereken kişilerin hem de Kickstarter destekçilerinin numaralarını içeren bu rehberdeki herhangi bir kişiyi aradığınızda gerçek bir sesli mesajla karşılaşıyorsunuz. Hatta aralarında 3 tane Türk bile buldum (Türkler her yerde!). Üstelik daha her şeyin sonuna a-reno ekleyen şeriften, her şeyin sonuna a-boo ekleyen otel müdüründen (keh-keh!), diğer tüm çılgın yan karakterlerden, seslendirmelerin hiç beklemediğim kadar harika oluşundan ve pikselli grafiklerinin sanat eseri gibi göründüğünden söz etmedim bile.

Sizin anlayacağınız en ince ayrıntısına dek özenle hazırlanmış, çok zekice bir yapım Thimbleweed Park. Başlangıçta bir şeyler yanlışmış gibi geliyor, kontrol ettiğiniz ajanlardan biri birdenbire bir fabrika yangınıyla ilgili sorular sorunca “O da nereden çıktı şimdi?” oluyorsunuz. Baş karakterlerden biri Sierra oyunlarıyla dalga geçip dördüncü duvarı yıktığında bunun öylesine bir espri olduğunu sanıyorsunuz ama sonra işin içinde “çok başka şeyler” olduğunu anlıyorsunuz afallayarak. Ana menüdeyken çalan müziğe gülüp “Bu ne be? Asansör müziği gibi,” diyorsunuz, sonra bir bakıyorsunuz hakikaten de öyle. Hele son bulmacayı çözmeniz için ne yapmanız gerektiğini öğrendiğiniz bir an var ki, of! Ayakta alkışladım. 

Derken ilk başta basit bir dedektiflik macerasından ibaretmiş gibi görünen hikâye acayip bir yön alıyor ve kendinizi bir anda Monkey Island 2’den bu yana gelmiş en orijinal oyun sonuyla karşı karşıya buluveriyorsunuz! Hayran kaldım! Yıllardan beri gördüğüm en orijinal sondu.

Bu tarz oyunları seviyorsanız mutlaka tecrübe etmeniz, hatta kesinlikle kaçırmamanız gereken bir deneyim Thimbleweed Park. Çünkü şu bir gerçek: 90’lardan sonra oynadığımız macera oyunlarının %90’ının olmaya çalıştığı şey bu: Ustalar tarafından yapılmış, gerçek bir klasik.

8/10

36181202.review:
Um jogo necessário no repertório de todo mundo que sente saudades do Lucas, aquele artistão da p orra. 

É um sopro de ar fresco que mostra que o gênero não está morto e consegue vender mesmo ilhado num mar tedioso de shooters genéricos. 

Seu humor não é tããão trabalhado quanto nos jogos que ele reverencia, mas é igualmente divertido e tem um bando de easter egg/referência. Consegue-se extrair muita coisa que daria pra discutir no nosso cotidiano. Ele tem muita metalinguagem e, assim, "discute" game design e comportamentos de um gamer (exemplo mais nítido é o que um achievement-w hore precisa fazer para totalizá-lo). Aliás, dá pra notar essa característica sem precisar começar o jogo. Basta explorar as opções de video e pesquisar a origem de algumas delas.

[spoiler] O jogo é, essencialmente, uma quebra da quarta parede. Tem muita gente  "gosto, gosto, gosto, mas OPA o final não foi o quê eu esperava! JOGO LIXO, NÃO RECOMENDO. A COMUNIDADE ESTÁ MORTA!" enchendo de críticas negativas só por causa disto. Se você é desses que acha que humor e 4th wall só existem ou são permitidos em filmes de quadrinhos (moda da Marvel), se retire, mas não prejudique um mercado que já não tem tanto apelo. Compararam até com LOST (no quesito "final polêmico")... ah vão pegar uma febre amarela! Ainda tem gente que não entendeu o final daquilo e faz novatos acreditarem se tratar duma historia sobre gente já morta. Seleção natural tem suas falhas.[/spoiler]

36178618.review:
Remember Lucas Arts? Do you? Do you really? Are you sure? Because this game reeeeeeaaaally wants you to remember Lucas Arts. And if you don't, or don't like their games, then this probably isn't the game for you. If you like playing time capsules that give you a look into the past then this is an excellent game. 

But if you want to play a adventure game that displays any modicum of the progress that's been made in the industry since the early 90's, then this isn't it.

Go play Limbo, it's cheaper and doesn't rely on base level references to get by.

Не понравилось. Местный юмор не смешит, навязчивые отсылки и пародийный тон без собственно поддерживающего его юмора раздражают. Локации слишком большие, предметов слишком много.

Но нет, приходится идти в огромный город, по пути подбирая десяток предметов, случайно ввязываться в довольно продолжительные побочные истории героев, не имеющих к непосредственному расследованию никакого отношения.
В итоге, не смотря на то, что в игре есть четкий и понятный чек-лист дел, которыми действительно было бы интересно заняться: снять отпечатки пальцев, найти образец крови и тд, ты к ним не приступишь, похоже, никогда - так игра заваливает тоннами бесполезного отвлекалова.

36113550.review:
Short version:

First you break the fourth wall. Then you break the third, mistaking it for the fourth, as well. Then, the second and the first. And then you get squashed by the falling roof.




Longer version:

The designers are quite apt at what they attempt to pull off here, and never is there any doubt that they are doing it on purpose. However, it is a completely different question, whether they are doing it for better or worse.

I expected TP to be a retro-styled adventure game, with well-written dialogue, likable characters and clever puzzles. In addition, I was pretty much sure that, coming from the mind of Ron Gilbert, it would feature lots of references, some thinly disguised whining about the genre’s ill fate, and an unhealthy dose of in-jokes.

I sincerely hoped that, having been created by industry veterans, TP would offer a unique view on puzzle design, some fresh intelligent mechanics, and a stellar story I’d remember for the next decade or two.

Well, guess what? Thimbleweed Park is exactly what I expected it to be, and absolutely not what I hoped it would be. An obnoxiously nostalgic, unbearably meta, quite self-indulgent, slightly better-than-mediocre imitation of the graphic adventures of the golden era, laden with mildly amusing writing, some nice puzzles and an ending that is even uglier than Monkey Island 2’s (which is an achievement in itself). Astonishingly, I suspect that it’s just what the community wants right now.

35807125.review:
Some of the reviewers of this game say they loved Monkey Island, but then they give this game a negative review because... it's like Monkey island.

This game is criticized in the negative reviews for breaking the fourth wall, but in Monkey Island 1 and 2, Guybrush is often looking at the player and giving wink-wink comments that reference the game itself. Other characters do too. The Herman Toothrot character is especially funny at that in Monkey Island 1, with his turning to look at the player and his "can you believe this guy?" type of comments about Guybrush.

This game is also criticized for being meta (especially the ending), but Monkey island 1 and 2 both [spoiler] often remind you that the characters are just part of a game [/spoiler]. In Monkey island 2 there is a call box in the jungle where you can "talk" to a Lucas Arts representative and ask him things like "Who thought up that stupid stump joke?" and the representative asks Guybrush [spoiler] "What are you doing, playing some frustrating graphic adventure?" [/spoiler]

Some reviewers loved everything about the game but then gave it a negative review solely because of the meta ending. Is that really fair? Personally, I liked the ending, escpecially the part where the original wireframe Kickstarter concept world was included in it.

I have played many games over the years that claim to be "like Monkey Island", but none of those have come anywhere as close as this one does. This game isn't as good as Monkey Island 1 (an impossibly high bar to match), but it comes very close. And it's a lot of fun to play. I've played it 3 times already (in both difficulty modes) and I know I will play it many times more.

Five Word Review: Classic homage made for today.
Favorite Thing: It had a fun cast of characters and story.
Least Favorite Thing: That interface design should have stayed dead.

Date Completed: 2017-09-26
Playtime: ~ 9h
Enjoyment: 8/10
Recommendation: Point-and-click fans will love it.

35687128.review:
[h1]Story & Characters[/h1]

The set-up is straight up Twin Peaks. Two out of town federal detectives team up with the PD of a secluded town up north to find a murderer. You venture through the town, discovering its backstory and the story of it's residences.

[b][i]Overall[/i][/b], Do you like Twin Peaks?

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

It follows a traditional point and click format with action keys and items at the bottom which are then used to interact with the world. The intergration of hotkeys for actions, items, swapping between players, makes the game much more fluent that if it weren't there at all. The gameplay feels fresh even considering the fact that it uses a very old, out-dated style of gameplay. Given that, the vast majority of the game is walking and talking. If you're familiar with Point and Click games, this should be no surprise at all.

[b][i]Overall[/i][/b], very fluent gameplay for using a very outdated style of Point & Click!

[h1]Sound, Voice, & Music[/h1]

The audio is done very cheaply. None of the sfx or dialogue is processed to accomodate for the settings. So hearing someone speak so clearly under a bridge or in a hectic inventor's laboratory or in a extremely large, crowded circus tent full of music and sounds and people. It just sounds really cheap and not thuroughly put together. There were very rare times where it seemed as though sfx were missing or had sequencing issues. There would also be points where pieces of dialogue only came out of one channel and then would came back out through all channels.

The voice acting isn't very good. A good handful of the voice acting is monotone and unconvincing. At its hightest moments, its merely passable. Nothing is done here with the intent of surpassing expectations. There were a few moments where I thought, "You couldn't do another take?" Was there really no one in the studio that thought, "Can we record that one more time?"

The music... Do you like Twin Peaks? 

[b][i]Overall[/i][/b], Sound was inconsistent and lacked continuity. Voice acting was bland.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]

The visuals is probably the best part of this game for me. Altough it is pixel art, this style of pixel art is incredibly clean and detailed. Information is presented very clearly and details in the enviroment and characters add a very respectful amount of imersion. There is tons of diversity within the settings, the objects necessary for interaction are contrasted perfectly with the background.

[b][i]Overall[/i][/b], This is abolutely the best presentation of pixel art I have seen within a game!

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

[b]Twin Peaks The Adventure Game.[/b] If that sounds funs to you, scroll up and add to cart. But for real, I enjoyed this game a lot! Even with all the grips, I cannot deny that I had a smile on my face while I was playing this. But the deformed midget in the room is that this game wears its influences on its sleeve. With that being said, I can easily recommend this game solely based on the fact that the gameplay is incredibly smooth and the story is familiar.

35282460.review:
[h1][url=store.steampowered.com/app/569860/Thimbleweed_Park/]Thimbleweek Park[/url] is an adventure game about adventure games for adventure gamers.[/h1]

This is retro done right in a perfect throwback to the genre's classic era with very noticeable improvements. It feels exactly like a long lost LucasArts game created in the early 90's and remixed with modern technology.

While it will inevitably appeal to nostalgic fans of this period, players who were not around in those golden decades may or may not fully appreciate this content. The puzzles, characters, humour and writing are all precisely what you would expect from the best Ron Gilbert titles.

Thimbleweed is more expansive and lengthy than I remember any old LucasArts adventure, which in this case is both a strength and a weakness.

Every character has its own useful to do list so you don't lose sight of the many ongoing objectives. However, sometimes too many open threads made me feel uncertain what to do next. It's all good, albeit slightly protracted. In the later stages I found myself calling the hint line to speed things up a bit.

The interface could have been streamlined and updated. There's never been any real use for the 9 individual verbs, neither back then nor today. I suppose the game wouldn't have felt as genuine without them.

[h1]Positive[/h1]
[list]
[*] Smaller self-contained flashback sections introduce new characters and settings, later revisited
[*] A true classic LucasArts style adventure with all the good bits you may remember
[*] Repeatedly breaks the 4th wall and takes numerous stabs at classic tropes of the genre
[*] An actual pixel hunt (optional)
[*] Helpful hint system (most of the time)
[*] I regularly find myself still humming the game's music weeks after completion
[/list]

[h1]Negative[/h1]
[list]
[*] Voice volume sometimes drops and plays from a single channel for one line of dialogue
[*] Many characters share identical lines and reactions despite their unique personalities
[*] A lot of numbers to note down: the game a bit excessive at what it does
[*] Old school interface does not improve the game
[/list]

Cuando pares el juego y vuelvas a nuestro tiempo -hay que ocuparse de las cosas que ocupan a los adultos-, recibirás una oleada de nostalgia que te dejará aturdido. Obviamente, no querrás parar. No querrás acabar la historia. No querrás salir de esa burbuja fabulosa en la que el tiempo se ha detenido. La estética del juego es la de sus antecesores, tal cual. 35161426.review:
I backed it on Kickstarter, and it was painfully obvious that Ron Gilbert learned the right lessons from the mistakes Tim Schafer made from the Double Fine Adventure (Broken Age) kickstarter, in both the extreme transparency of the development process as well as the execution of the final product. 

I grew up on games like Maniac Mansion, Loom and the Secret of Monkey Island, so I was really giddy to play this. The verbal interface is just like the old games and sometimes I was stuck just like the old games too (this was before the hint line was added)! A lot of people hate the ending but a lot of people (including myself) hate the ending of Monkey Island 2 so I was actually expecting to be disappointed, and I to be frank, while I could see why so many other people are disappointed, the experience with Monkey Island 2 led me to expect something like that and to be even franker, I actually liked the ending more so than Monkey Island 2's because it didn't set up the game begging for a sequel (after which Ron Gilbert left the company). 

This is also one of the few LucasArts-esque adventure games that could be played with a controller, so that's a definite bonus! 

I give this game a strong recommendation, and proof that Kickstarter has led to good things (and not just scams as its detractors claim)!

35055008.review:
I grew up with Monkey Island, Day of the Tentacle, and even the original C64 Maniac Mansion, and this game plays on my nostalgia like a fiddle. It's full of references to those games, following the same recipe of exploration and experimenting you'd be familiar with from that time. The game is also overflowing with shoutouts and nods to backers, which is pretty cool.
The game is fully voiced, and while the voiceacting can be a bit awkward at times, I felt like it only added to the 90's adventure game vibe.

If I'd have to point out any flaws in the game...I only played through Hard Mode, so I kind of only have myself to thank, but as you progress through the game, your inventory becomes quite cluttered, and with several playable characters and access to every area in the game, it can be hard to figure out what you are expected to do. It doesn't help that you gather a truckload of red herring items, and at one point the game literally asks you to look on the internet for a clue, at which point it stops being a puzzle to solve. I admit that I had to check a walkthrough more than once.

Is the game worth getting? If you're a patient person who wants a challenging Point and click adventure, sure, especially if you grew up with this genre back then.

35038528.review:
A very good adventure that self-consciously stops itself from being stellar.

What's good?  Rarely have I ever played an adventure so elaborate, with so many funny little interactions, with such tight programming, with so many neat surprises -- and even more rarely do I encounter quality adventures of such [i]length[/i] (I mean long if you don't use the in-game hint guide, or look things up, which I did not).  The game is made long, not by mundane padding, but by countless lines of fantastic dialog, bizarre occurrences one after the other, and, of course, a parade of crazy puzzles of the old-school variety, the type that make your head hurt, but when it comes down to it, have solutions that were staring you right in the flippin' face all along.

My adventure game-playing buddy and I had a blast playing [i]Thimbleweed Park[/i].  We were even ready to call it one of the supreme classics.  But then . . . the [i]ending[/i] happened.  Oh no, it's still a [i]very[/i] good game, a remarkable achievement on a number of levels; it's just that the developers sort of hamstrung themselves by being a little too clever.  As it stands, Terrible Toybox will just have to be content with adding one to the number of great neoretro adventures genre fans can enjoy.


SPOILERS AHOY!

[spoiler]
Meta.  The damned thing is meta.  Again.  Even though the game story is a funny one, it's still a mystery, with lots of clever little snake's hands and subplots that . . . don't really mean [i]anything[/i] after the big, too-clever-by-half reveal of the game's ending.  Ron Gilbert, if you see this, and I know you won't, please understand that not even your crazy die-hards will let you by a third time.  This kind of thing -- it's laziness masquerading as smarts.  Okay, I'm done!  I feel better now.[/spoiler]

35021967.review:
Mmkay. I loved it and hit it to ~80-90% through, but spoiler (which should be known):

You find dangerous red button device early in the game. I tried pushing it couple of times, but characters didnt want to press it. At ~70% I tried once again and got response "maybe I should save first?". Well, I didn't... at 80% I tried once again at end-game puzzle, and this resulted to characters exploding and game-over. Well, kind of fun gag? Well, would have been, but game reminded few times that in old Lucasarts games you couldn't die because that made adventure games more fun... Betcha you got that right - my last save was ~1-2 hours behind! I decided to watch walkthrough from youtube instead of running all those puzzles again. This was a serious design error, as there are no auto-saves or such.

Game itself is a nostalgia trip in a good way. Game is solid in many specs, but there is quite a lot of walking even with the quickmap and lack of story-dialog between characters is kind of strange (they just happen to work together for no real purpose). Also few puzzles which were not making much sense. Lot's of good stuff. Without nuke-design-error I would have given a solid 8/10, but now I'll have to drop score to 7/10.

35008036.review: Quite good, even if it didn't fully meet my unrealistic hopes, being a fan of Maniac Mansion (which there are plenty of jokes, nods, references to). This game's about thrice as long as most point and clicks (though possibly too long). It's challenging, and the puzzles are pretty good, even if there may be a little too many red herring inventory items. There may also be too many fourth-wall breaks (I think the ending would have been more effective had there been less fourth wall breaks prior to it). If you're looking for a good LucasArts style of old school point and clicks, you've found it here. You do actually get your money's worth for it. Recommended.

35006304.review:
Excelente historia, muy recomendado para jugarlo en esas tardes que no haces nada.
10/10

34994835.review:
An excellent game, a must-buy for any adventure game fan. 

The puzzles are logical and well integrated into the story, not overly hard even on the Hard level (which I recommend in order to get the full immersive experience). To summarize:
Pro
- interesting story
- interesting albeit insufficiently developed characters, 
- intelligent, funny puzzles. It also has one of the best types of puzzle: cooperative (where you use several characters to complete a task)
- intelligent humour
- nice, oldie graphics
- good length

Con
- the characters are not sufficiently developed, the relationships between them are very superficial/ one-dimensional.
- lackluster ending, probably also due to the fact you are not really invested in the characters. 

The price is not cheap, but I think it's worth it. I usually use a ratio of hours of enjoyment/price which should be higher than 1. For example a 5$ game that you finish in 2-3 hours is not really worth it, unless it had a very high enjoyment factor.

34987802.review:
The ending is a total disappointment.

34986725.review: Brilliantly executed, you must play this if Day of the Tentacle and Monkey Island are among your favourite point and click adventures.

34980591.review:
Ce jeu ne paye pas de mine, mais c'est une perle. Alors que de nombreux point'n'click récents se concentre sur le côté "jeu dans lequel vous êtes le héro", sans réelles énigmes ou puzzles (ce qui a le don de m'agacer, si je voulais me contenter de regarder une histoire se dérouler, j'irai regarder un film, merci bien), on trouve ici un univers rétro, une histoire passionnante et loufoque ainsi que des énigmes dans la pure tradition des point'n'click.
Certes, les énigmes ne sont pas toujours complexes, et certes parfois elles le sont justement trop, mais c 'est là toute la beauté des jeux de ce genre. On peut également saluer l'ingéniosité des créateurs de cette oeuvre, qui nous donnent une magnifique échappatoire lors d'énigmes insolubles, un numéro à appeler pour obtenir des indices lorsque l'on est bloqués, ce qui évite l'abus des sites proposant des solutions. 
En résumé, ce jeu m'a tenu en haleine jusqu'à la fin, et je n'espère qu'une chose, c'est que les créateurs continuent de créer, parce qu'après tous les dits "point'n'click" qui se sont révélés décevants et sans profondeur, j'ai trouvé ici tout ce que l'on peut attendre d'un jeu de ce genre.

(petite précision cela dit, je n'ai pas joué au mode facile, et je pense sincérement que ce n'est pas nécessaire, comme dit précédemment, les créateurs du jeu ont laissé la possibilité aux joueurs d'avoir des indices sur les énigmes à résoudre, jouer en mode "casu" ne ferait selon moi qu'appauvrir l'histoire)

34975608.review:
¿qué decir de un juego de Ron Gilbert?

Pues que, como todos los anteriores tras salir de Lucas Art (al  finalizar el Monkey Island II) lo empiezo con dos sentimientos contrapuestos:

-Ilusión: Hype inmenso y tremendas ganas de encontrar las mismas sensaciones que con otras aventuras gráficas de finales de los ochenta y principios de los 90 de Lucas Arts:  Maniac Mansion, Day of the tentacle, Indiana Jones, y por supuesto...Monkey Island.

-prevención: No vaya a ser que, como en otros títulos suyos posteriores a la época dorada de las aventuras gráficas, me lleve el chasco de no obtener lo que esperaba, o simplemente, no estar ante un juego ni decente.


En este caso ha sido empezar el juego y fue como si un viento fuerte se llevara las oscuras nubes de la precaución, desvaneciendo las barreras del miedo a la desilusión:

Es todo lo que esperaba y más.
Es volver a los 90 (aunque el juego se situa en un ficticio 19987 fechaq de publicación del Maniac Mansión y momento en el que comenzó todo en el género de las aventuras gráficas)
Es disfrutar con unos puzles lógicos pero no deasiado fáciles ( se tarda entre 12 y 15 horas en terminar)
Es sumergirte en una historia bien llevada y llena de sugestion
Es volver a disfrutar de unos iálogos brillantes


Todo un revival de las clásicas aventuras gráficas, con numerosos gestos a los jugones de antaño pero que
hará pasar un rato excepcional a cualquier amante de las aventuras gráficas. 

Tiene todo el humor absurdo, cínico y algo provocador que recordamos de sus juegos anteriores. Esto puede no gustar a todos los tipos de jugadores pero, desde luego, si te encantó el monkey island o cualquiera d elos otros anteriormente mencionados, comprar y jugar a este juego es casi una obligación. Es como volver a estar delante del monkey por primera vez, con... una aventura nueva por delante.

34972352.review: Definitely just as good as Monkey Island, ToonStruck, and the Day of the Tentacle were back in their heyday. The plot did, however, fall apart a little at the end; it was a bit disappointing, but not enough to ruin the rest of the game. Still worth playing by all rights. Takes 10-20 hours to play through depending if you use the hint line or not.

34967136.review:
Thimbleweed Park is definitely a neat adventure game that I'd reccomend to most of my friends who like a fun head-scratcher. Between the silly doalouge and plot points I'd say the time I put into the game was worth it.

Although, I do have two issues with the game. First being that certain elements of the story are pretty predictable, but to be honest that's HARDLY a serious issue for this game. Second issue being the in game guide that is provided for you, it enables the player to just jog through the game with little effort. And for those who would abuse the guide to rush through and experience the story I'd say the game becomes hardly worth playing at that point... But to be fair, even without the in game guide anybody can just alt+tab out of the game and find a guide online. So maybe the in game guide isn't that much of an issue since it doesn't give you the answers you're looking for immediately so much as nudge you in the right direction.

Eh, whatever. Is good game. Go buy it.

34961270.review:
A very creditable and well-made homage to old titles like Zak McKracken and the Alien Mindbenders and Day of the Tentacle. The puzzling isn't quite as obscure as it used to be (which is a good thing) and the few stumpers there are can be overcome with the in-game hint system. The graphics are good and appropriately in the style of, the sounds and music are adequate, and the voice-acting is nearly seamless (Javier Lacroix being the weak link here by a little). If you're into the old LucasArts adventure games, or the more recent Wadjet Eye games, this is right up your alley.

The full game (hard mode) takes about 10 hours.

Criticisms:

With "In-joke mode" on, there's a lot of bagging on Sierra. I get that this is Ron Gilbert, SCUMM, and in the LucasArts camp (which had a rivalry with team Sierra back in the day) but it's kind of obnoxious. It doesn't seem light-hearted either, it seems pointed and mean. Especially after so much time has passed, and doubly so that nobody from Sierra is still involved to carry on the rivalry; it comes across as petty and ungrateful to the people who built the genre that allowed games like this to exist.

If hard mode takes you 10 hours, by the end literally about an hour will have been spent waiting for elevators, and another hour in back-tracking. "Hard mode" for some reason only gives you 1 quick travel map between 4 characters, meaning you either end up passing the baton a lot or backtracking a LOT. This doesn't make anything harder, it simply wastes the hours of your life, and was a poor choice of difficulty mechanic.

Achievement hunting in this one is another totally un-challenging time-waster. Full achievement completion requires going through the game twice (even if you beat hard first), and also poring through kickstarter contributor content. Not fun, not challenging, not interesting. 

You can skip these complaints by playing casual mode, skipping achievements, and keeping "in-jokes" turned off, but then it's a little light on content for the price tag ($20). But complaints aside, this really is a nice retro-style adventure.

34960563.review:
Apres 9 heures de jeu, je rends ma petite conclusion et il faut choisir entre "Oui" ou "Non" (Le monde des evaluations de STEAM est cruel) et je vais dire "NON" ...
Que de plaisir de retourner et retrouver l'univers Old School à la LucasArts du Point And Click, des persos bien ecrits (enfin certains), de l'humour absurde comme on aime, des enigmes tout aussi absurde (voir trop) qui vous feront galerer pendant des heures alors que la réponse est sous votre nez depuis le début.
Tout commence si bien dans le meilleur des mondes quand on demarre l'aventure sous forme d'intrigue policière mélangeant du Twin Peaks, du Simpsons et du X-Files. Et la c'est le drame....
Le jeu se découpe en plusieurs chapitres où vous allez incarner différents personnages jusqu'à la limite de 5 sur les derniers chapitres. Génial vous vous dites ? Et non ca rends le jeu bêtement difficile pour pas grand chose... car a l'instars des anciennes productions LucasArts, qui dit 5 personnages dit 5 inventaires différents dont des objets qui ne sont ramassable que par certains persos, on se demande pourquoi lui et pas un autres, et des objets qui sont totalements inutiles (sans parler des objets invibles planqués derrière un décor), se qui encombre encore plus vos 5 inventaires et rends le jeu lourd. Et je vous parle même pas des phases où il faut changer des ampoules, chercher des bouquins dans des bibliothèques ou chercher numéro de teléphone dans un annuaire. C'est bête, simpliste et fainéant de la part des développeurs sur ce coup.
En parlant des personnages, à part Dolores (alors que j'aime Ransome le clown mais sous exploité), aucuns n'est intéressant par leur histoire (ou est connecté à un autre protagoniste) et ne justifie le scénario qui commence comme une intrigue policière, qui finit dans une espèce de suffisance speudo branlette meta sur le jeu, sans même que la situation de base ne soit vraiment résolu. 
Donc ce qui fait qu'on passe son temps à se demander où il faut aller (ex: le livre d'incantion ou le passage du burger), ce qu'il faut faire et pourquoi on le fait (ex: passage avec Ransome ou faut nourrir la sourit pour qu'il sorte du cirque ou faire peur 2 fois de la même facon dans l'hotel).
La musique est inexistante à part le thème de la ville que vous allez entendre pendant des heures à force de faire des allés/retours dedans.
Aprés avoir endurer 9 heures de jeu, j'ai juste une envie... Retourner sur Monkey Island ou Full Throttle. On m'a vendu un jeu dans la plus pur tradition LucasArts et je me retrouve avec un jeu faussement nostalgique pour faire plaisir au vieux de la première heure ayant aimé cette époque révolu. Mais sans jamais faire mouche dans l'humour, sans jamais être touchant, sans jamais être inventif.

Conclusion : Jouer a Déponia, Armikrog ou les anciens LucasArts.

34953055.review:
Пройдя эту игру я некоторое время озадаченно сидел, уставившись в экран, перебирая в голове увиденные события и упорядочивая сюжетные линии персонажей. Мне потребовались сутки, что бы переварить данное произведение и наконец-то сформулировать своё отношение к нему. Пожалуй, можно сказать, что Thimbleweed Park меня разочаровал.

С одной стороны мы имеем классический point-and-click квест образца прошлого века, предлагающий приятную графику со стилизацией под качественный пиксель-арт, нарочито топорный в исполнении игровых механик и анимаций дабы не разрушать иллюзию принадлежности к 80-м. Колоритные и запоминающиеся персонажи, верные сложившимся стереотипам от начала и до конца разыгрывают столь характерные для подобных квестов истории и сценки, жонглируя ожидаемыми классическими шутками и жанровыми подколами. Атмосфера города прекрасно передана, представляя собой этакую помесь Twin Peaks и X-Files. Музыка хорошо вписывается в антураж и периодически вызывает желание просто позалипать под неё. Головоломки не лишены здравого смысла и по большей части построены на девяти доступных дейсвтиях с предметами, без опостылого пиксельхантинга и избыточной замудрённости. И вроде всё хорошо... Так что же мне в игре так не понравилось-то?

Сюжет. Увы, чем ближе мы приближаемся к развязке, тем больше игра отстраняется от всего того, что казалось важным, и тем чаще прибегает к дешёвым приёмам класса deus-ex machina. Финал в некотором смысле умудряется грубо перечеркнуть всё, что ему предшествовало, обессмысливая прежние события и оставляя на сердце некоторую пустоту, заполнить которую игра старается концовками-пустышками. У нас на глазах показательно ломают 4-ю стену, после чего просто забивают на дальнейшие попытки свести концы и дать ответы на вопросы изначальной детективной истории. Как человек, честно ждавший продуманной развязки (в духе фильма The Clue) я был совершенно разочарован. Ощущение, будто авторы так и не смогли придумать, чем должна закончиться начатая ими история, и решали просто упразднить её, сделав бессмысленной. Кроме того, в какой-то момент наличие аж 5 раздельных персонажей, каждый со своим инвентарём, становится не столько фишкой игры, сколько раздражающей помехой, что отрицательно сказывается на игровом процессе в целом. 

Наверное, далеко не все согласятся со мной. Найдутся люди, которым пришёлся по вкусу данный сюжетный поворот, или же число достоинств игры в их глазах с лёгкостью перевесит недостаток повествования. Это отлично сделанная игра, которая принесёт массу удовольствия в процессе прохождения. Но в том случае, если для вас, как и для меня, законченный и выдержанный от начала и до конца сюжет имеет в квестах первостепенное значение, имейте ввиду, что Thimbleweed Park может очень разочаровать своим финалом, так и не ответив на вопросы, которые казались важными в начале.

Visual - 9
Audio - 9
Story - 5
GPlay - 7

Total - 7.5

34952507.review:
[h1]UNA DELICIA PARA AMANTES DEL GÉNERO[/h1]

Este juego es un genial revival de aquellas aventuras graficas de finales de los 80 y principios de los 90 creadas por lucas film games, posteriormente lucas arts, y por ello es una cita inexcusable para todos los que disfrutamos con juegos como los maniac mansion o los monkey island de los que bebe directamente. No es una obra maestra pero es una gran aventura con puzzles y diálogos a la altura de sus predecesores.

Me han encantado la historia, la ambientación y los personajes ya que recupera todo de aquella atmósfera tan loca, tan extraña, tan inmersiva, tan... no se como explicarlo pero os aseguro que en algunos momentos me he sentido viajando atrás en el tiempo, jugando con mi 4,86 clónico y derritiéndoseme el cerebro con algun puzzle absurdo mientras una dulce melodía sintética no dejaba de sonar una y otra vez.

No todo van a ser flores y creo que algún detalle se debería haber cuidado un poco más como la estructura narrativa, considero que la fragmentación de la aventura en capítulos no era la mejor forma para avanzar en el juego, y por otra parte creo que la interacción de los personajes no está bien desarrollada, provocando alguna confusión o mostrando falta de coherencia en algunos momentos. En cualquier caso son detalles que no empañan un resultado muy satisfactorio para la experiencia del jugador que en ningún momento se va a ver arrinconado en un callejón sin salida ni a tropezarse con un bug como los de la época.

En resumen, una aventura gráfica larga y divertida, difícil (ni se os ocurra jugar el modo casual, por favor...) pero justa, y sobre todo entrañable.

Os la recomiendo.


Saludos,

[b] [i] Eoghan[/i][/b]

34942395.review: Get it! It's great. Especially if you played Maniac Mansion - you will love all the references to that game.

34942228.review:
Oh wow, Thimbleweed Park™ is amazing!

It takes me back to the days of Maniac Mansion, Day of the Tentacle, Monkey Island, Lesuire Suit Larry, etc.

The game is lovingly crafted, with a well-written engaging story, and some in-depth thinking.

Naturally, there are occasions of "use pulley with chicken" moments from out of left field, especially in hard mode, but this is what I signed up for. In most cases the pieces will come together, the in-game hint line can be handy, and the personal satisfaction for finally figuring it out is worth it.

There's a rare issue where a voice line will only come through one channel (it's not that line in perticular, it happens with repeated lines) but then it's fine again.

34939241.review:
Ce jeu est tout simplement génial :)
Absurde, loufoque, vous plongerez dans l'histoire comme avec un bon vieu Monkey Island.
Je n'ai pas décroché, jusqu'à le terminer.
Nostalgie des jeux Lucas Art ? Peut-être, volonté de résoudre toutes ces énigmes et d'avancer dans l'histoire ? Evidemment.
Quel plaisir de lire les dialogues (#laconfiance) et de naviguer entre tout ces personnages auxquels ont fini par s'attacher.
Les graphismes sont beaux, les dialogues sont drôles et l'histoire, bien que farfelu (je n'en attendais pas moins), est prenante.
C'est ma première évaluation, je ne pensais même pas en faire une un jour, ce jeu mérite, tout simplement.
Musique répétivite, scénario et combinaisons parfois tirés par les cheveux, mais les amateurs du genre y sont habitués et c'est aussi pour ça que l'on passe environ 20 heures à résoudre cette sombre affaire de meurtre (est-ce bien la seule motivation des agents ?).

J'espère sincèrement que Ron Gilbert ne s'arrêtera pas en si bon chemin, et pourquoi pas, un nouveau Monkey Island dans les cartons ?!

DERRIERE VOUS !!! UN SINGE A TROIS TÊTES !!!

34928576.review:
This game heralds back to the lucasfilm/arts greats - monkey island, maniac mansion, etc... If you played those and liked them, then you're sure to like this one as well.  

Just don't expect too much from the ending.

34925999.review: Stay for all of the credits. A classic adventure game that is fun and has just the right amount of challenge and absurdity. The cast is well-written and provided laughs. Bonus points if you can spot all of the adventure game references. There are many. Some have complained about the ending; however, I think the designers did a good job with wrangling the loose ends as the adventure game conceit is that there is likely a ridiculous denoument. In any case, buy the game and enjoy it. Also, game design is a noble profession. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise.

34916050.review:
You should play it if you like adventure games from 80-90s. It's a classic point and click game with a good dose of humor, likable (though perhaps a bit cliche) characters and challenging puzzles.

You will likely be stuck on a puzzle or two, at least in the "hard" mode, but they don't feel too absurd or "guess the arbitrary reasoning"-like. Most puzzles seem to be fairly reasonable and logical, sometimes it's "why haven't I think of that before" thing. All I can complain about is that the puzzles are sometimes exposed to the player too early, so you waste some time trying to solve them without the required items and then forget about them later, when it's time to solve them. On the other hand, it doesn't feel like it's the design's fault and there's also an in-game hint hotline, which is pretty well designed. It doesn't spoil everything right away, but tends to give you vague hints first.

The art itself is solid, but the way it's displayed in the engine bothers me. Uneven pixels in pixel art games are my pet peeve and this game has plenty. It simply doesn't care if, for example, it displays the character in half of the background pixel or scales it so the background pixels are bigger than the character's. I don't get why modern pixel art games don't care about being self-consistent pixel-size-wise, all it takes from the technical point of view is a simple render target that's smaller than the screen.

Overall, I had fun playing the game, but the ending felt lazy and WTF-ish. [spoiler]I really wanted to solve the murder's case, but the game's universe just "blew up" instead. Possibly innocent Willy was jailed 'til the very end (it seems to be optional to free him) and everyone started to care about their personal goals. When you solved the character's goal, the character stopped being playable, possibly just ceased to exist (?). It really didn't make that much sense and felt pretty unsatisfying, unsolved.[/spoiler] It doesn't bother me that much though, since the rest of the story was pretty solid.

34910622.review: Un gran juego al estilo de las aventuras gráficas antiguas  Maniac Mansion o Day of Tentacle.  Tiene una trama que engancha fácilmente, no te lo puedes perder!

34909340.review:
Это просто великолепная игрушка, с первой сцены и до последней строчки "титров". 
Как знатный фанат старых квестов, заявляю - ГОДНОТА.

Однозначно 10из10.

34904076.review:
I love adventure games, but I hate playing most of them. Why? Because of "click everywhere, collect every item possible and combine them in most unintuitive way with a random pixel in the environment just to achieve something devs thought was a good idea" situations most of them are full of. 

This one is simply not like that. It's a really well designed game that just makes sense. It is made in a style of old monkey island era games, but is not just a nostalgia based money grab. I highly reccommend this one.

34902274.review: Fantastic game that brings me back to the classic Lucasfilm days of Monkey Island and Maniac Mansion.

34898372.review:
Ron Gilbert, un nome che molti videogiocatori giovani non avranno mai sentito nominare ma che per molti videogiocatori d'annata rievoca bellissime avventure piratesche e tentacoli alieni colorati del periodo d'oro delle avventure grafiche su PC.
Il nostro Ron ha deciso di tornare agli albori del genere producendo questo Thimbleweed Park, grazie anche ad una campagna Kickstarter che ha avuto un successo enorme e ha permesso di raggiungere praticamente tutti i goal.
Il gioco si presenta appunto come una vecchia avventura grafica, con una grafica pixellosa (ma stilosa e ben curata) ed il classico menù dei giochi basati su SCUMM, con i verbi per le azioni sulla sinistra e l'invetario degli oggetti sulla destra.
Thimbleweed Park ci narra le avventure di due investigatori alla ricerca del colpevole di un omicidio e di altri strambi personaggi che abitano la "ridente" cittadina. Molto presto capirete che c'è ben alto dietro l'omicidio e soprattutto un'avventura ricca di comicità e di superamenti della quarta parete (i personaggi spesso parlano con il giocatore e fanno citazioni esterne al contesto/gioco).
Le musiche sono molto belle e presto vi rimarranno in testa, con motivetti molto orecchiabili e dal classico stile retrò.
E' possibile scegliere all'inizio del gioco il livello di difficoltà voluto, con una difficoltà casual per i nuovi arrivati ed una difficile per i veterani delle avventure grafiche (più enigmi e più contorti).
In realtà il gioco l'ho trovato piuttosto facile nel complesso e c'è anche da considerare che è disponibile un aiuto in game (chiamando HintTron, come vedrete in vari volantini del gioco) che semplifica di molto i dubbi sul come andare avanti, quindi consiglierei la modalità difficile in tutti i casi per potersi godere appieno tutti gli enigmi.
Che dire, se siete fan dei capostipiti del genere non fatevi sfuggire questo nuovo capolavoro che finalmente si scollega un po' dai film interattivi che sono diventati ora le avventure grafiche, se invece non lo siete vedete di recuperare (ScummVM *cough*) i grandi classici e di visitare al più presto Thimbleweed Park !

34891910.review:
This game is excellent. Where other new point & click adventures fail, this one delivers. It feels exactly like a game from LucasArts's heyday. And it is superfunny. Seriously, I've only played for an hour, yet I found myself laughing all the time, constantly curious what weird something-or-other I might discover next. If you like ZakMcKracken, Monkey Island, Day of the Tentacle etc, go play this game. Don't wait-a-reno.

Edit:
I played the game in hard mode, and it took me about 13 hours to finish it. The puzzles are not as outlandish as many game reviews have suggested. I ended up calling the in-game hint line a couple of time towards  the end, only to find out that the solutions I was looking for were perfectly logical and visible. Just remember you can push and pull things, and you'll be ok ;)
The game stays weird and funny throughout. It takes a bit of getting used to having all these characters at your disposal and to understand some of them might do things other won't (yes, just make the clown do it). The ending is satisfactory - in this day and age not as mindblowing as it might have been in 1987 - you sort of see it coming at some point, and then you wonder, and you need to find out, and then you find you were almost on the right track, but not quite.

Perhaps I should play it again in easy mode. There are a few specks of dust left unfound.

Love this game. Want more.
