32030192.review:
OK. So wow.

On it's own the game stands bold as an interesting story betweem different characters, how they link with each other and how solving a mystery becomes everyone's business.

It's a fun point and click adventure game however the amount of polish made to the game is wonderous. You never come to a puzzle that feels unfair and with a bit of logic it's pretty rewarding solving puzzles as you progress through the game - which frequently rewards you by shwoing showing you more of the story and letting you feel a bit smarter for your puzzle-solving skills!

The controls are easy to get to grips with and the ability to change between characters means that when you get to a roadblock because of a hard puzzle, you can work through the other character stories and come back to the hard puzzle with a fresh mind to tackle it from another angle.

The music and sound of the game matches the artwork and is georgous. It's a treat for the eyes and ears and something that stands tall from the rest of games availble from Steam.

Buy it. Play it. Enjoy it. Remember it.

32023132.review:
I played and loved almost all of the old adventure games Thimbleweed Park is based on, and I can confidently tell you to avoid this game. It is meant as a meta-loveletter of sorts to games of this type, like Monkey Island and Maniac Mansion, but unfortunately misses the mark in several key ways.

- PCs who seem to have too much out-of-character knowledge and the player, despite the inclusion of a to-do list, has no clear indication of what they're current goals are.

- Horrible, third-rate voice acting. Seriously, it's so ameteurish that it harkens back to the early CD-ROM days when they would get any old nobody to provide the voices for the characters. The male federal agent in particular is supposed to have some kind of Latino accent but it mostly comes across as a grating lisp performed by someone who watched a telenovella once.

- Several involved, non-sensical puzzles. And not in a "non-sensical in a funny adventure game way" but non-sensical in a "this is unituitive and no player would think in this way" way. There are puzzles you can only solve by going to locations that the character you have selected would have no reason to visit in the narrative.

- All this could be forgiven if the game was funny and/or well-written a la Monkey Island, but it isn't. It is, in fact, unfunny in the most tragic way: it winks at you the whole time as if it's self-awareness is supposed to make up for the fact that the writers can't write funny dialogue. 

- Of the 5 different PCs, only one of these characters, the young game-enthusiast, is at all likable, and the female federal agent character stands out as being particularly nasty for no established reason, other than the fact that the writers thought it would be funny to have a "sardonic" character and then wrote no funny lines for her.

I backed this game on Kickstarter because of the genre it pays homage to and pedigree behind it's developers. I'm shocked and dismayed to see the final product faceplant so profoundly.

I received this game as a gift.  I absolutely loved it.  The amount of jokes and queue points taken from the 80's is on point. On the format of Point-and-Click.  This game has a very fluid story with no "what do I do now" moments.  On "Casual" mode, the puzzles are simple enough for anyone just getting into these types of games as well as remaining enjoyable from a veteren viewpoint.  On "Hard" mode, the puzzles devolve into to delicious delicious PnC Adventure puzzles. None of which are extremely abstract, and there was always something in the game that pointed you in the right direction.

Very enjoyable game, I 100%'d the game through 2.5 playthroughs.  My Hard (first) playthrough was about 12 hours, my Causal was about 5 hours.  If I had not played the game before, I would say my casual would have been about 7 or 8.

Definite recommendation.

31810010.review:
Thimbleweed Park was an absolute joy to play. It definitely feels like a spiritual sequel to Maniac Mansion. While it borrows many of its jokes from other LucasArts games such as Monkey Island, it's full of references to the 80s as well. Now, as far as the ending is concerned, [spoiler]initially I found it to be too meta for my liking, but then I grew to appreciate it, as it undoubtedly fits with the overall tone of the game.[/spoiler]

Something I did not enjoy was the repetitive dialogue at times (a lot of the characters would share the same lines), although I do understand that was most likely due to budget restraints. Expanding on that, the "look at" options were mostly "hit or miss," in the sense that while some of them were genuinely clever and funny, others were boring and dull. I was also a bit disappointed by the lack of things to "look at," but, again, I understand this was probably due to the limited budget, as well.

All in all, I would definitely recommend this game to any adventure fan, it's worth the price tag. if you cannot get it now, absolutely get it on sale, or you'll be missing out on one of the best adventures of the last fifteen years.

31793921.review:
Una aventura gráfica con estilo clásico de Ron Gilbert y Gary Winnick (que trabajaron en Monkey Island 1 y 2, Maniac Mansion, Day of the Tentacle, Loom, Pijama Sam entre otras). 

Parece como si fuese una aventura gráfica de LucasArts que nunca he jugado: el humor, las rupturas del cuarto muro y los dialogos con esa mezcla de humor absurdista e inteligente hace que estos personajes sean encantadores y entretenidos de ver como interactuan. La historia está bien desarrollada y los puzzles nunca llegan a ser demasiado crípticos pero tampoco son fáciles (lo jugué en difícil pero hay una opción llamada 'modo casual' en el que los puzzles son más fáciles) algunos de los puzzles son muy imaginativos pero creo que ninguno es algo completamente nuevo que no había visto nunca y eso es el tema con este juego: no hay nada particularmente rompedor, es lo mismo que esta gente nos dio cuando estaban en Lucas y a mi eso me vale.

Es entretenida, graciosa y la música y el pixelart son una maravilla.

31792036.review:
Thimbleweed Park is indeed like a classic point and click adventure game from the Golden Age. Just like the Kickstarter promised and I'm very happy I backed it up.

Just like in the good old Lucasfilm Games adventures, most of the puzzles are obvious (usually when you've accidentally figured it out) and some are just mindbendingly weird. And then there's one or two of those impossibly absurd ones, not going to spoil anything here, though.

The graphics are awesome in their own way and use the modern tricks pretty nicely, while still giving the classic air to the game. Multiple characters are fun and I found the story amusing, even though I have to say I could've lived with a bit less of winking at the other adventure games... Still, lots of fun and amusement. I'll happily recommend this to anyone who's not afraid of pixel art and a bit of the good old days.


Now if I only could get Tuna Head by Razor and the Scummettess out of my head's internal jukebox... It's been stuck in there for days now :p

31694085.review:
NOTE: This game was played on Hard Mode.

Oh ma. This game is a real toughie to review.

I gotta give it points for the wisecracking and meta level humor though.

The thing is: A lot of times, I had to use a walkthrough to get past some of the puzzles. It's not that the puzzles themselves were too hard. It's just that sometimes, there's no logical link between what is available and what can be accomplished.

Let me give some examples: (WARNING! SPOILERS AHEAD!)

1. So when Delores needed a stamp to send her letter to Mmucus Flem, I had no idea you could get the stamp by steaming the letter for her father in the microwave.

2. Then there was the time I had to give the ghost in the elevator ice cake. Besides how strange it was there was cake that ghosts could eat, how was I supposed to know that all I had to do was make Franklin chill the cake?

3. I had already explored the Madame Whats-her-name's shop before needing to have the Book of the Dead. Even then, I couldn't tell it was even glowing.

4. How was I supposed to make the connection to use the radioactive stuff from the old silo to see the footprints someone made to get through the forest?

5. How was I supposed to know that all I had to do was just push the trampoline so that Ransome would jump on it to get the lost page.

Hindsight is 20/20 of course. Regardless, the need to go and look up stuff in a walkthrough really takes a player out of the game and the narrative that unfolds.

Speaking of which, the whole "There's a rouge AI trying to take over/destroy ther town" could be seen a mile away.  Echoes of The 13th Floor could also be heard closer to the end. Not exactly all that original plotwise.

I dunno. Maybe I would have enoyed the game more if I played it on the Easy setting. Except that the difficulty setting can't be changed once the game is started. 

If I could, I'd give the game a sideways thumb, which is neither a thumbs up or thumbs down. Since that is not an option though, I'm going to go ahead and give the benefit of the doubt to the peopke who made the game with a thumbs up.

In all seriousness, the lack of logical connections to complete puzzles really does need to be addressed.

31675803.review:
Thimbleweed Park is a point-and-click adventure game created by Ron Gilbert and Gary Winnick, two game developers who worked on games like Maniac Mansion and Monkey Island.

Thimbleweed Park takes place in, as the name suggests, the town of Thimbleweed Park, which has a population of 80 people. The first two playable characters are satirically based on Fox Mulder and Dana Scully from The X-files. Agent Angela Ray is the senior, experienced "no nonsense" detective, while Antonio Reyes serves as the young, aspiring detective. Both detectives are charged with investigating a murder that happened on the bridge outside of town. Including the two agents, there are 5 playable characters total, but the other 3 come at a later time.

The characters are interchangeable, though their dialogue only changes slightly when asking questions. In most adventure games, I often find it tiresome and odious when I'm required to switch characters to do certain puzzles while carrying specific items, but Terrible Toybox nailed this concept down. It doesn't matter which character is carrying what, since all puzzles can be solved by any character. Items can be traded with characters as well.

The biggest feature of this game is that there are no game overs, you cannot die, and you cannot screw yourself over by putting yourself in an unwinnable situation (*cough* King's Quest 5 *cough*). Terrible Toybox specifically tailored the game so that you will be able to solve any puzzle without consequence. The game has two modes, Casual and Hard, but this only means that there are more complicated puzzles to solve in Hard. Some puzzles can be difficult, but all of them are logical, so there's no need to use items on every single corner of the screen like in the old days. The game's characters are interesting and well-written with pretty good voice acting. Everyone has their own little quirk, and the writing is clever, snarky, and funny at the same time. Willie ended up becoming my favorite character. 

My grievances with the game are slight. Personally, it took some time for me to get used to the UI and commands. Commands like "push" and "pull" felt redundant when you can simply right click on something to do the action with "use". There are some items in Casual mode that are only used in Hard mode, and will sit in your inventory for the entirety of the game. 

Additionally, there are a few puzzles in Casual mode that might cause you to overthink. For a non-spoiler related example, early on in the game Ray and Reyes need county maps in order to explore the rest of the tri-county area. You can find a genuine county map, but it needs to be printed. The printer says that it requires a nickel to use. In order to get the nickel, you need to recycle a bottle at the Quickie Pal. Since I had a whiskey bottle in my inventory, I tried to trade it in at the clerk, but had no luck. I spent about 20 minutes looking for a different bottle before I realized that I could just print the map with no cost. Perhaps I was overthinking it, but I felt like an idiot for trying to solve a puzzle that wasn't even in my game mode.

Finally, there's the ending. I'm not going to give it away, but I think it's going to leave some people dissatisfied; not because it's poorly written, but because it's so...unorthodox.

Barring some minor frustrating details, this is the most fun I have had with an adventure game for a long time. I give it a 9/10.

Offrire un’opinione riguardo Thimbleweed Park è molto più difficile di quel che potrebbe sembrare.

Certo, per i canoni assoluti e sempliciotti dell’internet moderno è una bazzecola:

[b]pollice in alto, compratelo tutti, tanti saluti.[/b]

Ma siccome parliamo di un gioco pensato anzitutto per gente di un certo livello™, capite da voi che la faccenda merita ben altro trattamento:

Diciamo che, se The Secret of Monkey Island I e II rappresentavano un spensierato amore di cuore, Thimbleweed Park risulta un intenso sentimento cerebrale che sguazza consapevolmente della nostra nostalgia con il vago intento di ucciderla, e quindi superarla.

Morale ?

Amo ciò che rappresenta, il modo in cui è stato costruito, e mi pare un esperimento assolutamente riuscito…

Eppure come Avventura la trovo un po’ una beta, la crisalide di un qualcosa di più grande figlio del medesimo autore, la prima scossa di un sisma di cui il genere (nonché tutta l’industria) avrebbe decisamente bisogno.

E boh, io ci spero, fan *bip*!

31637052.review:
How many hours did I spend playing Maniac Mansion as a kid? Probably literal weeks out of my life were spent trying to reach every conceivable ending. And I became a bit obsessed with Green Tentacle, I'll admit. Back then, there were no walkthroughs available at the click of a mouse button, so it meant trial and error with tons of backtracking and enduring endless repetitive dialogues. BUT THAT'S WHAT MADE IT SO AWESOME! (Also, running away in terror from Nurse Edna -- shudder.) I think that if you didn't grow up playing adventure games (I started with simple text-based ones on my Commodore 128D), then this game might feel too slow or repetitive. For those of us who remember the classics, all the references (both subtle and overt) to old adventure games -- Maniac Mansion especially (the broken ketchup bottles!!!) are totally delightful. I absolutely love this game. I've only made it to Part 3 so far on hard mode with no walkthrough or hints, but so far, it's brilliant. My only regret is that I didn't find out about it until after the Kickstarter ended -- otherwise, I would have backed this game to the max. I think that the best way to enjoy Thimbleweed Park, in my opinion, is to just take your time and explore everything. Collect those dust specks! Click on the same thing again...and again...just to see what happens. Rushing through the game would ruin the experience, and even if some parts seem inefficient, it's the journey, not the goal that makes the experience so worthwhile.  

10/10

31619581.review:
As a long time adventure game fan (including maniac mansion), I was delighted by Thimbleweed Park. The characters and setting are nearly perfect, the game and puzzle design are well thought out, the tone and experience are great, and even the graphics, sounds, and music are quite well done. Ransome the bleeping Clown and Delores truly shine as characters and the rest are good too. There's a number of in jokes for fans old maniac mansion and other lucasarts games, but they're not core to the story. The game leans pretty heavily on the 4th wall, which you'd expect from a Kickstarter fueled by nostalgia.

Overall I loved this game, but the overall story is where things go a little awry. The story relies on tired tropes near the end and completely discards the murder investigation thread without a truly satisfying ending to it. Things ultimately make some sense, but there's a growing number of plot holes surrounding some of the game's events once the antagonist is revealed.

All characters have their arcs nicely tied up in some fashion, and it's a satisfactory conclusion, but the ending went in a different direction than I had hoped and the events of the story didn't make sense in retrospect (some of this is explained by the nature of the ending, but I find that a bit of a cop out for something that presents itself as a murder mystery)

Anyway, buy, play, and love this game. It's worth your time and you'll be glad you did.

31603722.review:
I think Terrible Toybox nailed this. They pitched it on Kickstarter as a forgotten point and click adventure from the early 90s, and that's what they delivered. The engine and UI are quite a bit better than those earlier SCUMM-engine games, but it feels right. I admit I never played Maniac Mansion, the inspiration for Thimbleweed Park, but I can see I probably would have enjoyed it. In Thimbleweed Park you control five separate characters, each introduced gradually in the early stages of the game. At first they almost feel superfluous, the first two characters Rey and Reyes are interchangeable and even say the exact same things when you interact with objects. I found this rather disappointing, especially as half the fun is hearing all the responses you get from interacting with the world in different ways. In some ways the game might have been better with just one character at first. Fortunately things quickly improve as more characters are introduced, and each takes on their own personality. It won't be long before you realise you're getting quite attached to them.

There are plenty of puzzles to solve, often involving more than one character, but fortunately each character has his/her own diary which keeps track. I never found myself completely stumped about what to do next, although I did get somewhat stuck in a few places. Most of the time I came back the next day and figured it out, and only once did I have to check a hint guide (incremental hints) which gave me enough of a clue on where to go next. I can live with that!

The ending is going to be divisive. Frankly my initial reaction was one of disappointment once the game's intentions were revealed, perhaps because it felt like a cheap way of resolving a few of the town's mysteries. Yet playing through those final moments, knowing where it was all going, ended up being quite satisfying, even emotional.

I played two point and click adventure games lately, this and Paradigm. Both are excellent in different ways. Paradigm is considerably funnier, but Thimbleweed Park has better puzzles. Both are recommended. And to think they once declared the adventure game was dead, hah.

31601681.review: Finito in modalità difficile! Veramente delizioso e in diversi punti del gioco effettivamente non è stato facile nonostante fossimo in due a giocarci tutte le volte. Sinceramente non so se le nuove generazioni apprezzeranno fino in fondo questo gioco ma a me poco importa, questo è stato palesemente creato per noi "vecchiardi" appassionati che hanno giocato in passato con le altre avventure punta e clicca (sia create da Gilbert con la "MMucasFlem", sia di altre case) e che possono cogliere tutte le citazioni (o quasi), l'ironia e i riferimenti a quegli anni in cui questi giochi erano considerati delle opere d'arte (pixelate). E' stato come cominciare un nuovo Monkey Island e mi aspetto che ne facciano altre altrettanto gustose. Consiglio comunque a [b] tutti [/b] di provare ad immergersi (con pazienza) in questa avventura. Un ringraziamento di cuore ai creatori.

31593649.review:
Ladies and gentlemen, as someone whose teenage years as a gamer were totally defined by [i]Monkey Island[/i], [i]Grim Fandango[/i] and related games, let me tell you something: this just might be the definitive adventure game of all time. 10/10, would defy the sheriff-a-reno to escape to the sewers and hunt shrooms for a bitchy old psychic again.

To be sure, it's got a few flaws if you search for them, as some reviewers have: a few too many clever '80s references, a couple of minor but irritating bugs (e.g. the on-off status of the caps lock key randomly influences whether keyboard shortcuts work), and a couple of logical leaps where the different playable characters have to read each other's minds-- though honestly, this is a damn adventure game, so just be glad you aren't making a fake moustache out of cat whiskers or trampolining off of a rubber skin costume stretched over a manhole. But overall, this game takes everything that has ever defined the very best of this genre, puts it all in one place, and uniformly improves on it.

Play it on Hard mode, the way God and/or Ron Gilbert intended it, and you'll find an enormous network of brilliantly intertwined puzzles that range from "easy but clever" to "spend 2 hours hunting for the solution in-game, then wake up at 2 a.m. and sneak out of bed to crank up your PC as the solution bursts forth from your Thimbleweed-fevered subconscious". What's really amazing about this game is that every single one of the puzzles is completely logical and accessible if you just pay enough attention. You can pick up, manipulate, and get interesting descriptions etc. out of tons of objects that you won't actually use-- so interactivity isn't automatically a hint that it matters to gameplay. Red herrings abound. But each interaction leads you gently along to the next, and you'll still get enough subtle hints from descriptions and even fail responses ("I can't do X with Y") that you'll eventually figure it out.

I never played [i]Maniac Mansion[/i] or [i]Day of the Tentacle[/i] back in the day, and when [i]DotT: Remastered[/i] came out, I couldn't get into it at all because (among other things) coordinating the multiple characters seemed like way too much of a pain. Here, not only are the individual characters handled beautifully (all well-written, with comedy props to Ransome and infinite all-around identifiable coolness points to Delores), but their puzzly interactions all work smoothly, and a few of them even have well-written stories that they share between them-- Franklin and Delores in particular.

For all the complaints about excessive nod-and-wink references, over-the-top fan service (taken to a literal extreme in one case near the end), and breaking of the fourth wall, the game pulls it all together at the end in a sort of hypercube-level breaking of the fourth wall squared that is truly a delight to experience. Not everyone will like the ending, but it's impressively well executed, like everything else in this game. If you love adventure games, buy it today. If you don't love adventure games yet, try this game on for size, and if you don't like it, then consider that as definitive proof that this genre is not for you-- because this game captures everything that's great about adventure games, and adds to it, right down to a uniquely great soundtrack and voice acting. 10/10.

Thimbleweed Park does everything right.

It's self-referrential narrative is full of love not only to the genre of adventure-games itself, but also to a whole spectrum of pop-culture. Reflect on this and not only feel nostalgic, but embrace the urge to have more games like this.

Ron Gilbert and his team has achieved, what I was hoping Broken Age would be, which is also an fantastic adventure game. 31551277.review:
[h1][b]《银莲花公园》[/b]卢卡斯艺术的梦想变成了Ron的玩具[/h1]

太长不看看这里：不论是“谜题细节人物塑造配音”各方面都精雕细琢独具匠心抢夺天工完美无瑕的???[b]烂尾[/b]???点击冒险杰作。

[h1]小背景[/h1]

- 1982年，星战之父乔治·卢卡斯成立了卢卡斯艺术（LucasArts）游戏工作室。

- 1987年，Ron Gilbert加入LucasArts，出于对现有冒险类游戏的失望，自主设计了SCUMM引擎，并以此帮助LucasArts发布了一代经典《Maniac Mansion》。

- 1989~1995年，Ron Gilbert协同Dave Grossman，Tim Schafer，Gary Winnick等主创，基于SCUMM引擎陆续发布了一系列点击冒险作品。大部分都好评如潮，成为了最早一批最经典的AVG游戏，至今被世人铭记。

- 1995年，Ron离开了LucasArts，开始追寻自己的游戏梦想。LucasArts之后依然在Tim Schafer等人的主导下发布了一系列AVG经典作品。

- 2000年，Tim Schafer离开了LucasArts，创建了Double Fine Productions。2010年，Ron Gilbert受Tim Schafer邀请加入Double Fine，一起开发《The Cave》。

- 2012年，迪斯尼收购LucasArts，并于次年关闭了工作室，将其所有150名员工裁员，所有开发中作品叫停。经典陨落，整个游戏业一片惋惜。同年《The Cave》完成后，Ron Gilbert离开了Double Fine。 然而LucasArts的神话并没有结束——

- 2014年，Double Fine开始陆续重置LucasArts的经典作品。

- 2014年底，Ron Gilbert找到了Gary Winnick和David Fox，并一起在Kickstarter上开启本作众筹，想要制作一款“如同乘坐时光机回到30年前”的经典AVG作品，并在大量怀旧粉丝和游戏设计师的支持下最终筹得60多万美元，远超37万美元的目标。

- 2017年，经过2年多的制作，承载了LucasArts梦想的本作最终上线。[strike]所以本游戏有整整35年的历史！你没有看错只要68，1年2块钱超值！你不是在玩游戏，而是在见证历史，有没有觉得自己好伟大？[/strike]  然而，它[b]烂尾[/b]了。

[h1]小建议[/h1]

* 一定要选择“困难模式”！
[code]
普通模式会跳过大部分解谜，而那正是本游戏的精髓之一（相信大多数玩家不会玩二周目）。
[/code]
* 在第一次通关前尽量不要看攻略。
[code]
如果遇到困难，仔细观察对话并设想物品间的联系，找到答案的那一刻是最好的体验。实在不行可以去论坛询问不涉及剧透的小提示。
[/code]
* 不要快速通关，尽量阅读更多的对话。
[code]
以轻松的心态阅读大量机智幽默的分支对话，是本作最大的乐趣。而且我相信你不想很快看到结尾。
[/code]

[h1]小特点[/h1]

+ 经典的SCUMM类型游戏
[code]
SCUMM即“为疯狂豪宅设计的脚本创作工具”（真拗口）类游戏。《疯狂豪宅》是LucasArts的一部出色的骨灰级游戏。这个引擎最大的特点是，解谜部分通过找到屏幕下方合适的动词来与物品互动实现，例如“交谈，捡起，开关，推拉，给予，看”等等。这个看似繁复的设计其实产生了奇妙的化学反应，让解谜过程变得有趣又有深度。
[/code] 
+ 极其出色的NPC角色塑造和配音
[code]
一周目后，我竟然记住了所有NPC的外形、语气和性格，这得益于天才般的差异化设计和生动配音。
[/code] 
+ 顶级的2D像素艺术风格
[code]
如同《Owlboy》一样，本作又一次证明了像素画面并不过时。
[/code]
+ 非线性的解谜体验
[code]
5个角色实时切换，同步解谜。正如主创所说：“如果冒险游戏只有一个谜题，那是个重大的错误。你必须同时解决多个谜题，然后，每个谜题都会打开更多的分支谜题。” 与此同时，这些谜题与故事情节紧紧契合，并没有mini game这类与主线无关的脱节内容。
[/code] 
+ 无以伦比的细节
[code]
场景会随着时间和选择结果而变化；五个角色在同一场景中都有一整套完全不同的对话。
[/code]
+ 独特的幽默感
[code]
全游戏梗无数，一个不小心就会噗出来。更重要的是，这是一个meta游戏。
[/code] 
- 部分幽默对话显得过于刻意。
[code]
打破第四堵墙的情况过于常见，部分梗显得不那么自然，感觉就像是故意想引起玩家共鸣一样。一部喜剧想要逗人发笑是很难的，一不小心就会变成尴尬症放映室，而本作其实做得不错。
[/code]
- [b]烂尾[/b]！（详见后文）

[h1]为什么LucasArts的游戏与众不同[/h1]

近年来大量质量平庸的流水线生产出来的隐藏物品（Hidden Object）类冒险游戏频现，其中《谜画之塔》这样的精品少之又少，而大部分则代表了“模式化的剧情 + 伤眼睛的找东西 + 廉价感”。与此同时，点击冒险（Point & Click）类型的游戏同样井喷，其中《机械迷城》这样的佳作同样罕见，而其他大多的感觉无非是“平庸的故事 + 特别的艺术风格 + 脱节的解谜”。这一切让很多玩家对点击AVG游戏心灰意冷。

然而无数的厂商依然没有放弃努力，其中不乏有很多优秀作品，但是总体依然无法跳出思维定势。《秘密档案》系列从第一部以后质量就逐年下滑。想要继承经典的《梦陨新章》和最近出的《赛博利亚3》则同样不尽如人意。一直坚持推出点击AVG新作的Daedalic也难求突破。还有KING Art的众多佳作 ……（此处省略3千字）等等。这些作品我都很喜欢，大多可谓“优秀”，但比之“杰出”依然有差距。

然而LucasArts的作品则完全不同，例如《猴岛2雷查克的复仇》《印第安纳琼斯与亚特兰蒂斯的命运》《触手也疯狂》《冥界狂想曲》等作品（还有DreamForge 的《疯人院》），在很多玩家的心里只能用“杰作”来形容。而本作《银莲花公园》如果不是因为[b]烂尾[/b]，则同样可以跻身其中一员。

这些作品本质上与其他作品有什么不同？相信每个LucasArts的粉丝都很难用言语描述清楚，那只是一种感觉：无以伦比的细节和NPC塑造，媲美顶级CRPG的分支对话数量，自然融入叙事且没有挫败感的解谜，独特的幽默感等等的杂糅体？也许是这样，但又好像不是。用Ron的话说就是“去除了所有传统AVG惹人厌烦的部分，只保留核心乐趣。” ……其实无可言喻，只有亲自体验后才会明白。

[h1]烂尾？![/h1]

这是前文出现最多的一个词，足见我心中的怨念有多深。95%的流程都完美无瑕，但是最后的5%毁所有。无数的铺垫和闪回，幽默外表下潜藏的神秘危机感，瞬间变得毫无意义。这同时让我明白了一个道理，就是通关前不要写评测……

因为经费不足么，因为时间不够么？这样的结尾本身是一个出色的点子，初见时也会会心一笑，但因为缺少铺垫让一切变得突兀潦草不负责任。为防剧透不会写太多，但相信90%的玩家通关后会有一样的感觉。

如果你有耐心和充足的时间，如果你认为“沿途风景的意义远大于最终的目的地”，那么这将是一个精妙绝伦的游戏。反之，如果你对一个自圆其说的结局有很高要求的话，则很可能会像我一样无语凝噎（???

[h1]小彩蛋[/h1]

发现视屏设置里有个选项叫做“厕纸翻转”（Toilet paper over），很困惑这是做什么用的？找到了答案……石化了一分钟…… 忽然间原谅了Ron，因为他只是一个长不大的孩子，一个离开Tim就不再会讲故事的游戏设计天才。

也许Ron并不是在制作游戏，而是在玩游戏，祝愿他玩得开心~ :)

31507189.review:
[h1]Höchstdosis Nostalgie[/h1]

Thimbleweed Park ist ein neues, formal sehr klassisches Adventure von Ron Gilbert, dem Macher von Maniac Mansion und Monkey Island 1 & 2. Wer diese klassischen Spiele, wie so viele, geliebt hat, dem kann ich Thimbleweed Park ans Herz legen. Wer sie nicht kennt, für den mag es Besseres geben. Und sei es, die Klassiker endlich nach­zu­holen.

Man möchte meinen, die Spiele-Publisher hätten inzwischen be­griffen, dass sich mit Nostalgie Geld verdienen lässt. Oder vielleicht wissen sie es, aber Gilbert wollte sich nicht von einem Publisher abhängig machen. Jedenfalls ist auch dieses Retro-Projekt mit den Geldern tausender Kickstarter-Unterstützer entstanden.

Herausgekommen ist ein Spiel, das ich mutig nennen würde. Pixelig bis zum Anschlag und, seit wohl zwei Jahrzehnten nicht mehr ge­se­hen, mit einer Liste von Verben. Während ein modernes Adventure einem oft nur zwei Möglichkeiten zu jedem Gegenstand anbietet, "Kuck" und "Mach", kann man bei Thimbleweed Park wie in der guten alten Zeit öffnen und schließen, nehmen und geben, drücken und ziehen, ansehen, benutzen und ansprechen.

Das ermöglicht Rätsel und spaßige Bemerkungen, die ein modernes Adventure schlecht bieten kann. Ich war mir nicht sicher, ob ich mit etwas so Altmodischem und Ungewohntem noch zurecht­kom­men würde. Doch in den ersten Minuten war ich dann nicht etwa von der Vielfalt an Möglichkeiten herausgefordert, sondern enttäuscht, dass sie bei erster Gelegenheit nicht funktionierten. Will man die Person, die man im allerersten Bild trifft, ansehen, wird sie statt­dessen angesprochen. So habe ich mir meine neuen alten Mög­lich­kei­ten nicht vorgestellt - und [url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2017/03/31/everything-wrong-with-thimbleweed-park/]dieser Herr[/url] von "Rock, Paper, Shotgun" schon gar nicht. Das Problem, dass man Figuren nicht ansehen kann, zieht sich leider durch das Spiel. Eine vertane Chance. Aber ansonsten ent­wickeln sich die Interaktionsmöglichkeiten gut und ich bin auch schnell wieder reingekommen. Nach dem Durchspielen bin ich ge­spannt, ob ich das nächste moderne Adventure nicht als zu simpel empfinden werde.

Apropos "simpel", der Schwierigkeitsgrad lässt sich in zwei Stufen einstellen. Ich habe natürlich die härtere genommen, und bis auf eine Stelle, an der ich mehrere Tage gehangen habe, waren die Rätsel nie zu schwierig. Ich wollte an dieser Stelle partout nicht in eine Lösung kucken (die ja heutzutage verführerisch schnell er­googelt sind), in der Befürchtung, dass es sich als unnötig erwiesen würde und ich es die nächs­ten 25 Jahre (bis zum nächsten Gilbert-Adven­ture?) bereut hätte. Ich bin dann zum Glück drauf gekommen, und ja, ich hätte mir 25 Jahre lang in den Bürzel gebissen, wie Onkel Dago­bert so schön sagt.

Die Geschichte entspinnt sich an einem Mord, den man mit zwei Polizisten aufklären soll. Bald gesellen sich weitere spielbare Fi­guren hinzu, meist kann man zwischen 5 Charakteren frei hin und herschalten. Einige Bereiche oder Möglichkeiten bleiben einzelnen Figuren vorbehalten, der größte Teil lässt sich mit einer frei ge­wähl­ten Figur erkunden. Wobei es leider häufig auch keinen Unterschied macht, zu vielen Gegenständen haben sie gar keinen unter­schied­lichen Kommentar parat.

Das Adventure ist nicht nur sehr retro in seiner Steuerung und Grafik, es dreht sich auch stark um die 80er, in denen es spielt, und um Adventures. Eine Figur ist Adventure-Programmiererin, man trifft Mitarbeiter an den alten Lucasarts-Adventures "persönlich" und es gibt Seitenhiebe auf den damaligen Konkurrenten Sierra. Das Spiel macht mehr Spaß, wenn man sich damit und den Achtzigern all­ge­mein ein wenig auskennt, und an zwei Stellen wird solches Wissen auch in Rätseln "abgefragt". Stellenweise durchbricht das Spiel die "Vierte Wand" (die imaginäre Wand zwischen Schauspielern und Publikum im Theater, die dafür sorgt, dass die gespielten Figuren die Zuschauer nicht wahrnehmen). An einer Stelle gegen Schluss für meinen Geschmack allerdings zu brachial.

Das Spiel bietet eine englische Vertonung und deutsche Texte. Für die Übersetzung ist Boris Schneider-Johne verantwortlich, der auch die klassischen Adventures des Autors übersetzt hatte. Ich habe aber lieber mit Vollvertonung gespielt und auf die deutschen Texte ver­zichtet.

Thimbleweed Park läuft problemlos unter Linux.

31477101.review:
I thought it was fun! I played on casual mode as I have played very few of the old verb-based adventure games, and I thought the puzzle difficulty was fine; I got stumped a couple times but not for very long. 

The story was fine up until the very, very end, where it went off into a kind of...strange...direction that I didn't particularly care for. [spoiler]Regardless of the [i]extremely[/i] meta nature of the ending, I don't think it's a good idea to have a puzzle that requires looking beyond the game in order to solve without clicking the object on every other object. It breaks the immersion and what if you were playing this offline and couldn't access the internet in order to watch the original kickstarter video? That might be fine for Adventure Game veterans but I found it offputting.[/spoiler]

Barring that though it was a really neat little game and I'm considering playing it on hard mode sometime! There were tons of items I picked up that didn't have a use in casual mode and I'm super curious what they were used for!

31471581.review:
Ich liebe es, dieses Spiel hat wirklich alles was man liebt an den alten Adventures und erwartet, aber auch neue Verbesserungen die das Spielen angenehmer machen. (Leichte und intuitive Maussteuerung)

Die Adventure Logik ist ein bisschen zu krass gegen Ende des Spiels, aber nicht unfair, wenn man darüber hinweg sieht dass in einem Moment eine Person mit Niemandem reden kann, dies aber weil es vom Spiel verlangt wird plötzlich möglich ist. 
Was ich sagen will ist, wer sich denkt das Spiel in einem Rutsch durchzuspielen ist hier leider an der falschen Stelle. 
Manche Rätsel sind so leicht, oder auch leicht übersehbar, dass man an einem einfachen "Öffnen" von einem Buch 2 Stunden festhängt, weil man sich sicher war, das doch schonmal versucht zu haben, aber die Freude und den Spaß den man verspürt wenn es endlich klappt kann einem kein anderes Spiel geben.

Wer jemals Spaß hatte an einem Spiel von Ron Gilbert wird das hier sicher mindestens genauso mögen, wenn nicht noch mehr, das Spiel wirft ein Gagfeuerwerk ab das ich niemals für möglich gehalten habe. 
Außerdem fand ich die Größe und Länge sehr gut. Ich wurde sehr gut unterhalten, besonders weil man gezwungen ist sich jeden Dialog sehr gut zu merken und die Umgebung zu analysieren, weil man sonst nicht weiterkommt, aber das macht es so besonders, man taucht in eine kleine Stadt mit 81, Sorry, 80 Einwohnern ein und lernt jede Person die man trifft auf mehreren Ebenen kennen.

31456774.review:
This is a classic point and click adventure from the makers of Maniac Mansion and Monkey Island.  Thimbleweed is the name of a rundown town and gameplay starts with a murder. There are five playable characters, all collecting and using various items to solve the murder.
You can choose to play in casual or hard mode where hard mode extends the puzzles and increases the number of inventory items.

Music - Good
Graphics - Very high quality pixel graphics
Cost - May want to wait for a Steam sale
Top Hats - None. The Sherrif-erino wears a sherrif's hat, Ransome the clown has a clown-fro, and there's a pirate hat.

31452964.review: After playing Maniac Mansion and Zak McKracken on my Commodore 64 as a kid,  I was always a huge fan of Ron Gilbert and Gary Winnick games.  Once finding out they released a new adventure game, I was quick to grab it. Now only a few hours into it,  So far they have not disappointed me.  With it's retro look and a ton of call backs and easter eggs to their previous works already mentioned,  as well as others like Monkey Island,  This game has it all.  Puzzle solving, Comedy and a great story line makes for one awesome time.  This for me is one of those games where I really don't want it to end.  I hope they added some multiple endings or some kind of replay value?  But I highly doubt it seeing as it only seems to head in one direction. I really hope this game paves the way for future devolopers to follow suit with more adventure games like this.

31450656.review:
Il se passe des choses étranges à Thimbleweed Park...
Mais qu'est ce qui attire nos agents fédéraux dans cette petite ville de 80 habitants?
Que se cache-t-il derrière les murs du manoir Manoir?
Pourquoi ramassent-ils donc tous ces objets qui traînent dans les environs et surtout;
Comment diable font-ils pour que tout tienne dans leurs poches!?

Malheureusement, répondre à certaines questions ne fait qu'en révéler d'autres...

Les Point & Click et moi, c'est une grande histoire d'amour, surtout grâce à Ron Gilbert qui m'a fasciné avec Monkey Island (surtout avec LeChuck's Revenge mais aussi The Curse of Monkey Island bien qu'il ne soit pas de sa plume) ainsi qu'avec les Maniac Mansion et sans oublier les differentes oeuvres des anciens de chez LucasArts. En somme, c'est ce qui a éveillé en moi l'une de mes passions culturelles favorites; les jeux-vidéo.

Autant dire que l'arrivée de Thimbleweed Park sur la plateforme Steam m'a réjouit au plus haut point! Mais ça ne m'empêchait pas non plus de faire preuve d'exigence, sachant que ce genre de nouvelles a souvent été synonyme de décéptions (Sybéria 3 pour ne citer que lui).

Dès les premiers instants, retrouver le tableau des verbes m'a fait remonter dans le temps sans pour autant me faire oublier qu'on était bien sur un jeu développé avec des outils modernes;

-La DA est maîtrisée avec du pixel art soigné
-Le gameplay compatible avec la manette (bien que préférant exploiter le jeu de manière classique; à la souris)
-Un game design irréprochable

Question scénario, Ron Gilbert et Gary Winnick ont clairement bien fait leur boulot; on a toujours envie d'en savoir plus, l'humour est omniprésent et les références sont multiples. Du début jusqu'à la fin, je ne me suis pas ennuyé une seule seconde et j'ai apprécié chaque instant passé sur ce titre.

En terme de durée de vie, c'est exactement ce qu'il faut pour un P&C, à mon sens. Comptez une vingtaine d'heures si vous prenez votre temps (en mode difficile).

Concernant les énigmes, elles sont très bien intégrées, souvent subtiles et bien imaginées. La difficulté est légèrement mal gérée mais dans l'ensemble c'est bien plus que satisfaisant. Exit les casse-têtes clichés et redondants; nous sommes réellement en présence de problèmes bien plus élégants, des arcanes bien ancrées qui révèlent un level design qui n'a pas à rougir de sa structure. (Bon, en tant que consommateur régulier de ce type de jeux d'aventure, ça m'a semblé plutôt facile mais j'ai quand même rencontré quelques challenges.)

Il reste à noter qu'on aurait tout de même apprécié avoir une bande son plus élaborée ainsi que des commentaires propres à chaque personnage utilisable, même si certains s'en démarquent.
Mais ces petits détails n'altèrent en rien le plaisir de se balader dans Thimbleweed Park et d'épuiser toutes les lignes de dialogues possibles.
De nombreuses surprises sont à découvrir, surtout pour les plus observateurs/fouineurs qui parcourent les tableaux que nous propose l'équipe de Terrible Toybox.

En conclusion;

C'est un excellent titre qui répondra certainement aux attentes de la majorité des fans du genre et qui redonnera le sourire à un grand nombre de nostalgiques des vieux jeux LucasArts, toujours en respectant les mots d'ordre évoqués dans l'un de leurs bébés:
"Never pay more than 20 bucks for a computer game"

Sachez, cependant, que si vous êtes hermétiques à ce type d'humour méta qui partage ses frontières avec l'absurde, vous risquez de ne pas être embarqués dans le même bateau que moi.

Mes félicitations aux concepteurs et mes remerciements aux backers!
C'était une expérience très plaisante!

31450164.review:
Thimbleweed Park is a modern "classic" adventure game, which stays close to the LucasArts formula.

It's mostly frustration-free and has lots of quality of life features aimed at to not waste your time.

Storywise the buildup to the end is interesting, but all arcs come crashing down in the end in what turned out to be one of the most unsatisfying closures in any adventure game I've played so far.

The uninspired and rather abrasive fourth wall breaking became more and more unbearable as the game went on.

The lack of interaction between the characters next to "Give x to y" caused me to lose my suspension of disbelief on more than one occasion. Why are all these people cooperating with each other?

If you're a die-hard fan of the authors or Maniac Mansion this may be a game for you. If you enjoy well-written story arcs that don't insult your intellect you should give this a pass, at least at the 20 USD price point.

31429755.review:
Upon finishing the game, it's time for a new review.

Firstly, before getting into the meat and potatoes...



You should buy this game.



Thimbleweed Park is a modern game which uses (and improves upon) the tried and tested formulas of classic LucasArts point-and-click adventures from the 1980s and 1990s. In a sense, it feels like an anachronism and a relic carefully handled and newly enshrined in some dark corner of a videogame museum which only exists in the Elysium of a very distinctive and largely maligned videogame genre, yet it reminds us of just how immersive and rewarding those old formulas still are when they are executed with as much thought, care, flair and brilliance as has been captured by Terrible Toybox with this shining title.

The mastery of this title is manifold and all the individual points of excellence combine symphoniously to create an experience which is ultimately hugely rewarding -- and this is a viewpoint largely agreed upon by those who have finished the game but for one huge sticking point which has been a buzzkill for many: the ending. Yet, how the game ends has been built to meticulously throughout the whole intertwining journey of the happenings in Thimbleweed County and the narratives and sympathies of the lead characters. 

Taking place in a neo-noir setting in 1987, the clues constantly present themselves about the gnarly fate of Thimbleweed County, and the pacing of the unfolding of this grand tale -- from a simple murder story transmogrifying surreptiously into musings on the meaning of life and determinism -- is both exquisite and mysteriously undermining, leading to a climax which might best be described as being startingly harrowing, empty but yet purposeful.

The puzzle design is among the best and most consistent ever seen in a game of the genre, with every solution being well led to and well thought out and a total absence of what we call "moon logic" (completely irrational puzzle solutions). The nature of the puzzles and how they flow and interlink help move the story along at a very satisfying pace and the game continuously incentivises one to explore and truly listen to what characters in the game have to say. The ambience and mystery of the story is likely to stir the player, which is one of the big reasons why the ending is so divisive -- the gamer becomes truly immersed in the world and is very invested in the "answers". In this sense, the game has knocked it out the park and then into and out of orbit with its execution of interactive and dialogue driven gameplay. 

All of this is achieved even in dealing with five different playable characters who each have their own purposes, problems and goals.The story pacing brings us to their plights and their journeys within the meta-world of an evil (or is he?) genius rather than just clinging onto the red herring of a simple murder mystery plot -- one involving an individual who we are never told much about, nor meet people who sympathise toward him.

The visuals and sound certainly help to bolster the wholesome experience of the game, and though the music in the game isn't as memorable or melodically tuneful as in many other games, it is completely apposite. The pixel art is truly a feast; especially with the use of multiple layers of parallax scrolling, which is something we simply didn't see with the old classics from the 1990s.

The game is flooded with various in-jokes and references which fans of old classics will typically enjoy, and I'm no different. However, when playing it did occur to me that it can at times verge on being something which panders to an echochamber of the already converted, and I wonder if enough has been done to pull in a new audience to enjoy a genre of game which in the case of Thimbleweed Park has been mastered and even surpassed the old golden standard.

My main concern for this game is that the gem won't be played by as many people as it should be. Forget that it relies fundamentally on old core values and specific execution and remember, rather, that it's an outstanding game -- period. At least, that's what I'd like to convince people of, and especially those who have not delved into the world of point-and-click adventures who, if they'd just give it a shot, might be rewarded much more than they could've imagined.


+++++ The ending (others might give it a 5-minus score).
+++ Outstanding gameplay with nigh on flawless puzzle design and flow.
+++ Immersive and intriguing dialogue and story which links in seamlessly and intrinsically with the puzzle design.
++ Super production value all around, with very few negative quirks in the design.
++ Fantastic pixel art graphics and a memorable set of locations and scenes.
++ Tremendous details; most notably the huge library with more than a 1000 readable 2-page books in the Mansion Mansion.
+ Excellent sound and very fun and appropriate voice acting -- it doesn't take itself too seriously and strikes a great balance.
+ Casual mode is a very good introduction for those who are new to the genre who might be daunted by a very different way of thinking in gaming.


+- Self referential nature (in an overarching point & click meta sense) of the game will likely be divisive and there's a likely disconnect there for a newer audience.
+- The ending has proven to be extremely divisive. It's a brave ending which is balls to the wall, but certainly meticulously crafted and intended. Nonetheless, it has been jarring for many -- and perhaps that just adds to the intrigue.

- The one big minus I would wager is the overall holistic view of the game, in that I'm not sure it's ignited a new furore over the genre of point & click adventures that one might have hoped for.
- For all the puzzle brilliance, perhaps we could have more puzzles involving pushing and pulling things (where use specifically doesn't work) given that the options are there.

Score: 9.5/10


In closing:


You should buy this game.

If you want a ride like the ones with the classic point-and-click adventures (Maniac Mansion, Monkey Island, etc.), this is the game you want to play. 

The story is very good, with flashbacks to play the actual situation instead of being told in conversation. It's fill with jokes and references (and actual characters and dialog lines) from earlier games, also from Ron Gilbert and Gary Winnick. 31363353.review:
El análisis original podeis encontrarlo en 

https://thepastisnow.net/2017/04/17/thimbleweed-park-aventura-grafica-pura-y-dura/

esde que se anunció Thimbleweed Park a finales de 2014 lo he estado esperando y siguiendo de cerca, sus creadores han hecho los juegos que mas veces he completado a lo largo de mi vida.

Pierdo la cuenta de las veces que he jugado Monkey Island (Que tengo pendiente traer al blog) u otras aventuras gráficas como El día del tentáculo o Indiana Jones y la última cruzada y es por eso que cuando supe que Ron Gilbert y Gary Winnick sacaban un nuevo juego no quería perdérmelo.

Efectivamente molan y mucho, gracias Delores.

El juego cumple perfectamente con las expectativas, y tengo que añadir que no solo para los jugadores retro,  aunque a priori pueda parecer lo contrario no está pensado exclusivamente para los que han jugado muchas aventuras gráficas o las aventuras de LucasArts, este juego es para jugadores tanto antiguos como nuevos, eso si, tiene guiños con los títulos clásicos, pero eso no quiere decir que si nunca has tocado una aventura gráfica de LucasArts no vayas a disfrutar de este juego.

Algunos guiños te hacen dar un salto de la silla.

Mucha gente piensa que es para los nostálgicos y que si no sabes quién es Guybrush o Bernard no podrás disfrutarlo, y creedme cuando digo que nada tiene esto que ver aunque si es cierto que tiene muchos easter eggs aunque creo sinceramente, que es casi obligatorio que ahí estuvieran.

Igual que en las anteriores, estas aventuras se basan en los puzzles, por lo que no te matarán (casi) nunca.
La estética del juego es obviamente pixel art, pero usa tecnologías de hoy en día, la iluminación, las sombras, los cambios de tamaño, los movimientos de los personajes, la fluidez y otros tantos detalles que deberéis descubrir jugando nos dejan claro que el juego es 2017.

No voy a desvelar detalles fundamentales del juego porque rompería la magia, dan ganas de hablar del título con todo tipo de detalles y Spoilers porque hay muchas cosas que contar, pero no quiero romper la magia a nadie por lo que tocaremos solo aspectos muy superficiales del juego.

Nuestros personajes listos para emprender esta aventura.

Alguien ha aparecido muerto en Thimbleweed Park, un pequeño pueblo de 80 habitantes, y dos agentes federales, con cierto aire de series de los 90 tipo Expediente X, se han desplazado hasta allí para averiguar que ha sucedido. A partir de este punto, empieza una historia genial en la que cada uno y de manera particular tiene su propio objetivo que cumplir aunque tengan alguna meta en común, como suele ocurrir en las mejores historias, nada es lo que parece en un principio.

El aspecto visual es maravilloso, la riqueza de colores y la composición hace que la inmersividad en el título sea completa, puedes quedarte embobado solamente paseando por el juego, todos los detalles están muy cuidados y no hay ningún detalle dejado al azar.

Los ambientes generados en cada pantalla son diferentes y crean diferentes sensaciones.

Por la música recordaros que hace poco os la traje al Blog y cuyo enlace os voy a dejar aquí mismo con una playlist incluida desde la que podéis escuchar la banda sonora genial de este juego, muy a la altura del resto del título. Pinchad en este enlace para acceder al artículo.

La dificultad del juego está muy bien medida, no es un juego extremadamente difícil y si estás atento al juego y eres cuidadoso con todo lo que va sucediendo no tendrás problemas en completarlo en Modo difícil, hubo pocos puzzles en los que me quedé muy atrapado y debo decir que al resolverlos una sensación de absoluta felicidad recorría mi cuerpo a la vez que decía "¡Claro! ¡Como no lo habré visto antes!". No vais a tener que probar todos los objetos con todos los objetos, la clave es prestar atención y utilizar la lógica.

Navegando por internet he visto algunos que dicen que el juego se puede hacer extremadamente difícil y no queda otra que tirar de guías porque puede llegar a desesperar, esto no es más que un problema que tenemos hoy en día con la dificultad de los juegos y la necesidad inmediata que tenemos por completar los juegos, en serio, disfrutadlo, mirad los detalles, leed todas las líneas de texto, viajad a todos los lugares, ¡sacadle el jugo! No penséis que por estar un par de horas dando vueltas pensando como completar un puzzle vais a desesperaros porque esto no es real, al contrario, cuando lo resolváis os vais a sentir encantados y os va a emocionar ¡Que también esto es parte de las aventuras gráficas!


Como ocurre en otras aventuras como Monkey Island 2, el juego ofrece dos niveles de dificultad ¡No descartes jugar primero el Modo casual!

Si hay algo que criticar, es que al usar los personajes puedes interactuar entre ellos, pasar objetos de unos a otros, pero sin que entre ellos exista ningún tipo de relación previa, simplemente vas de uno a otro y les pasas objetos porque sí, esto no está explicado de ninguna manera y aunque es algo que ocurre en otros juegos pero en este que está todo tan mascado es llamativo que no expliquen este punto.
 
Por no crear Spoilers, no trataré el tema de los guiños del juego, pero más adelante cuando ya tenga más tiempo, si me gustaría hacer un artículo donde sacar los guiños con otros juegos que he visto y explicarlos por si no los conocéis.

Para los que pusieron su granito de arena y dieron apoyo al juego a traves de la campaña de crowfunding que hubo en kickstarter, hay cabida en el juego en forma de mensaje de contestador automático  a los que se puede llamar desde las guías de teléfonos que hay en el juego o de título libro en las diferentes bibliotecas, un detalle muy bueno que además su traducción es la original, osea si el título lo dejaste en inglés sale en inglés.

Algunos mensajes son buenísimos, pasar un rato probando contestadores también es un atractivo del juego.
En definitiva, este es uno de los grandes títulos de 2017, si te consideras jugón, gamer o videojugador deberías jugar Thimbleweed Park sin dudarlo y si eres de los de vieja escuela, decirte que si este juego hubiera salido en 1995, sin duda sería uno de los grandes a día de hoy.

¿Y tú? ¿Ves las señales?

¡¡¡Nos vemos pronto!!!

31362504.review:
If you love Maniac Mansion, you will love this. I get the feeling it takes place in the same town during the same time period, though it's not ever explicit. If you enjoyed Secret of Monkey Island, you'll probably also enjoy this.

My first playthrough took me 27 hours, but I am pretty slow and thorough and got hung up for like 6 hours during trying to solve one puzzle about a cotton swab and fingerprint tape. I predict I could speed run it in less than three hours now, maybe less than 1, if I made no mistakes. Maniac Mansion has a similar play style, and you can speed run that game in 6 minutes.

It has some cool multi-character puzzles like Maniac Mansion does (distract a baddie with one character and have the other sneak by, for instance). I am not sure if the game has multiple endings like Maniac Mansion, but the one I got was really interesting and hefty.

There are tiny things that seem cut due to not enough dev time. An Arcade in town, you can't go in. Ron Gilbert said they wanted to add a patch after release to allow that, so we'll see. There are a few security camera style cut scenes that hint at some arcs and character development that doesn't really happen and leaves some loose ends in my mind. These are minor complaints, but as always with me, if I imagine something will be in your game and you don't include it or hint at it but don't include it, I become disappointed.

I am glad I bought this game, and there's even an easy mode with fewer or simple puzzles for casual players, and I want to try it out, too. For $12, this would be a great steal.

I played this right after The Sexy Brutale, a Groundhog Day mansion-based murder mystery on Steam that's also great. Combine some of this gameplay with some of that gameplay, and you would have a formula for an amazing Maniac Mansion 2.

31302889.review:
Soy una persona que no ha jugado demasiadas aventuras gráficas a lo largo de mi vida.. monkey island, siberia, broken sword 1 y 2... y poco más.

Que puedo decir de este juego, en cuanto a su historia: me ha parecido bastante fascinante, muy entretenida y divertida... te hace reflexionar mucho sobre hacia donde se está orientando la sociedad en general y los problemas que ello pueda acarrear.. como siempre a algunas personas les parecerá bien a otras no tanto, en cuanto al tema tecnológico se refiere.

Graficamente: obviamente no podemos pedirle mucho a una desarrolladora indie y menos siendo un point and click como es el caso jeje, de modo que, en este aspecto no puedo decir gran cosa, pero si os interesa más una buena historia que unos graficos increibles, no os importará jugar este juego.

Personajes: están muy bien planteados y pensados, cada personaje tiene su propia personalidad y su forma de ver las cosas... lo que si me deja un poco decepcionado es que las frases establecidas en las conversaciones no varían de un personaje a otro, y me hubiera gustado escuchar otro tipo de opinión diferente, ya que llevas a 5 personajes en total, pero bueno. Por lo general, son unos personajes a los que les cojerás cariño y disfrutarás con ellos, al menos a mi me han dejado esa sensación.

Puzzles: apartado muy importante como aventura gráfica clásica que es,.. tengo que decir que yo lo jugué por primera vez en modo difícil, porque me gustan los desafíos... y dios bendito esto es más hardcore que cagar ladrillosss. Algunos puzzles sino la mayoría los resolverás con la pura lógica, pero hay otros que por mucho que pienses no se te ocurriría ni de cerca hacer tal cosa... además algunos de estos resultan muy tediosos... yo he tenido la sensación de resolverlos todos o el 90 % para mis adentros, pero no de la forma que ellos querían.. nose si me explico, no voy a poner ejemplos porque no quiero hacer spoiler, pero cuando lo juguéis sabréis a lo que me refiero.

Música: la banda sonora del juego esta bastante bien en general, pero cuando estéis en una situación de que no sepáis que hacer, se os pasará por la cabeza matar al compositor de la misma xdd, porque vais a escuchar esa mierda hasta que deis con la solución y eso a mi me sacaba un poquito de mis casillas por decirlo de forma suave.

Concusión: si os gustan las aventuras gráficas tipo monkey island, broken sword... entre otras, este es vuestro juego, os resultará bastante satisfactorio cuando resolváis un puzzle y os sentiréis los putos amos... de modo que para mi tiene un 7/10 y espero que esta desarrolladora haga más aventuras gráficas. Un saludo y espero que os haya servido de ayuda :)

31298838.review:
TL;DR: My personal game of the year 2017!

Ron Gilbert and his team managed to create an adventure game that is both true to the classics like Maniac Mansion and Monkey Island and yet so fresh and inspiring as you'd expect it from a game released in 2017. While the art style may look dated at first, it is incredible well done and very detailed (and finally we have ladder-climbing animations!). The story itself is hilarious and includes lots of references and homages to older LucasArts classics while the pizzles are nicely woven into the story. 
Some people complained about the voice acting, however it was just like I expected it to be. The LucasArts classics which had voice acting always featured some hilarious (not in a bad way though) voices which added a lot to the game - just like in ThimbleWeed Park.
I've just finished the game and will definitely play it again (this time in casual mode, just to see the differences).

I backed this title when the campaign was live at Kickstarter with $30 and it is worth every penny!

31293327.review:
When Ron Gilbert announced the making of Thimbleweed Park on his blog back in late 2014, I had very high expectations. Now that I finished the game, I can say they were even surpassed. This is easily one of the best adventure games I ever played, up there with the all-time classics; the attention to details they put into it is astounding. The puzzles are brilliantly designed, the characters and dialogues are both amusing and interesting, the retro pixel graphics are incredibly rich in quality.
In short: if you like adventure games, you can't miss this one.  Even if you're not much into adventure games, I think Thimbleweed Park is still worth a try.

31290165.review:
If you were a fan of the classic LucasArts adventure games (such as Maniac Mansion and The Secret of Monkey Island), Ron Gilbert and Gary Winnick, who created some of those classics, have teamed up to produce a new game in that style: Thimbleweed Park.

I just finished it and I'm impressed; they made a game which appealed to my nostalgia for old-school adventure games, but which felt *new* at the same time. I would love it if they could start making this sort of game as a normal thing again...

31288957.review:
Unsurprisingly, Thimbleweed Park is like Maniac Mansion meets Monkey Island... Maniac Island?  Monkey Mansion?? It truly plays like a forgotten LucasArts game... well, other than the METRIC *BEEP*LOADS of shade thrown on practically EVERYTHING, like "the futuristic year of 2017"...

What I like best is how all the puzzles, for the most part, make sense.  Sure there are comical elements (for instance, how to start a fire in the fireplace), but there aren't any "hypnotize a monkey with a banana"-style solutions.

What I dislike--sort of--is how the characters have this bizarre hive mind once they all become active, which I suppose is from how awkward it would be to have them talk to each other for every little thing so that anything any one character does, the rest will know.  There's not really a better solution, and it's only jarring at first (and also sort of explained away at the end anyway).

What bothers me is the dialogue is for the most part unskippable, and all the loose ends don't get tied up because, ultimately, they don't matter.  That's fine, though, because once you get a certain item, you can make a satisfying BOOM whenever you're feeling frustrated.

I heartily recommend a playthrough if you're a fan of adventure games (and who isn't??).  It's fun to play, and you'll feel smart when you don't have to consult a walkthrough because, really, the only hints you'll need is "thoroughly check EVERY ROOM" and "try EVERY ACTION on EVERYTHING." I only got stuck in two places: where to find an object I knew I needed (didn't look closely enough) and how to use an object (didn't try the correct verb).

Also, it's fun reading in the library and calling everyone in the phone book!  If you feel like it, call me: 1640 (I think I set up the voicemail correctly...?)

31270869.review:
This is a technically excellent point & click adventure game - the puzzles are hard, yet logical - they flow well together, rarely outstay their welcome and I only found myself reaching for hints once or twice. The pixel graphics are lovely -  the modern touches that they included work really well, without taking away from the aesthetic. And the voice acting is mostly fantastic - although playing with 5.1 surround sound, occasionally the odd line would come through only one rear speaker, very quietly. But withstanding (presumably fixable) audio playback bugs, the game is clearly a labour of love - and I'm very glad I backed it on Kickstarter.

With all that said, I felt the game lacks much of the soul that made a lot of the classic LucasArt point & clicks so endearing. With the exception of one playable character (arguably two I guess), the majority are flat and uninteresting. The dialog spends far too much time on making jokes about old adventure games or "fan service", which although sometimes smile inducing, rarely got any honest laughs. The storyline starts interestingly, but peters out well before the game actually finishes - and I think the actual ending is a lot less clever than they thought it would be.

All in all, I strongly would recommend all point & click adventure game fans play Thimbleweed Park, if just to see what technical excellence in the genre looks like. If you're not already a fan, I'd suggest looking elsewhere first, such as Day of the Tentacle, Grim Fandango or the Monkey Island series - which on the whole I'd say are more compelling games.

31241081.review:
actual playtime: 14.30 hours
My favourite adventure game is Monkey Island. I never liked the big heads of Zack McKraken and Maniac M. I didn't back it.
And yet, playing it was such a joy, much more fullfilling than playing Broken Age. The game captures the feel and style of the first LucasArts adventures so well. The exploration, the creepiness, the unexpected places, the naivetee (the phonebook is sorting the first names alphabetically - maybe that is common in the States?; all machines have "-Thron 3000" added to them, you catch criminals by feeding evidence to machines,...), all the red herrings and random unnecessary objects (I never knew I missed them so much!).
At the same time it is a much more mature game, the graphics look beautiful, the story itself twists and wriggles in all directions, and yet seems round and even as a whole, unfolding until the very end and offering a cathartic and melancholic end note.
One of the best adventures I've played in recent years.

31240819.review:
Holy shit is this a great game. Fan service wherever you move your cursor, addictive story and gameplay, smart riddles to solve and lots and lots of stuff to do, some puzzles just leads to nowhere but a joke, you're always making progress somehow and you just can't stop stumblin through Thimbleweed Park discovering new things everywhere.

In short, you like point'n click adventures? Go get it. You liked the good old SCUMM styled classics? You'll love it. Remember the starrings from Maniac Mansion? Get ready to shout your joy into the screen.

But theres one thing I can't get over with. The fact you're playin several characters is pretty cool, but the devs missed out any interaction between them, theres no connection, no motivation doing things for each other, nothing. Characterdevelopment is just that particular thing in this game wich's a _big_ missed opportunity here. Later ingame you need to interact between characters wich never had any interaction ever and it just makes no sense at all. Especially at one point with no clue what to do one dude needs to do a thing for another one without ANY reason at all and it drives me crazy. Just one or two dialogues more between them and this game would be pure gold. 

Anyway, don't get me wrong this games i so much the awesomness, but it could be so much more. 

Sad at this point, but after all that ragin, in the end I cried like a child at the end and I loved it. It's one of those games I'll tell my children about.

31227112.review:
[h1]Willkommen in...Thimbleweed Park™[/h1]

Du erwartest abstruse Charaktere? [u]Dann bist du hier richtig![/u]

Du erwartest ein klassisches Point&Click-Adventure aus dem preisgekröntem Hause "Lucas Arts"? [u]Dann bist du hier richtig![/u]

Du erwartest Nostalgiefeeling, wie in den späten 80er bzw. frühen 90er Jahren? [u]Dann bist du hier richtig![/u]

Du erwartest Lug und Trug, eine ausgefeilte Story und eine geschichtliche Wendung, die es in sich hat? [u]Dann bist du hier richtig![/u]

Du kombinierst gerne Verben und Substantive der vollkommen genialen SCU(f)MM [Script Creation Utility "for" Maniac Mansion-Engine] miteinander? [u]Dann bist du hier richtig![/u]

Pixeloptik gefällt dir und ist ein essenzieller Bestandteil deiner früheren kindlichen Spielerfahrungen? [u]Dann bist du hier richtig![/u]

Du willst mehr als nur einen Charakter spielen und dennoch nicht sterben (wie damals bei den alten Sierra-Games)? [u]Dann bist du hier genau richtig![/u]

Du *piepst* auf konventionelle Games a la Triple A und ziehst Singleplayer-Spiele den Multiplayer-Games vor? [u]Dann bist du hier genau richtig![/u]

Menschen wie "Ron Gilbert" sind dir kein Fremdbegriff? [u]Ja, richtig erraten, du bist hier genau richtig![/u]

Anzügliche, gesellschaftskritische und vor allen Dingen *piep*-ende Worte findest du recht sympathisch? [u]Du bist hier richtiger denn je![/u]

Du wolltest in einem Videospiel schon immer mal einen Hamster in einer Mikrowelle braten, oder Benzin in einer funktionierenden Kettensäge benutzen, ohne die daraus schlussfolgernden Konsequenzen zu tragen? [u]Dann bist du nur zum Teil ein eingefleischter Adventure-Veteran! :D[/u]

Genieße die unzähligen Anspielungen und Eastereggs, die teils schwierigen aber logischen Rätsel, genieße eine Zeitzurücksetzung ins Jahr der Point&Click-Adventure-Hochkultur. Entdecke jedes Easteregg, jeden Spaß, den sich der Erfinder und Schöpfer des Games ausgedacht hat. Fühle dich in die Anfänge aller heutig erstellten Point&Click-Adventuregames zurück.
Du kannst schneller laufen mit einem Doppelklick!!! Eine spätere Map begleitet dich hin zu allen erreichbaren Orten! Eine ToDo-Liste wird dir alle möglichen Fragen nach und nach beantworten. Aber nur schlüssige, logische und bis zum Ende durchdachte Kombinationen werden dich tatsächlich an dein Ziel bringen. Natürlich mit allen Vereinfachungen und Spielverbesserungen, die es heutzutage gibt (Hotspotanzeige, englische Sprachausgabe etc.).
Klischees begleiten dich rund um die Uhr in [b]Thimbleweed Park™[/b].
Sei ein Nerd, sei ein hochgestochener Polizeibeamter, sei ein *piep*ender Clown, der alles und jeden beleidigt.
Es gibt weder Makel, noch sonstige Beschwerden meinerseits. Alles ist wie damals, nur eben in besser. Tolle Hintergründe, tolle Animationen, selbst das Lachen der Charaktere wurde animiert.
[b]Thimbleweed Park™[/b] ist eine Lobpreisung, eine Liebesbekundung an alte Zeiten. Und wenn du auf diesen Zug mit aufspringst, dann wirst du all das bekommen, was du dir insgeheim versprichst und mit gut 15 Stunden Spielspaß sogar vielleicht mehr.
"Wir sind alle nur Charaktere in einem Videospiel."

31222900.review: This game is point and click to its finest. 31221392.review:
This is a masterpiece! [NO SPOILERS]

Storytelling, puzzles and playability are superior to all the early scumm adventures: no sudden deaths, no dead-ends, no trial-and-error-puzzles, stylish graphics, cool soundtrack. There is one thing, I would like to mention, which the other reviews did not focus on: If you compare it to adventures from the last ten years, it beats them in a crucial aspect which lacks games nowadays: All characters have depth. Their biographies are both interesting and complex, you can understand why they act like they act and that gives their world credibility. You follow them with the same affection you felt with Frodo, Harry Potter, Luke Skywalker or any other of your heroes on their journeys to fulfill their quests. You want to help them to get over their problems and you can do it without trying this and that by chance, but by thinking and combining. It's not just a retro adventure, it's a modern classic in combining the comfort of modern gameplay with surprising story twists, lovely characters, clever puzzles and an intriguing setting. Thus, you will remember the game in years.

If you want to start playing adventures: Buy the game.
If you want to experience the immersive power of a fascinating plot: Buy the game. 
If you just want intelligent interactive entertainment: Buy the game.
If you loved Maniac Mansion or Zak McKracken: Buy the game  (unless you are in a bad need of some frustrating situations like getting stuck without cash in Katmandu or unless you just want to watch characters shuffle over the screen for minutes and minutes: in this case, play the old games first, then) BUY THIMBLEWEED PARK.

I really liked the game and I think that it is beautifully crafted. I especially enjoyed the old-school style and the pixel-art graphics by Mark Ferrari and Octavi Navarro, which greatly helped me to find in Thimbleweed Park an atmosphere similar to the one I found in games like "The Secret of Monkey Island".

Unfortunately, the story wasn't very interesting to me. One of the reasons why I play games is to briefly live in a fantasy world but the story of Thimbleweed Park [spoiler]mixes fantasy and reality to the point that the game explicitly reminds me that I'm just a gamer playing a simulation[/spoiler]. This twist completely broke my suspension of disbelief and it wasn't pleasant to me.

Said that, I still think that Thimbleweed Park is a very good game and I really enjoyed playing it.

[b]Things that I liked a lot:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Old-school pixel art graphics
    [*]The atmosphere
    [*]The puzzles (very logical and fair if you pay attention to the details)
    [*]The music
[/list]

[b]Things that I didn't like very much:[/b]
[list]
    [*]The story
[/list]

[b]Overall vote:[/b]
8.5/10

31189780.review:
[h1] Cheesy with a chance of mystery [/h1]

[b] Summary: [/b]

Thimbleweed Park is an exceptional adventure game with 10+ hours of gameplay, excellent art, and witty jokes; However, I feel the ending of the game is somewhat lame/dissapointing but I still reccommend you to play it. 

[b] My Take: [/b]

[u] Gameplay 9/10: [/u]

I feel the gamepplay not only invokes a feeling of nostalgia but can hold it's own for over 10 hours without getting boring or too repetitive

[u] Dialogue 7/10: [/u]

Most of the dialogue is funny or well done but you end up hearing many of the same voice lines over and over again so I gave Dialogue a lower score because IMO it gets annoying later in the game

[u] Art/Music 9/10: [/u]

All of the art in this game is well done and deserves love. Every "room" felt well done and I did not notice and major blemishes in design. 

The music was very good overall and other than hearing the same song on the radio for over 20 hours(no wonder they are called KSCUM) there was no major mistakes/problems

[u] Story 9/10: [/u]

Interesting story all the way through until the final part which felt very cheesy and lame for me. [spoiler] The 4th wall/we're all in a game ending felt forced and almost like a prank from the developers [/spoiler]

[b] Overall 8.5/10 [/b]

I don't think this is a game of the year but it is an experience that you should not pass up

31170407.review: Feel those waves of nostalgia wash over you. Thimbleweed Park is everything an old Lucasworks game used to be. Closer in style to Maniac Mansion than Monkey Island, it's full of Easter eggs and other fun throwbacks to its forefathers. I clocked in the game at about 15 hours on difficult mode, and I only had to look up three puzzles that absolutely were a leap of logic beyond what I could manage. So I think it's just about the right level. I enjoyed the variety of characters you can play as, and the personalities of the characters. I hope we see more of this kind of game in the future; the style has aged well and was very enjoyable. I particularly liked Ransom. I would have liked a few more fleshed out bits of town, but nothing huge. Highly recommended to anyone that lived through the 80s, or enjoys adventure games, or would like to see a cleaned up playstyle from those early games.

I loved this game... Absolutely loved it... It took me back to an era where everything was simpler and when adventure games were king. Loved the throwback to the 80's, loved the easter eggs and specially - loved all the puzzles... At about 21 hours of playtime i got stuck several times and was really proud to not have used a single hint to solve the game. This, for me, is a testament to adventure games and it could easily be one of the best adventure games of the 80's had it been released in that era... 

This goes to show that for such a niche market, you don't have to 3D your way through it to bring gamers in... If you don't have millions to develop a good 3D game, don't do it, it'll look bad. And besides, we adventure gamers LOVE the pixelated art or at the max a 2D HD game is enough... 

Thank you Ron Gilbert and Gary Winnick for this masterpiece...
