31160679.review:
OK, so I'm a veteran of gaming of the adventure kind. I played pretty much everything LucasArts put out and loved it at the time.

The non-spoiler version, I guess: if you're a die-hard fan of the 1980s/1990s style of games and wish we were back there, this would completely be the game for you. And if I were the me of that time period, I'd love this game and recommend it to everyone that played adventure games because it's a solid game that exemplifies everything we know and love about the genre as it was then.

The problem is, that's exactly what it is: a love letter to that time, unfortunately 20-odd years too late. I'm not the person I was 20 years ago and in fairness, it is exactly what it seems to be. I wasn't missold on it being a retro-themed game. I'm just bitter that it feels like it violates every one of Gilbert's own 'how not to design an adventure game' rules, whilst piling on the nerd/fanboy references.

-----

Now we've got the tl;dr version out of the way and the people who care about being spoiled are also out of the way, I want to look at what is wrong with this game, and why it is not the game I hoped it would be.

Graphically, it's exactly as presented. I'm a huge fan of the pixel aesthetic and this really shines. The fact that they can use the power of modern graphics to do things not doable in the real resolutions of the day is actually cool; the ghost effects when playing as Franklin after his initial flashback works rather well to set the mood. The tilting of Ransome's trailer gives you a sense of immersion not previously really doable in such games.

But from the off, it sets itself up in so many other bad ways.

Firstly, the references. I'm a fan of the old games. Yes, I know Sandy and Dave were in Maniac Mansion. Yes, I know about the 1138 stuff. Yes, I know who Bernard is. I know about the SCUMM engine. The in-jokes asked at one point which profession was involved, be it flooring inspector, pirate, or leather jacket salesman. I got these. I got them all because I remember.

I don't even mind the occasional wink to the audience, but when it's done gratuitously like this, where you can't move for references to things. It stops being an adventure game with a plot and starts being a love letter to times long ago. And if that's what you want in a game, sure, go for it. Unfortunately I wanted a game with a plot, with the occasional nod to the audience for fun.

Speaking of the plot. The plot is a mess. I get the mechanics of the multi-player making it very hard to have, say, cross-person dialogue. I accept the mechanics required everyone to know things that they individually shouldn't be able to know. I even grudgingly accept the additions to each characters' todo lists to reflect things even when sometimes those things didn't actually reflect the individual character's motivations or goals. But at the same time, the plot is paper thin in places, and obtuse throughout pretty much the story's second act onwards where people do things because the game insists they do them, without rhyme or reason behind it other than the player can direct them to do things. Of course, this does make some grudging sense given the climax, but it's such a cop-out to hand-wave everything in this fashion. More, possibly, of a cop-out than any explanation given after the ending of Monkey Island 2. Big Whoop indeed (even referenced in this game)

Though, I'll add, the todo list was a nice quality of life addition, with this many characters and potential lines of inquiry, it was a nice to have rather than expecting the player to track everything.

Then we have the puzzles. Holy monkey bladders. I will admit up front that I'm clearly insane and tried it in hard mode, and that possibly explains why the puzzles are that obtuse but I refuse to believe this was anything other than bad game design - Gilbert's own list and various articles of his outline what good game design should look like, and I see no reason why this should not extend to the 'hard' version.

There are puzzles that are definitely in the 'why didn't I think of that sooner' territory. And there are puzzles that I simply would not have solved without trying every object with every object in every location because it's simply not that obvious. I mean... the location of the secret bunker. There are so many things in that puzzle that just don't fit together as things you'd logically do to solve it. (SPOILERS AHEAD)

Let me break it down. So there is a secret bunker in the forest. I was vaguely aware this was a thing. But to have to take Delores' trophy, collect some radioactive waste, put it in the puddle in the trailhead, wait for someone to walk through it and then follow the footprints. This is something that would have seemed like a "logical" puzzle in the 1980s. Unfortunately it's 2017, as the game helpfully jokes about on multiple occasions about what life might be like.

And the problem with that being, the genre has moved on. What is considered 'acceptable' by players has moved on. Players who thoroughly favour the illogical hoops to jump through are firmly in the minority now - anyone who has played the Wadjet Eye Games will see the difference; none of those have anything like the guess-the-thing-to-use-with-the-thing games going on.

I still remember the Old Man Murray article that Gilbert referenced on occasion, that 'adventure games killed themselves' with the breakdown of a puzzle from Gabriel Knight. This is exactly what this feels like, a series of things that just happen to work together that don't actually connect except laterally. Gilbert himself stated on multiple occasions that he wanted to set up for the style of puzzle where the player has a problem and has to go find the thing to solve it, rather than being expected to collect everything along the way and somehow be expected to know when to use it - but here even tagging everything along didn't help in the slightest. I don't, for example, know if pewter can withstand radioactive waste - it certainly wouldn't have occurred to me as a first, second or even third thought.

Then there's the thimbleberries. I find this particular puzzle annoying for the wrong reason. I haven't tested it but I find it suspicious that the route to the thimbleberry bush is eeriely similar to a certain set of instructions that could be dancing lessons from a map written in 1990... It was the first thing I tried and it led me straight to them. To say that was disappointing...

And this leads me onto the ending. The ending is horrible. Utterly horrible. It undermines everything the game set itself up for. We had a cast of characters that were annoying to various degrees - but I at least cared about the outcome of them. I wanted Reyes to get his closure. I wanted Ransome to get redeemed (hoping that the interview with Natalie would somehow do this). I didn't know until quite late what Ray's real objective was, and finding out actually undermined her, she seemed like a good agent for the most part (though where she said that all she did was as little work as possible didn't help her at all!)

But I had a cast of characters I had some investment in. And then the finale killed whatever investment I had. Closure for Franklin was nice but overshadowed by the Big Reveal. Reyes getting his closure by way of the newspaper was valid, though it irked me that he didn't keep his promise to Willie and that we didn't actually 'solve' Boris' murder as far as the sheriff-a-reno was concerned. (Also, the a-reno, a-who and a-boo thing was stupid. Very stupid. And it didn't really answer the point from the journal that the coroner had been fired and replaced. Though the coronor was even worse at his job than the sheriff, and that irked me too)

Lots of nice ideas and some technically excellent execution but it's the wrong end of a time warp for me. Wrong end of a time warp and in search of a plot. Shame, too. I really wanted it to not be that.

31156086.review:
Having grown up playing Monkey Island, I came to Thimbleweed Park hoping for a dose of nostalgia from that classic era of point and click adventure games. Thimbleweed Park certainly delivered that nostalgia, but exceeded my expectations by proving to be an addictive, mysterious, amusing little adventure in it's own right.  On a technical level, the game is a delight, the pixel style being reminiscent of those old adventures but clearly updated in a way that makes it shine and not look dated in the current day. Sound and voice-acting was excellent too.

I loved the atmosphere of this game. Something I've heard Ron Gilbert talk about in interviews is giving the game a sense of "place" and that's something I really felt, the town intrigued me and was a joy to explore. It definitely has that creepy Twin Peaks vibe. I enjoyed meeting all of the odd and zany characters, especially the main ones you can switch between - Ransome and Delores were particular stand-outs, and I found their individual stories contained some touching moments as well as amusing ones.

Puzzle-wise, I am often worried about getting stumped for hours on illogical puzzles in point and click adventures, but I'm happy to say I didn't feel like that with Thimbleweed Park. I played on "hard", though I would describe it more as the normal mode for those familiar with these sorts of games. I found the majority of the puzzles to be at a good level of logic, and I found that a lot could be solved by paying attention to the details of dialogue and conversations. A few got me stumped for a while but mostly in a way where I could go away and ponder on it, then come back with a new idea, and felt satisfied when I figured them out. Nothing seemed too obscure to me, nor too easy, so I felt the puzzles were at a really good level.

There are so many cool little touches in this game too, particularly for fans of Monkey Island and Maniac Mansion, and even the fact that there are 100s of books in the game written by the fans who kickstarted it. Very cool.

Overall my only complaint with the game is that the later parts felt a little rushed in comparison to the first parts, but it still took me 18 hours overall which felt like a decent length for the adventure. 


I would give Thimbleweed Park 8.5/10 just because of the latter part feeling slightly rushed, but all in all I loved this game!

31132700.review:
Thimbleweed park is an excellent old school graphic adventure by Ron Gilbert, who back in the day helped create some of Lucasarts most memorable adventures including Monkey Island and Maniac Mansion.

As you can tell by the screenshots the game goes for a very retro feel graphically. The scenes and animations are quite well done and are full of life and detail. So long as you dig the kind of retro aesthetic the game is going for, it's a title that really nails what it's aiming at and I enjoyed it a lot.

The sound is a little up and down, music and sound effects are great, but some of the voice work is a little dodgy. I should be clear, there is nothing game breaking here, just some of the characters sound off. For the most part the cast is well voiced though.

As to the gameplay, it's classic old school fare, requiring you to examine things carefully and talk to all the characters to get clues. Most problems are of the use item on item variety and for the vast majority of them, they are very logical. Some of the old school games required great leaps in logic (Or a total absense of logic), Thimbleweed park is a game where in nearly every case, the solution makes sense. There are two difficulty modes, hard for those who prefer more challenging puzzles, and casual for those who would rather just persue the story.

I'm not going to say too much about the story actually, as it's best experienced. It begins with a murder and two FBI agents investigating it. Both characters are playable and as the game goes on, 3 more will be added to the roster. Having 5 different characters makes for some interesting puzzles and you will need your team to work together to finish some of them. If you ever get stuck there is always something to be doing with another character, and its possible that furthering another characters path could open up the solution that was stumping you. Overall I found the story to be quite engaging and it gets deeper as the game unfolds.

My only minor complaints for this one are some patchy voice acting and the inability to skip dialogue you have already heard.

A really solid adventure. 8/10

Let's use these old shit assets (wtf is with the wireframe world otherwise?) and make Dolores make some just-obvious-enough comments!"  They could've had a really well fleshed out ending if they would've gone with AI takes over the master and makes duplicate-arinos throughout town but what they went with was total garbage.

31127099.review:
What a wonderful and charming game! Thimbleweed Park kept me engaged from start to finish, with colourful characters, well-crafted puzzles, and a meaty mystery to get invested in. It's a classic adventure game where you play as multiple characters that initially set out to solve a murder, but as the story progresses the focus shifts much more onto the main characters and their (sometimes!) dark histories.

The art and sound are top notch, and in classic adventure game fashion reward you with beautiful new locations whenever you solve a new puzzle. Steve Kirk's soundtrack also adds a subtle level of atmosphere to the whole experience, invoking old television series themes and weaving them with tunes that feel right out of the LucasArts (Mmucusphlegm?) games of yore.

The puzzles themselves are very well designed and generally logical. I got stuck a couple of times, but there is so much content that it was never boring to revisit previous locations looking for missed items or dialogue choices. It never took long to find a clue to help point me in the right direction, and each character having a journal always gave me a sense of what I was trying to accomplish.

Don't let the retro style and pixel art fool you! There are a lot of refinements to the general adventure game formula, with fast travel, dialogue and cutscene skipping, quest logs (in a sense), and other clever little quality of life improvements that make the whole experience smoother. The game is designed in such a way as to avoid the old adventure game trap of getting stuck on a single puzzle. With a multitude of player characters each with their own goals, if you ever get stuck you can just switch to another character and start trying to solve a different set of puzzles. You can also tackle many puzzles in whatever order you choose, and as a result there were very few of the bottlenecks that have so often made me turn off the game in the past.

This game is a MUST for adventure game fans, and will delight and amuse you with all the nods and winks to the mighty and venerable genre we know and love. It's also a great game to sit and play through with friends, since the story hooks you in and keeps you guessing right to the incredibly satisifying end. Some of the references might go over the heads of the uninitiated, but that just made the game feel that much more special to me. So go and get a copy of Thimbleweed Park right away, you won't regret it!

With a storyline that gains depth with every chapter, I'd reccomend this game to a friend. I'd probably reccomend playing the casual version to someone if they don't want to go through hard mode scowering the map for a nickle; It took me a really long time to realize that *SPOILER*, if you look past where the guy in the Quickie Pal typically stands, theres a sign that says they'll take a bottle off your hands and give you five cents. Much of the time, the puzzles weren't too bad. You can often figure out what to do based on the name of the current chapter, which dialogues keep reappearing when talking to various characters, and comments your character says. However, there were quite a few moments like the one I mentioned with the nickle. Another example is *SPOILER* how you are supposed to find ice cream (i-scream?) ghost cake. Well, you're not. You're supposed to freeze regular ghost cake. Also, why would I *SPOILER* ever pour toxic/radioactive waste into a puddle? Well, the answer is, I wouldn't. Just like I wouldn't normally pick up specks of dust whenever I see them. But that's the thing about this game; you have to do things you wouldn't normally think to do.

Overall, this game is creative, has a wonderful storyline, and requires some out of the box thinking. At times, I wished there were some more hints as to which direction to take (if you go down the wrong train of thought, it can take a bit to realize that it's time to switch gears), but for someone who doesn't rush through games for the storyline like I do, this would be a great purchase. This is a game for someone who is in it for the experience of the game, rather than the story behind it.

31118201.review:
Vuelta a Maniac Mansion:

Thimbleweed Park es un verdadero regreso a Maniac Mansion en toda regla, pues el "LORE" de aquel está aqui solapado de forma que deja claro que ambos títulos forman parte del mismo "universo". (Incluso veremos o nos harán mención a los protagonistas de Maniac Mansion,al meteorito de la mansión EDISON y a los tentáculos!)

Es un clásico atemporal, si este juego hubiera salido a principio de los 90s sin duda estaría a la altura de Maniac Mansion o Monkey Island en el colectivo aventurero, pero lanzado en 2017 es un GRAN HOMENAJE a nuestras inolvidables noches delante de nuestro PC 386 SX.

La historia que comienza investigando un asesinato consigue enredarse y llegar a un climax como solo Ron Gilbert nos acostumbró ya en tiempos de la búsqueda del BIG WHOOP, nos sorprenderá.
Los puzzles son los suficientemente enredados como para dejarnos atascados durante horas, pero en cualquier caso son más lógicos y menos basados en el "ensayo/error" que en  otras aventuras de antaño.
Los dialogos y el humor sigue intacto, logra mantener nuestro interés, nos sacará mas de una sonrisa y en ningún momento nos aburrirá leer dialogos y elegir las distintas opciones de diálogo.
La cooperación entre los 5 protagonistas para resolver puzzles, salvando momentos puntuales es anecdótica. Maniac Mansion o Day of the Tentacle potenciaba mucho mas este aspecto de cooperación, aqui los distintos personajes mas que estar insertados para cooperar en la resolución de puzzles (salvando contadas ocasiones) justifican su presencia para aportar sus tramas propias/cruzadas que deben resolver "de forma independiente". 

Si vienes de las aventuras de los 80s/90s compralo ya, OBLIGADO! Si te gustan las aventuras de Telltale y quieres jugar una aventura OLD SCHOOL que suponga un verdadero desafiao puede ser también interesante. Si tu caso no es ninguno de estos espera al lanzamiento de los próximos 12 CALL OF DUTYs.

31105748.review:
Quando si deve recensire un gioco da qualcuno come Ron Gilbert è sempre problematico, dopotutto stiamo parlando di una delle menti, geniali, dietro a "Monkey Island"!

Scherzi a parte il gioco è assolutamente bello!
Se volete sparare la tipica domanda: "Sì ma pari a MI?"... a parere mio assolutamente no... cioè è bello, divertente e gli enigmi sono pure tosti ogni tanto, ma credo che, onestamente vuoi anche per nostalgia, qualcosa che raggiunga gli apici di MI ancora deve venire. (Escludendo seguiti di MI stesso)

E forse anche a proposito!!! MI era demenziale praticamente dall'inizio alla fine, Thimbleweed Park in alcune parti potrebbe quasi, sottolineo il quasi, sembrare un'avventura seria e da questo punto di vista tanto di cappello a Ron nel non aver voluto a tutti i costi "parodiare" MI.
Non franteindetemi però, ci si diverte, i suoi momenti li ha sicuramente e vi troverete a ridere pure durante i titoli di coda, ma probabilmente è l'ambientazione in sé: in uno sei un pirata wannabe con prove assurde, ecc., qua si cerca di risolvere un assassinio e in generale il mistero che si nasconde dietro TP stessa!

Per concludere comunque, visto che problemi prestazionali non ce ne sono e parlare del gameplay mi sembrerebbe un po' assurdo, credo che l'unica parola che si possa usare in questo caso sia: imperdibile! (^_~)

31104899.review: Amazing game, totally exceeded the hype and am guarenteed to buy the next one... hurry up! :)

31104684.review:
I have played the game, and finished both easy and hard modes. Easy is really nice for the story and to have a quick game. There is little that is tricky and you should be able to get through it without many issues. The hard mode is as you'd expect if you played the old games such as Maniac Mansion, Monkey Island, etc. puzzles are harder, you really need to talk to everyone and use everything.

TP is definitely worth getting, if you are not sure about hard mode, doing easy first does help a lot if you decide to replay in hard mode as a lot of the puzzles are either the same or you just need to work out how to create/get the object you need.

Overall I love it, I hope they make more and will back other projects from these adventure creating geniuses.

Thank you Ron and Gary.

31102260.review:
I have to say that I expected TP to be good, considerig who was behind it, but I never thought I would enjoy it just as thoroughly as I did. Much like Ron Gilbert himself proclaimed in pre-release interviews, TP isn't a new point-and-click adventure game trying to replicate the exact formula of 80's/90's adventure games as much as it is a new game that plays out like your *memory* of those games. And most of all, it's a *deconstruction* of the classic adventure game, more than it is a reproduction of it. 

And it actually works absolutely marvellously. The quirky, funny and also slightly eerie tone of the game is complimented by some of the best adventure game puzzle design I have seen in years. Playing in hard mode, the challenge was at a perfect level of difficulty almost throughout the the whole game. For once, I found myself truly transported back to my childhood, with puzzles and obstacles lingering in my mind throught the workdays and nights, but never stumping me or forcing me to give in to hints in pure frustration, as is so often the case. Instead, I only felt joy and pure fun from the challenge of thinking out different solutions in my head. 

Towards the final couple of chapters, though, the puzzles starts to lose some of their brilliance, and the fun somewhat dries up. Sadly, the story also sort of loses a bit of its charm in time for the last act, with the story taking a meta-turn that is funny in a way, but also sort of dampens the previously built-up tension and engagement in the story. 

As a whole, though, TP is a glorious return to form for Ron Gilbert, and a superbly entertaining 80's romp that hopefully makes way for more Ron Gilbert adventure games to come.

31096046.review: Thimbleweed Park is exactly what it says it is: a SCUMM styled point and click adventure game made by the original SCUMM team! Set during the golden age of adventure games in 1987, Thimbleweed Park takes you on a whirlwind journey with a cast of unique characters and humorous dialogue. If you've played any of the old LucasArts adventure games, you will feel right at home, as this feels like the long lost love child of Maniac Mansion and Monkey Island. The game has tons of references and callbacks aimed at veteran gamers. This is truly an experience you will not want to miss.

31095491.review:
Für mich ein absolutes Highlight, ich habe das Spiel extrem genossen. Jeder der Zak, Maniac oder Monkey Island gespielt hat wird hier einen Treffer landen. Kritik an Rätseln oder technischen Mängeln finde ich persönlich kaum welche und wenn sind diese Punkte völlig unkritisch. 

Was mich persönlich aber am allermeisten freut: 
Das die Art und Weise wie sich das Team um seine Backer / Kunden gekümmert hat aufgegangen ist. Die vielen Interviews, die Podcasts, die ausführlichen Blogposts mit Einblicken in die Entwicklung. Die ganzen Berichte von Messen und Aktionen wie die Treffen in London, München und Berlin, etc. Das hat mir ein Gefühl gegeben es mit ehrlichen Leuten zu tun zu haben die wirklich daran interssiert sind ein geiles Produkt herzustellen.

Die Arroganz mit der sich so manche andere Studios hinstellen und verbuggte Spiele (zum Teil auch große AAA Titel) rausrotzen ist mittlerweile ja kaum noch auszuhalten. Hier ist ein Beispiel wie es auch anders geht, DAS ist für mich das eigentliche Highlight an diesem wirklich gelungenen Spiel. Es ist mehr als ein Spiel für mich, es ist eines der Beispiele wie Crowdfunding gut funktionieren kann.

Alleine für den Preis ist es für jeden auch nur annähernd Interssierten ein absoluter Pflichtkauf.

31087636.review:
I loved the old LucasFilm adventure games. I grew up with Monkey Island, Indiana Jones and Loom... Ron Gilbert was a name that got engraved in my memory. So I was quite excited when I heard they were launching a Kickstarter for a new game in the style of their old adventures.

In the meantime, I tried some other, modern adventures and was somehow disappointed. Although they were funny and engaging, I just didn't enjoy them that much. I thought that maybe I just "grew out of it".

That is, until Thimbleweed Park got released.
After some friends of mine totally freaking out about it, I thought "oh well, let's give it one last shot".
And wow, I wasn't disappointed.

[list]
 [*]The game looks nice, if you're into the pixelated retro-look (which it even jokes about itself. I love that.)
 [*]The dialogues are funny and sometimes self-referential, fourth-wall-breaking and meta. Always in a charming way, no tryhard meme-harr-harr-awkwardness.
 [*]The story is engaging and keeps you coming back
 [*]If you haven't played any of the old LucasFilm Adventures, you might miss out on a few referential jokes, but these aren't really game relevant. 
 [*]The two characters you start out with pretty much seem to have the same dialogues through a big part of the game, so this seemed a bit redundant in my eyes.
[/list]

I would wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone wo likes a good point & click adventure game. 
I found out, I certainly didn't grow out of these :)

31085908.review:
Soy un gran jugador de aventuras gráficas desde los años 80 (he jugado casi todas las franquicias importantes, desde las clásicas de Lucas y Sierra como King's Quest y todos los Monkey Island, hasta otras sagas más modernas como Secret Files, Borken Sword o Blackwell).

Thimbleweed Park tiene TODO lo que cualquier fan de las aventuras gráficas podría querer. Para empezar, se ve que es bastante largo (cuando un juego te gusta mucho y lodisfrutas, es una lástima terminarlo demasiado pronto). Yo no lo termino aún, pero parece que voy más o menos por la mitad y llevo jugadas 12 horas sin usar walktroughs ni nada.

Tiene uno de los mejores equibrios de dificultad que he visto. Cuando una aventura gráfica es demasiado difícil o incoherente se hace frustrante. Si, en cambio, es demasiado fácil, aburre pronto.

El hecho de que puedas jugar con muchos personajes le agrega una gran diversidad y hace que no se torne monótono. Por si esto no fuera poco, el mapa es ENORME. Múltiples pantallas que visitar, explorar y recorrer prácticamente al mismo tiempo, como sifuera un juego de escenario abierto.

Hay muchas otras MUY BUENAS aventuras gráficas en las cuales la acción avanza y se pueden visitar no más de 3 o 4 pantallas a la vez. En este caso, se van abriendo algunas nuevas, pero las viejas permanecen accesibles, por lo que cada vez hay más por investigar.

En definitiva, habiendo jugado más de 100 aventuras gráficas, y sin haberla terminado aún, la pongo derecho en mi top 5 al lado de Monkey Island 2, The Longest Journey o Grim Fandango sin dudas.

Por favor, a cualquiera que haya disfrutado un point & click, NO DEJEN PASAR esta joya repleta de humor.

This game is really fantastic. I am really very positivly surprised by this because some other adventure games I have played recently didn't really were that good after all.

But Thimbleweed Park has amazing writing, awesome art, good voice acting and amazing music. It really is fantastic, and the length is also perfect. Not too short, but not too long to feel overly drawn out.

In general the jokes are good, but sometimes they might be a bit too much inside gags that a lot of people will not understand.

And here is the only negative thing, people like me, who played all the old LucasArts adventure games will love this game and get all the jokes. But people who haven't or are younger, they will not get them and might rather think they are stupid or not funny at all.

31076534.review:
Wonderful game. I played for 14 hours without using a guide but in the end hit a brick wall and had to google the solution to a few puzzles in order to make progress.  Those puzzles weren't necessarily more difficult than the puzzles I had already solved, but after 14 hours of puzzle solving...my old brain said "no more". It says something about how much I loved this game that I spent two or three hours trying everything to solve those remaining puzzles (and I solved a lot of puzzles in that time, but not them all).

Thimbleweed Park starts gently but expands to include a remarkable web of puzzles. The overall effect - I think anyone who has completed the game will agree - is very, very impressive.

I've only talked about the puzzles but there are so many other positive aspects to Thimbleweed Park. Not least the ending, which will put a smile on the face of anyone who's been following this game from the beginning. I won't say any more. :)

31067046.review:
No sabes lo que tienes hasta que lo pierdes...

...y no sabes cuánto lo echaste de menos hasta que lo vuelves a encontrar.
______

Thimbleweed Park es muchas cosas: 

Es una vuelta a los 90 del pixelote y el humor cafre... pero con un punto de veteranía, unos recursos y un cuidado al detalle inconcebibles años atrás. Tantas aventuras gráficas modernas comiéndose la cabeza para eliminar y/o simplificar hasta el ridículo la caja de verbos para que ahora descubramos de golpe que no sólo no es una aberración que no molesta tanto, sino que es hasta útil. ¡Qué demonios! ¡Es casi como si usarla fuera la forma ideal de jugar a estos juegos!

También es una muestra de que al jugador moderno no hay que darle todo tan taaaaan masticado. Aún es posible amaestrarlo. Pocas veces se disfruta más de un videojuego que al encontrar la solución tras largas horas de atasco en una Aventura Gráfica. Sobre todo si los puzles son lógicos y, aún siendo desafiantes, nunca resultan frustrantes. En esto Thimbleweed Park funciona a la perfección porque tienes tantos frentes abiertos que, aunque te atasques en un punto, podrás seguir con otros puzles hasta ir resolviendo los otros por simple eliminación y deducción. No es como esos juegos en los que te atascas en un puzle y sabes que hasta que lo resuelvas ya no puedes avanzar, ésos en los que quieres reventar la impresora/pantalla/puño contra el ordenador. ¿Que te has atascado en 'A' en Thimbleweed Park? Pues ok, cambia de personaje y tira para 'B' a ver qué hay.

Y también es, por supuesto, una confesión de amor por lo que un día fueron los juegos. Sin mamonadas filosóficas, sin disparos, sin 100 millones de presupuesto en reflejos de luz fotorrealistas en el agua y un oscuro protagonista que busca la redención. Sin helicópteros explotando en 4K, aliens-robot, ni nosequé actor que salía en esa peli que le ha hecho el motion capture al padre del villano. 

Es sólo un juego donde se ve que los creadores se lo han paso casi tan bien haciéndolo y escribiéndolo como yo jugándolo.
______

Por cierto, al juego le doy un 8/10.


Contras:

El final es un poco gratuito y es lo menos inspirado del juego. También hay veces en las que tener tantos personajes que hacen y dicen lo mismo en buena mayoría de las acciones se hace un poco pesado y les resta personalidad. 

Pros:

Todo lo demás.

31060721.review:
I beat Thimbleweed Park last night. It requires two play-throughs to 100% achievements.

[b]Overall it's an excellent P&C Adventure game.[/b] There are a few places it stumbles but I'm not actually sure if it was *intended* to be "bad" in those particular instances. Without giving out spoilers, I'll give an example that was used in-game.

Very early on in the game, there is a moment where the fourth wall is broken and they reassure the player that Thimbleweed Park is not like Sierra games where the game can suddenly end and you'll need to back track through saves. But there actually *is* one instance where, KABOOM, game over, you shouldn't have done that, reload.

We, the players, are given fourth-wall-breaking information that is purposely false. While at first I thought this was just tongue-in-cheek stuff to laugh at older P&C tropes, instead I'm now thinking that there is an added layer of mystery that we're supposed to figure out?

The first half of the game starts with a Mystery Murder whose protagonists have hidden agendas themselves. During the course of the game as you reveal the plot, I almost feel like the mystery inverts itself. Like the information that we're given as players is, once again, false. 

That is to say, I think there are multiple endings, but I've only experienced one. I experienced the one where I thought the fourth wall breaking information was truthful. 

Naturally I could be WELL over-thinking things, but having experienced an ending that was kind of lackluster and re-thinking events that happened in the game, I have to wonder if there aren't more layers.

Anyhoo, Thimbleweed Park is solid even if you take everything at face value in the game. 

Side-note: the voice actor for Leisure Suit Larry uses the Larry voice in the game. Not sure why that is either. MORE MYSTERIES.

31058978.review:
[h1]IL FIGLIO LEGGITTIMO DI MANIAC MANSION E ZAK McKRACKEN[/h1]
Dopo i giochi a puntate di Sam&Max e Monkey Island, quegli "Adventures of"/"Tales of" che personalmente non considero nemmeno della famiglia Lucas (velo pietoso su Monkey Island 4), temevo un po' l'uscita di questo Thimbleweed Park. Avevo paura che s'infrangessero altri miti di gioventù: Ron Gilbert, Gary Winnick e David Fox, i factotum degli anni d'oro di LUCASFILM. Beh, mi sbagliavo: gallina vecchia fa buon brodo! ;-D

Le atmosfere alla Twin Peaks e X-files fanno da contorno a un'avventura esteticamente ineccepibile, che sotto i suoi pixel nasconde meccanismi solo accennati nella golden-age per ovvi limiti tecnici. Ecco quindi il parlato per tutto il gioco, tonnellate di contenuti creati dai backers, un'apparente libertà di movimento (potrete affrontare gli enigmi nell'ordine che preferite), tanti effetti grafici e personaggi a schermo, senza dimenticare quel costante sfondamento della [i]quarta parete[/i] che negli anni '80 e '90 ci ha regalato gran divertimento.
Ovvio che la comicità e i tormentoni di Gilbert&Winnick siano figli di un'altra epoca e possano non piacere a tutti, ma per chiunque abbia adorato e conosca a memoria le avventure LUCASFILM & LUCASARTS, Thimbleweed Park è pieno di riferimenti, autocitazioni, strizzate d'occhio ed enigmi tratti dai precursori del genere punta e clicca che non potranno lasciarvi impassibili. Il tutto sostenuto da una trama intrigante che si dipana lungo quindici/venti ore di gioco, supportata da una grafica low-res, successivamente upscalata ad arte.
La scelta dei verbi a schermo fa riaffiorare quelle idee di emancipazione ridimensionate solo nel '93 dall'interfaccia grafica di Sam&Max e rinforza l'idea di antica discendenza. Gli shortcut da tastiera fungono come 30 anni fa, compresa la lumachina durante la pausa e qualche gradita aggiunta come il TAB per evidenziare gli oggetti a schermo (come l'F11 di Simon the sorcerer!), ma la cosa bella è che oltre al mouse si può tranquillamente usare un gamepad... e funziona egregiamente! :-)

Tirando le somme (ahia!), da superfanatico risolutore di avventure quale sono ed ero vi posso dire: COMPRATELO SENZA ESITAZIONE! Se avete ancora nel cuore un po' di quell'omino dorato in piedi sulla gigantesca "L", questo titolo farà l'effetto della torta della nonna che non mangiate da vent'anni. E il prezzo è sotto al limite consigliato nel '90 da Guybrush!!! ;-)

Amazing game that feels like stepping into the world of a David Lynch film. Some of the background tunes make it very apparent early on, that it borrows from influences like Twin Peaks. It pays a huge amount of fan service to earlier LucasArts games. Which is either incredibly awesome or won't really strike a cord with you if you're a new comer of Ron Gilbert's games. 

Much like the original Maniac Mansion you're put in control of multiple characters. Personally, out of them all. I find Ransome the Clown the most enjoyable to explore and go through the dialogue tree's with. Unfortunately alot of the times each character will basically just repeat the same dialogue without adding anything new or commenting from their own unique perspective. 

As seems to be the case alot of people find the ending to be rather weak. Personally it doesn't bother me for the fact that it leaves alot of options should a sequel or expansion dlc be released. Most of the puzzles aren't to insane to figure out compared to the older games. Once in awhile you will come across a bit of a head scratcher but with a bit of thought an persistence it's nothing you can't overcome. 

Maybe the biggest complaint is a part of the game that requires you to go back and watch a very early kickstart video of this game. Which could be incredibly annoying to come across if you were playing the game offline for instance. That or just don't feel like searching the web to go back and find it. Not quite sure what the reasoning was for including that as a in-game clue... 

All in all the music is superb, the writing and voice acting very well done and fitting. Along with some great pixel visuals from painted landscapes down to a 1980's convenience store! It's a good trip and one that most likely won't disappoint adventure fans. Give it a shot!

31045047.review:
First, a disclaimer: I am one of the original Kickstarter backers, so I could be biased towards wanting to like the game in a less objective way than as a mere customer. On the other hand, the expectation for the game's qualities was also very high.

To me, Thimbleweed Park(TM) has ticks in all the boxes: it presents a rich and colourful world, an intriguing plot and many interesting characters. It builds on the reputation of the adventure game classics and pioneers, but the execution works well  for the modern desktop, and I can imagine it fits into living room or mobile platform just as well.

The designers' choice was to go for a pixelated 16-bit-like graphics. This is in no way a downside, because it manages to pull off many beautiful screens and backgrounds. It also adds to the visuals features like dynamic character lighting and shading, which would not be doable 30 years ago.

The puzzles are all solvable as long as you pay attention, remember the places and characters and apply logical thinking. I got stuck only a handful of times, but to my own oversight. The player does need to apply some sense to the game, so I would not call the game trivial and easy, at least not on the hardcore mode.

I did find it a bit annoying at the beginning that the game seemed to have been stealing control over the current character in the many of the introductory flashbacks. But in the long run (and by that I mean 15 hours gameplay and more), these introductions were well worth it, because we do get to meet and know these characters better. I particularly liked being able to revisit the town and its inhabitants with the newcomers, getting fresh perspectives on their own background and the backround of the locals.

I think we have come a long way with the adventure games. Thimbleweed Park(TM) works so much better than just the parts from Maniac Mansion and Monkey Island combined. It delivers a rich and entertaining package well worth the price tag.

31042284.review: This is the first review I have ever done on Steam... This game is freaking awesome. I love it. I actually started it on 'casual' mode, but after reading some reviews and the discussion threads, I started over (mid-chapter 2, about 3 hours in) on hard mode, and I am SO glad i did! I was afraid it would be too difficult, and I'd become frustrated and end up (as I often do with games of this type) just going to the walkthroughs every time I started having trouble, and would eventually lose steam and lose interest...I still havent finished DOTT because the switching of characters and inventory items between characters was too overwhelming...but I did not find that to be the case in Thimbleweed Park.  Instead, I have been so engrossed by this game that I only went to the walkthroughs once (I don't WANT to go to the walkthroughs, it ruins my experience almost every time)... I thought I was totally stuck in the sewer, but the answer was right in front of me. If you love point and clicks like Monkey Island and the other LucasArts games, etc then PLAY THIS GAME! Just do it! This is the first Steam game I have ever paid full price for, and not only dont I regret it... I probably would've paid more. Mark my words, this game will go down in history as one of the best point-n-click adventure games EVER. It has just the right level of difficulty, is so entertaining, and the characters are fantastic (especially Ransome). I just started Chapter 4, and I have to stop playing and go to bed now because I work tonight. I will be dreaming of Thimbleweed Park.

31031993.review:
Excellent. While this was made for those who always loved the classic LucasArts adventure games, it really should appeal to anyone who wants a game that truly feels like soulful art coming from an individual/small team. This game has personality. It's akin to an interactive book from your favorite author VS a mainstream Hollywood production that's passed through 1000 hands.

It 100% captures the spirit of an old LucasArts adventure game, in the best way possible, and I am honestly more drawn to it than many of my AAA games I still haven't finished. It's hard to put down, because it's just so enjoyable to experience the world, characters, and story. This game is pure joy, and while it will absolutely appeal to any and every old school adventure game player I can't imagine it wouldn't appeal to anyone open to a good, unique game. It's not for the ADD inclined fancy graphics, shooter crowd. And while I love those too, this sort of game is an absolute lost art and I'm convinced if more people experienced it, the genre would make a resurgence. It's funny, it's witty, it's entertaining, it's smart, and THANK GOD - the return of the LucasArt's adventure game is back.

Everything I had hoped it would turn out to be, and honestly, I think a bit more. Big thumbs up.

Just finished the game. I liked it. 

One of the first video games that I ever played was Monkey Island 1 and I was hooked on LucasArt's point and clicks after that. I've ultimately played the entire adventure game catalog from LucasArts. 

This game is like the old LucasArts never went away and kept the SCUMM engine alive. The puzzles in this game are a lot more logical than the older games and the overall game sees the benefit of having veteren adventure game developers make the game. 

The story is overall pretty interesting though maybe some weak parts at the end. The interesting story and puzzles carry the game. The humor isn't quite as strong when compared to the older, more cartoony point and clicks. It's got the same kind of quirky and tongue-in-cheek absurdity of Full Throttle I'd say. The story this time is a mystery and that's probably what dicated the feel of the game. The older games were never shy about referencing other games, but this game definitely pushes the references harder; maybe a bit too much. Still, if you like the LucasArt's point and clicks, this is a no-brainer recommendation. 

p.s. For those that might not know or remember, the "." button lets you fast forward through text in the game, like the old LucasArts stuff. I wish they let us map this to a different keyboard button though, since it's a bit awkward with it being away from the other shortcut keys (i.e. q, w, e, a, s, d, z, x, c)

TL;DR version will follow;

This is old school gaming done right. Puzzles are clever and only very few of them feels far fetched and only on the hard difficulty. The story might feel a bit senseless to some, but stay focused, read all possible dialogue and while it will feel really weird, if not disjoninted, everything is explained and taking time to actually understand Thimblewee Park and its characters leads to satisfaction and that "what the heck???" feel I expect from adventure games. There are many unexpected twists. Finding the solution to the hardest puzzles after spending a lot of time on them give that satisfaction feel people are expecting from those games. The game already received a bunch of updates, which proves the devs are hard at work and intend to deliver a solid experience. I really hope those guys are going to bring us more games like that in the near future!

Pros:
- The story has many "What the heck???" moments.
- Many unexpected twists.
- Creative puzzles, some easier, some harder.
- 2 Difficulty levels will please both hardcore and casual puzzle solvers.
- Old school done right.
- Frequent updates.
- The devs are using community feedback much to improve their game.
- Timed puzzles are rare and doesn't push you towards optimal navigation speed to solve them.

Cons:
- Not much music variety.
- 2 puzzles feels far fetched on hard difficulty.
- The story might feels hard to grasp when not reading all dialogues.

31017190.review:
Thimbleweed Park is a point and click adventure game that wants to stay in the past. Even if I grew with old MMucasFlem, ehem, LucasArts games, I feel I moved on from some of the ideosyncrancies games like this one.
For those you have not noticed that already, the game UI and art style evokes an era around 1990. You get a bottom side of the screen with both the verb list and the inventory. For those you did not live through that era, the developers even matched the verb list with the keyboard shortcuts. The story itself is also set in 1987, so it is hard not to think of nostalgia. Computers like the C64 are in the game.
The problem I see is regarding the innovations the developers tried for this game. One of them that you will notice is that almost every location spans over one screen. I get that you can now make every location stretch, unlike earlier games like Monkey Island, where pan movement of the camera was a truly first for a game like that. However, it makes traversal slower. Add to that that stretched locations do not add much to the game at all, with them being empty. Cemetery is especially aggravating. Developers added some tricks to make traversal faster - and even so I feel it is a little bit slow to my taste.
Another inguriating feature of the game is the multiple characters you take into control. This feature, when done correctly, does add something extra to the game. You shall expect actions that can only be done by a character, like the computer game designer being proficient with computers. There are a few situations where two characters need to do two separate things based on a timer, but that is all that it is. There is no direct interaction between characters except for transferring inventory items. Motivation of the different characters working together is non existant. One annoying feature of the game is that various characters do tell the same lines, just with different voice actors. There is an in-game joke that plays at the end of the game regarding that, although by that time I was alread past the annoyed phase.
As with any graphic adventure game, inventory and dialogue puzzles are the centre piece of the game elements. They are OK, nothing too stravagant or anything like that. I need to add that puzzles can only be solved in specific acts inside the game. You might already have all the components, but you cannot get past that hurdle until the dialog option opens. Apart from that, they are not too far fetched. That is, if you assume characters are telepathic or something.
The story is OK, although I do not particularly agree on how it is split.
I am sure that those that Kickstarted the game like things like appearing in the phone book. As a non backer, I have mixed feelings about that. I feel it pads the game with unnecessary and distracting info. The worst idea is that you more or less need to watch an early video at the Kickstarter page in order to know how to solve a puzzle.
I hope this review tells you which kind of game you are getting into. I was disconnected from the characters during most of the game, thus not really wanting to see what is next. If you have a lot of patience and endurance, feel free to apply.

Thimbleweed Park is absolutely a must have for those who grew up with Monkey Island, Day of the Tentacles and other adventure games.

Prepare yourself for the fourth wall to be constantly broken. The game is not too difficult (i only got stuck in a couple of puzzles and it didn't take very long to get unstuck) and has a ton of content to explore.

The only weak point in this game is the story, which, withouth spoiling too much, stay hanging a bit too much. Most characters works for the same goal (without knowing each other) through you and early on this breaks the immersion a bit too much.

I loved this game and i hope Ron Gilbert, Gary Winnick and their amazing staff make more.

If you grew up with monkey island, you'll love Thimbleweed Park. A must buy, especially for the fans!

31012009.review:
It's hard to meet expectation. From waiting years as a backer to who created it, Ron Gilbert, Godfather of the point and click and now back in his realm. But if I'm honest, this game has smashed right through my expectations and risen above and beyond what I hoped for and imagined. It's like waiting years and years for a new record from your favorite band and somehow it's better then ever before, it's an entire album of new personal favorites. 
The story shocked me in how cinematic it was written, so well orchestrated I found myself pondering what a movie would be like if made (id see the crap out of it). The humor was what I worried about, could it cut it with today's tastes. Another strong yes, I laughed out loud dozens of times from inside jokes to the adventure gamer to just great wit. Then there's the insult clown who's voice acting is tip top and who's lines are legitimately edgy here in 2017. It's not PC and I loved it. 
The puzzles are magnificent. Put it this way- I got really stuck twice and in the end I was literally over thinking it both times. That's refreshing from a genre where more often than not you could rip hair out over-thinking and still not come to grips with what the game wanted. Not in this game. It's intuitive and I think I got held up or stuck when I treated it like adventure games past, only to realize I skipped an obvious or simple approach and find that was the solution. 
The characters and story intertwined beautifully both as an epic journey and as a puzzle solving team. In fact the co-op use of the 5 unique characters made it hard to feel trapped, anytime progress was thwarted I'd switch characters, make progress with them and return to the other with a fresh mind set. 
I'm sad it's over, the ending was hilarious, incredibly creative and actually a bit touching. 
This has to be the greatest game in my favorite genre, ever. So here's to the team making more and meanwhile, enough time passing so i can play it again!

31001449.review:
This game is billed as a nostalgic throwback to the adventure games of the nineties, and it delivers on that a bit too much. I both enjoyed this game and was deeply annoyed with it the entire time I was playing.  I wish there was a third option between thumbs up and thumbs down.  Maybe a shrug.

The good:
-The puzzles! There are some really excellent puzzles in this game that require a bit of lateral thinking, but even when I was stuck the solution never felt unfair.  For the most part the game lets you figure out the solutions without too many hints, which is refreshing.  
-Multiple playable characters.  The townsfolk react differently to different people, which is fun and adds an extra dimension to the puzzle solving.  It's also fairly easy to  move between different locations, so haiving the wrong person in the wrong screen isn't really a problem.
-The art and animations are really well done

The bad:
-The writing is a mixed bag.  The constant in-jokes and fourth wall breaking are really heavy handed - it's a steady stream of "nudge-nudge wink-wink" that gets to be obnoxious after an hour or so.  We get it.  We know who Ron Gilbert is, we know we're playing an adventure game (and if you don't, you aren't going to get the joke anyways).  I realise this is personal taste though and YMMV - if you love this sort of humour then you're in for a treat.
-The "plot twist" is telegraphed from a mile away and is pretty cliche - it also makes the mysteries you've been trying to solve up until that point irrelevant, and the ending feels rushed.
-The voice acting is wildly uneven.  I ended up turning it off and cranking up the text speed. 

If you love old-school adventure games and have played every game in the LucasArts catalogue multiple times, you've probably already bought the game.  If you're newer to the genre I'd suggest starting elsewhere.

31001157.review:

30999790.review: Recomendadisimo!!! Para quien jugo a los Monkey Island de los 90' es diversion y cariño asegurado. Tambien es una excelente entrada para que los jovenes entren a este mundo y vuelvan a esa epoca. Aun si fuera mas caro seria una excelente compra. Se nota mucho la madurez de Ron para el diseño general. No es un puro fanservice descarado tampoco, el juego tiene un peso propio que la verdad lo hace brillante. La variedad de personajes y lo que sus historias cuentan lo hacen muy interesante tambien. Eso es algo que se perdio durante estos 30 años (Con Guybursh, Many y demas) y la verdad que se agredece enormemente. Agregarle pluralidad en lugar de linealidad a una aventura grafica no es nada facil la verdad, y Ron lo hace perfectamente. Atentos con el final del juego en este punto. Yo lei que un aspecto negativo era su final abrupto, y es que no es asi; lo que sucede es que al meter varias historias pasa eso. Si vas derecho al "tema" principal y no estas al tanto de la seleccion de otros personajes, pues te comes sus historias. En resumen, compralo!!!!! Y roguemos por dios que Ron haga el verdadero Monkey Island 3. Mi GOTY del 2017 es este juego, no tengo ninguna duda.

30981492.review:
Ein geniales Text-/Grafik-Adventure im Retro-Point-and-Click-Stil. Wer Maniac Mansion mochte, wird das hier lieben. Es gibt viele Anspielung, man erinnert sich an alte Rätsel, und tatsächlich gab es in den alten Spielen Hinweise, die einem hier helfen. War das etwa alles so schon der Plan?

Leider ist nur der Text auf deutsch. Da ich das als sehr störend empfinde (englische Sprache, deutscher Text), habe ich ohne Untertitel und mit englischen Texten gespielt - das ganze wirkt dann stimmiger. Die Texte sind auch nicht schwer zu verstehen.

Der Retrostil lässt einen in alten Erinnerungen schwelgen und sieht trotzdem modern aus. Das haben die Entwickler sehr gut hinbekommen. Vielleicht lässt sich ja sogar der eine oder andere zu diesem Spiel hinreißen, der das aufkommende Internet nicht mehr mit Modems mitgemacht hat, und der keine Spiele von Datasette geladen hat. Man muss allerdings schon etwas mehr Geduld aufbringen, die Bedienung über eine Verbenleiste ist ja nun nicht unbedingt das, was man heute gewohnt ist. Aber lasst euch nicht davon abschrecken!

Bitte unbedingt dieses Spiel kaufen, damit eventuell ein weiteres Adventure rauskommt. Vielleicht kommt ja sogar noch deutsche Sprachausgabe. Dann spiele ich es erneut durch, und diesmal mit Toilettenpapier hinten... Auch wenn das so nicht gehört.

Ich kann es jedem empfehlen, der sich gern an die alte Zeit zurück erinnert. Also greift zu. Für rund 20€ wird man locker 15-20 Stunden unterhalten, wenn man alles erkundet und auch die nicht lösungsrelevanten Gimmicks und Überraschungen findet.

PS: Ich glaube, ich muss mal wieder ein paar Spiele aus dem DOS-Emulator ausgraben...

30979916.review:
Pros:
[list][*]Nice pixelart with fancy, modern lighting and shaders sprinkled in. The backgrounds in particular look really nice. Overall, the graphics looks like a LucasArts adventure game made today if they were completely oblivious to the introduction of 3D graphics and high resolution monitors. In other words, it's how graphics should have evolved.
[*]Since it was a low budget game, I expected the duration to be short, but it ended up being fairly lengthy.
[*]Though I don't think it comes close to games like Monkey Island 2 and Day of the Tentacle, the dialogue is pretty well written. What drags it down is an unnecessary barrage of references, and some character quirks which become tiring after 5 minutes. *bleep*-a-reno indeed.
[*]Verbs! Dialogue trees! Inventory with tons of items to pick up! It's extremely old-school mechnically but works very well. A reminder that a lot of modern adventures have gone a bit too far with streamlining and simplifying the genre.[/list]

Cons:
[list][*]Story has an intriguing start, but the direction it goes in feels very arbitrary and the ending especially is very lackluster.
[*]Not many interesting characters, and the playable characters in particular feel very one-sided and uninteresting. Please don't let make me play as that *beeping* clown again.
[*]The act structure works against the game. The entire game takes place in the same area but the game arbitrarily denies you access to certain rooms until you hit certain story points, so many puzzles you can only half-way finish until you finish up other puzzles first (and it's not always apparent which sequence of puzzles the game wants you to work towards). The structure feels like a weird mix of Maniac Mansion and Monkey Island 1 when it should have gone all in with one of the styles.
[*]The multiple playable characters feel like an extremely underused feature. Most of the playable characters could have been removed with minimal effect on puzzles, dialogue, and story. Especially the clown. Oh, why is the clown there. Just please let me buy some DLC which removes the clown from the game.[/list]

Despite the many flaws I enjoyed the game overall, and I hope the developer continues making more adventure games. If you're a die-hard LucasArts fan this game is a very easy recommendation.

30976089.review:
Un muerto ha aparecido en la pequeña ciudad de Thimbleweed Park, y los agentes Ray y Reyes, del FBI, son los encargados de dar con el perpetrador de turno. “Un cuerpo muerto es el menor de tus problemas” es el eslogan del juego, y no podría ser más cierto. El asesinato en cuestión queda relegado a un segundo plano con una rapidez tremenda, y el auténtico misterio pasa a ser la fábrica de almohadas, abandonada tras la reciente muerte del respetado magnate de la industria almohadística local.

Thimbleweed Park es prácticamente una aventura antigua adaptada a tiempos modernos. Volvemos, cómo no, a la interfaz SCUMM, considerada un retraso ortopédico por unos y una reliquia siempre bienvenida por otros (entre los que me incluyo), pero con algunos retoques; haciendo click derecho sobre un objeto siempre se elegirá la opción más lógica (pero no necesariamente correcta) y las diferentes acciones tienen atajos de teclado personalizables. 

Volvemos a esos puzles de probar a usar las decenas de objetos de tu inventario, pero con un nivel de lógica lunar mucho menor. Los puzles en Thimbleweed Park son bastante lógicos. Relativamente. Desde luego no son el bigote de Gabriel Knight 3. El diseño del juego es bastante abierto, y hay muchos puzles que se pueden resolver al principio del juego, o prácticamente al final del mismo. Las primeras horas son bastante directas, hasta que desbloqueas a todos los personajes jugables y las posibilidades y combinaciones se disparan. De las 19 horas que necesité para pasarme el juego, aproximadamente 5 son de quedarme trabado. Pero no hay nada que digas “esto necesita guía sí o sí”. No hay que usar monos como llave inglesa.

En esta investigación, además de a los dos agentes, podremos controlar a otros tres personajes: Delores (literalmente una versión joven de Ron Gilbert pasada por la regla 63), Ransome (un payaso malhablado cuyo show consiste en insultar al público) y Franklin (el cobardica padre de Delores, que quiere usar la fábrica de almohadas para abrir una línea de ositos de peluche). El principal objetivo de todos estos personajes, por un motivo u otro, es entrar en la fábrica de almohadas. Y aquí es donde viene uno de los defectos del juego: no hay suficiente interacción narrativa entre los personajes. Salvo por Delores y Franklin, el resto de personajes no se conocen de nada, y el juego requiere constantemente intercambiar objetos entre ellos, o usar a varios para resolver un puzle único. Más que un grupo con un objetivo común es un grupo de individuos resolviendo cachos de puzles relacionados cada uno por su cuenta. ¿Es una queja muy autista? Quizás. Pero siento que con simplemente añadir algunos diálogos se hubiera podido justificar mejor la interacción entre el quinteto.

Durante una de las sesiones de brainstorming de Maniac Mansion, a Gary Winnick y Ron Gilbert se les ocurrió un puzle que utilizase uno de los anillos aislantes que provocaron la tragedia del Challenger. Decidieron no incluirlo por ser “too soon”. Treinta años después, Thimbleweed Park incluye un chiste sobre dicho anillo. Y uno de los personajes dice que es “too soon”. Porque Thimbleweed Park ocurre en 1987.

Creo que esto es un microcosmos de lo que ofrece el juego. Thimbleweed Park puede parecer una amalgama de referencias a aventuras gráficas sin ton ni son, pero hay algo más; tiene un claro carácter autobiográfico. Es un juego que se disfruta especialmente si se conoce a Ron Gilbert, sus juegos, su forma de ser y su forma de ver y vivir la industria del videojuego.

Decir que el juego tiene alguna que otro guiño sería quedarse cortísimo. El juego funciona en un extraño nivel de meta-continuidad con respecto a Maniac Mansion: Dave y Sandy son personajes interactuables, Bernard aparece mencionado y hasta Chuck, la planta, hace aparición en una mansión análoga a la del juego clásico. Hay referencias a Maniac Mansion, Zak Mckracken y Monkey Island a lo largo de todo el juego, hasta el punto en el que a mucha gente le resultarán más molestas que otra cosa. Si tu tolerancia al humor autorreferencial tiende a nula, este juego no es para ti.

Si este tipo de humor no te molesta, es muy fácil recomendar Thimbleweed Park. Si bien la recta final es muy divisiva (como lo fue en su época la de Monkey Island 2), el viaje para llegar hasta ella es uno que merece la pena recorrer. Es honestamente todo lo que se podría pedir del concepto de “aventura gráfica clásica”. 

Bueno, no. Se podría pedir más Elijah Wood.

30974647.review:
Why, yes, it's a worthwhile point and click adventure game that I didn't have to look up any hints for, so it's probably not difficult at all for genre folks. No mega-monkey excrement here.

The first 30 minutes are absolutely turgid with callbacks and in-jokes, and one'd be forgiven to think it's gonna stay on that level. They do tone it down.

On the Lucaslike sliding scale it's much closer to Maniac Mansion than Day of the Tentacle in about every respect, and that's a YMMV good thing. The soundtrack is maybe the single most notable part to clash with the package: It does the job, but it's basically a slow bass guitar riff all the way and there's nothing you're gonna remember in there. VA is prett-ty good, but it seems to divide opinions - but Reyes has a really cute accent. At first I was thinking about turning the VA off entirely and just taking in the text, but the whole thing grew on me.

You probably either hate or love the ending. It fits, though.

30974187.review:
Я бы ХОТЕЛ порекомендовать Thimbleweed Park всем, кого нарочитое ретро не отталкивает, и тем, кто любит чудные игры, в которых нужно подумать, но она застряла всеми конечностями в конце 80-х и гордится этим. Если вы не знаете почему хомяк сидит в микроволновке, что такое модем на 1200 бод или чем отличались квесты Sierra и LucasArts, то вы вряд ли проникнитесь от здешнего очарования, а если же на два из трёх вопроса вы знаете ответ, то приготовьтесь купаться в ностальгическом экстазе!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pLY2Rg6vh0g

Больше всего в Thimbleweed park мне нравится какая-то своя атмосфера. Тщательно созданная чудилами, которым нравятся похожие вещи. Я как зомби сидел первые часов 5 подряд и тихонечко радовался. Забавным и порой заковыристым диалогам, всем бесчисленным отсылкам, тут даже музыка хорошая, пиксельарт весь из себя такой приятный, а не тот что нынче моден среди инди-разработчиков. Хотя, всё было с точностью наоборот, именно они своими играми меня заставили любить такие шутки, такой подход. На мой взгляд это один из лучших ностальгических проектов за последнее время. Ни Тим Шейфер ни Джейн Дженсен, ни Эл Лоу, даже создатели нверхуда не смогли сделать, как раньше. Парни с андромеды так вообще всё ещё не разродились. А Гилберт и компания смогли, пусть и залезли немного глубже в прошлое, чем я привык. Концовка тут вообще блестящая! Я давненько так не хохотал. Словом, однозначно приятный проект для старпёров, как я.

30972331.review:
ok so i kickstarted this game and i was not dispointed but I do feel like this was made for a select audience. it reminded me of being a kid and playing maniac mansion and monkey island, though it was maybe slightly less engaging than the latter which is a shame since the first two monkey island games were pure magic. that said, this game really does capture old school adventure games perfectly, down to the sometimes maddenly random puzzles that are more arbitrarily mashing items together vs actual puzzles. i love how the kickstarters are integrated into the game (through the library, phone book, and ranom's swear jar), the graphics are great, the world is beautiful, the humor is good...that said, i don't like playing 5 characters, at times it felt cumbersome. some clearly have skillets that are necessary, but i would've preferred to have one character that i maintained an emotional attachment to and just run with them for 10 hours.  i'm curious to see the differences between hard and easy mode (i played on hard) just since that was never an option in the past though i can see it being a cool way for people who are first getting into the genre. i will say i thought the ending was both cool and kind of eh though, which i know is a contradiction but somehow it managed to both get me back into the game but also feel like a cop-out. just go with me on this one. 



so yeah, if you loved lucasarts and sierra games, you're gonna like this. is it the second coming of monkey island? sadly no, but that's not a bad thing, it's it's own thing and hopefully it will be the start of something new since so many people are so jazzed about it, it would be great to see a resurgence of the genre.

30970688.review:
Note: This Review is for Casual Mode
I remember when Thimbleweed Park was first announced several years ago, when all we had was a simple concept art of Agent Ray and Reyes. And now look at the masterpiece this game has become..

Thimbleweed Park is game that has two mysteries in one: figuring out a murder mystery and solving the mystery of the Pillow Factory Fire that occured before the events of the game. 

Ron Gilbert and Gary Winnick have done an amazing job with immersing players into the decrepit and spooky town of Thimbleweed Park. Oftentimes, I find myself getting the chills looking at the run down buildings. The graphics fit the game perfectly.

The soundtrack of Thimbleweed Park is also memorable. I find myself humming the game's theme song. The sound effects like opening and closing doors, hearing footsteps, and even the ambient environment noises like the wind blowing in the distance, crickets chirping at night, or a fire hydrant splashing water really add to environment, further immersing players into this world.

What really drives Thimbleweed Park foward are the characters. Agent Reyes and Agent Ray share a unique relationship with each other. Neither one trusts the other, but they choose to work together. Delores is the perfect programmer/nerd girl with a passion for following her dreams. Ransome the Clown is obnoxious and full of sarcastic remarks. Franklin the Ghost is depressing, but also adds an entire layer of puzzle solving an already amazing adventure game.

The gameplay in Thimbleweed Park takes a step back from modern adventure games and lets you do all the work in figuring out what to do in your environment. Playing this game makes me realize just how much modern adventure games hold our hands and silo us down a typical path. One of the things that I love is being able to test and experiment around with different commands. This usually pays off in very interesting or unexpected results. I found myself stuck in the game multiple times only to do something weird and solve the puzzle! I feel like a lot of the puzzles in this game are either predictably logical, or they require you to think about it from a different perspective to figure out. I was never stuck for too long, and having that "Ah ha!" moment was always worth it. I was able to finish Casual Mode in 12 hours. 

Perhaps one of the things that I enjoyed the most about Thimbleweed Park was the immersion itself. Never did I feel impatient on wanting to progress the plot further. Sometimes, I would just sit in the cafe and take in the welcoming environment. Other times, I would sit in the Edmund library and just peruse the tons of books that the game has to offer. There's just so much in this tiny world worth exploring, that I never felt bored expecting something more to do. Even as something as little as revisitng areas to look for collectable specks of dust. Yes! Specks of dust!

Gripes. There were a few things that did make Thimbleweed Park frustrating to play. Thankfully, there wasn't too much, but I do need to address them:

- Some characters in the game share task lists. This isn't a problem, but if you have multiple playable characters, it can be annoying having to make sure both characters meet up to give each other items. It immediately reminded me of Gilbert's The Cave game, where characters had to constantly backtrack to give each other items. The map item resolves problem pretty fast.

- At some points in the game, I found that the Part I was in prevented certain tasks from being completed. For example, Franklin's task list had goals that he needed to accomplish, but I had to wait until I was in a later part of the story to accomplish that specific task. Don't include the task in that part of the story until it's needed. It would have saved me a lot of time! 

- I found it quite strange that playable characters couldn't communicate with each other. If Agent Reyes and Agent Rey are in the same room, why can't there be some conversation topics that they can share between themselves? Even if it doesn't necessarily pertain to the plot. Another example of this is when Agent Rey goes to the Edmund Mansion to speak to Delores, but Delores dismisses her. Agent Rey never has a future conversation with Delores. I know that these characters are all on their own storylines, but the only real cohesion between them was at the very end of the game. Maybe this was on purpose? Perhaps we are supposed to feel this disconnect between the characters, because they are all operating on selfish gains? And the very end of the game causes all of them to work together? I don't know. I can't really peg this as a gripe -- maybe I was just expecting something else. 

Overall, Thimbleweed Park was a joy to play. Playing the game felt like I was binging a Netflix show. Ron Gilbert did a fantastic job grabbing players into this world and holding them tight in figuring out the mysteries. Even after finishing the game, I still find myself excited to go back and play the Hard Mode, ready to check out all the puzzles and different locations I missed from my first playthrough. 

I highly reccomend this game to people that love adventure games; you are in for a welcoming and truly wonderful treat.

30969768.review:
Thimbleweed Park marks the return of Ron Gilbert and Gary Winnick to classic "point and click" adventure games. It was funded on Kickstarter in 2014 and raised around $626,000, resulting in the game not only being funded but also reaching a number of stretch goals including voice acting and mobile ports.
I backed this game on Kickstarter and recieved a Steam key when the game launched.
 
[h1]Premise[/h1]
The game takes place in 1987 in a small town called Thimbleweed Park. There, a body was found and two FBI agents - Angela Ray and Junior Agent Antonio Reyes - are dispatched to investigate the murder. However, not only does the Sheriff try to prevent them from solving the case, they also find out that some strange things are happening in Thimbleweed Park...

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
Thimbleweed Park features a style similar to the ones seen in older [strike]LucasArts[/strike] MmucasFlemm games. But, instead of relying on "soft" edges like in Monkey Island 2, the art is crisp and detailed, utilizing an neat color palette across the various areas of the game. Some areas even make use of parallax scrolling, emulating "depth" where none exist.
The level of detail seen in the background art is quite fantastic. Many signs across town are actually legible, individual leaves are visible, fireflies are buzzing around, tufts of grass are moving in the wind, broken lights are flickering...the list goes on.
The characters are even more resemblant of Maniac Mansion than the backgrounds, mainly because their heads are larger than one would expect, allowing for neat facial expressions despite the technically "low" resolution of the character sprites. As a little extra, there's even some form of dynamic lighting being applied to the character sprites, making them seem more "in place" when walking past lights.

Overall, I can't find anything wrong with the visuals, although the big-headed characters might be off-putting to some people.


[h1]Sound[/h1]
Honestly, I didn't have any expectations when it came to sound. In fact, I completely forgot that the game recieved voice acting, which was a nice surprise when I started playing.
The music fits the theme of the game very well, being reminiscent of film noir - dark, slow and moody.
Thimbleweed Park also utilizes quite a few ambient sounds, including but not limited to wind rustling, grills chirping, dogs barking and so on. None of it ever seemed out of place.
And while the voice actors overall do a great job, I'm not entirely satisfied with the audio quality. I assume it's deliberate, but the voice acting sounds like it's played back from a cassette tape - one that has been used quite a bit. The audio is not "slurring" but the heights aren't as crisp as they could/should be. Again, it might be deliberate but I'm not too fond of it.

[h1]Writing[/h1]
The game is able to keep the tension while at the same time being pretty much littered with dry jokes that very much remind me of Gilberts and Winnicks previous works. It made me laugh out loud several times - now, that may seem like a pointless thing to mention but it's actually quite difficult for games to make me laugh.
Thimbleweed Park also drops quite a few references, not only about older LucasArts games but about adventure game tropes in general. It doesn't take itself too seriously which works very well.
I don't want to go into much detail in order to avoid spoilers, but the story might be the only somewhat polarizing part of this game. But I did find it very enjoyable.

[h1]Puzzles[/h1]
People looking for a classic point and click adventure experience will enjoy this game. On "hard mode" (which is more like normal mode) the game requires you to think outside the box very often, but without relying on blatant moon logic. And there are loads of red herrings that you can pick up. You *will* get stuck on hard mode but you can do it. Try to not look up a walkthrough, okay?
Casual mode is a very nice addition. In that mode, roughly half of the puzzles in the game are pretty much skipped, allowing beginners to enjoy the story and get through the game without getting stuck too often. A great way to make the game more accessible without compromising the original experience.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
A very good, super entertaining point and click adventure game that oozes charm and features a tremendous amount of puzzles, hilarious dialogue, diverse areas as well as likable and fun characters. The only drawbacks are (possibly deliberate) voice quality issues, some slightly unbalanced puzzles and a few questionable story decisions.

[b]8/10[/b]

30969488.review:
Your first five minutes:

A statement about socialized health care and it's importance
A statement eco-shaming people for throwing out trash
A dissertation on how to make a game the 'right' way by eliminating deaths and dead ends.

Seriously, if this is what Ron Gilbert has to turn to in order to voice his political and social opinions then I'm simply not interested.  I LOVED his earlier games, but his motivations are just TOO heavy handed in the dialogue, and as others have mentioned, the sheer amount of fourth wall shenanigans wears thin fast, leaving you with an indie game that, were it not for Ron Gilbert and Gary Winnick's involvement, likely would be received much more poorly.

Half the dialogue seems to be trying to bank on earlier games he worked on with callback after callback, reference after reference, and frankly, it plays out as desperate rather than nostalgiac.

I just can't recommend a game with so much soapboxing and back-slapping in it.  An entertainment title is NOT the place for it.

I ended up having to go to Reddit for help a few times and the solution always seemed obvious in retrospect. I could see this game being a tough sell for someone who didn't grow up with the genre, but anyone who has fond memories of Gilbert's catalogue is likely to enjoy the 12ish hours this game takes to play.
