30964930.review:
Thimbleweed Park is a masterpiece of puzzle design. Many people think the adventure genre covers any game that combines a story with any old kinds of puzzles, but I have never believed that. A true adventure game entails puzzle-solving through deductive reasoning from the premises provided by the story and gameworld. This game does exactly that, only that, and brilliantly. Every puzzle is organic and can be solved by following the story and thoroughly exploring the gameworld. Here there are no non-contextual puzzles, no minigames, no moon logic. 

The story is also terrific, so long as you take to heart this line from the game's description: "In a town like Thimbleweed Park, a dead body is the least of your problems." Not every detail gets wrapped up into a little box with a bow on top. If you need that kind of complete closure, then you might conclude, illegitimately, that the story is flawed. It is not. The story is something anyone with the ability to embrace nonconformity will truly relish.

The only "negative" I noticed is that getting to the main menu requires an odd key-combo rather than ESC, but, you know, see above re: nonconformity. ;-)

30962282.review:
Thimbleweed Park is a love letter towards players from the golden age of adventure games back in the day. Highly recommended for gamers who used to play the Lucasfilm games in the eighties and early nineties or those who are discovering these old games with retro gaming. Lots of references (maybe too much) to those games as well.

Maybe a bit less recommended to those gamers who want everything quick and easy  (although I did not try out the easy mode myself yet). I do not want to go into spoilers, but one good thing for example is that by switching to multiple characters you can keep things going without getting stuck into one place for long.

Great retro style graphics which can probably run on older machines too, audio is okay, characters maybe not so lovable, plot may be better (although some silly things may be intentional), but puzzles are great. And overall a great achievement.

Conclusion: I certainly hope this is the start of a comeback for more adventure games. A must have!

I did like being able to switch between characters but it was weird that they would only have conversations with each other during cutscenes. The rest of the time they just stood around in silence. I feel like the positive reviews are more because of the genre than the game. Had it come out during the heyday of point-and-click games, I think it would have been seen as average. Is it worth £15? I think that depends on whether you're a fan of the genre. If you aren't, this won't change your mind. If you are, it will remind you of better times. 30950822.review:
This is a point and click adventure that feels just like a classic LucasArts game. Which is no surprise of course, since the project is headed by Ron Gilbert, the Monkey Island and Maniac Mansion creator. 

What surprised me the most is that even though I didn't find the game very funny, it didn't hurt my experience at all! It's instead quite charming and has more than a few heart warming moments. The puzzles are just the right level of difficulty on Hard for seasoned adventure gamers. And for newcomers there is a Casual mode that makes things less frustrating. Another thing that surprised me is that this is not a small adventure game, it's really long but I never got bored! I replayed Monkey Island 1 & 2 recently and none of them are longer than ten hours. Here I finished in at about 25 hours (exploring mostly everything) and even with a walkthrough I don't think I would have finished it in under 15 hours. There is lots of dialogue too good to skip through and there are many beautiful locations to explore. 

Something that did annoy me in the beginning is the constant fourth wall breaking. Characters make many comments about being in a game, that you don't have to save often like in Sierra adventures and so on. The longer I played, the more I liked these things though.

Overall I really recommend this game. The old adventure game magic is here in spades.

I was a little sceptical when i first heard about TWP and followed the Team on facebok and twitter. I really loved the screenshots i saw. The pixel art is really art here. When the game came out, I instantly bought it.

In my opinion, it is one of the best point and click adventures i have ever played. The characters are unique and fun, the voice acting is great and the soundtrack is a perfect mixture between oldschool point and click music and quite modern music. I mentioned the graphics before, i admire the pixel art.

If you like to solve puzzles, this game may be just your thing. If you dont like to solve puzzles, maybe you should not buy it. The easy mode is just boring to play for an point and click adventurer, and if youre not into story and puzzles, you may not be interested in this type of game at all, so better dont bother.
But if youre up for a bit of a challange, and like it, when the solution is not always easy to find, you will love this game. The references to all the old games and characters is a nostalgic flashback and brings back good old memories. Ron Gilbert just knows how to make games. Please sir, continue to make games like TWP and make me happy again.

Secondly I was a bit disappointed that my main characters could not talk to each other. It is a bit strange at the beginning or first half of the game when one main character is missing for short/some time and comes back and the other main character doesn't react in any way. However this is just nit-picking and some healthy scepticism I developed about recent Kickstarter adventures games. *cough* 2+ million $ *cough*. Ha! With more time into the game and finally having finished it on normal/hard mode, they really did a great job here. It definitely is a classic graphic adventure game! It definitely feels and play like a SCUMM game! Yes!

[b]+[/b] 99% Great German translation by Boris "Doc Bobo" Schneider-Johne! I played my first playthrough with all Retro options, no voice, and German texts. Just like the first time I played Monkey Island when I was 8-10 yrs old or so.  It felt like the good old days! Some minor tiny mistakes I found like sometimes "das", where it has to be "dass", or missing comma etc. But I'm no grammar nazi. No, I'm really not. (NO!) Translation is great, witty and funny. However very small mistakes or 1-2 missing letters at end of words however stretch through the entire game. Really tiny and only if you look closely. When you think about that Boris did the whole translation for just 1 (one) USD, this translation is his best and gets a 11/10 from me!

[b]+[/b] If you use no hints you can get 15-20 hours out of this game! I needed 22 hours. But I wanted to see everything, every line. Still haven't.

[b]+[/b] For a classic adventure game it is all I ever wanted. Having played all the old adventures with walkthroughs (shame on me). This is the first real graphic adventure game I played through all by myself. It's perhaps only slightly easier than the old ones like Monkey Island. But never too easy or cheap. Clever good puzzles, with great difficulty. 

[b]Thimbleweed Park™ is a love letter to the old classic graphic adventures and it really is one of its kind.
Verdict: STRONGLY RECOMMENDED.[/b]

PS: I'm a 75$ backer. Would back again. 9.0/10

30937065.review:
고전 어드벤처 게임의 영광을 완벽하게 재현하다!

루카스아츠를 필두로 한 고전 어드벤처의 느낌을 아주 잘 살려낸 게임이다. 그 시절 게임이 떠오르는 레트로풍 그래픽과 인터페이스가 인상적이다. 누군가에게 게임 화면만 보여주고 "이거 사실 80년대 게임이야!" 라고 해도 믿을 정도. 그래도 폰트가 보다 깔끔해지고 음악도 현대풍이며 캐릭터 이동에 있어 '달리기'를 지원하는 등, 고전 어드벤처와는 다르게 한 층 편해진 게임플레이를 보인다. 고전 게임의 느낌과 현 시대에 맞는 게임플레이가 적절히 조화된, 레트로의 미덕을 완벽히 준주하는 게임인 것이다.

게임을 시작할 때 캐주얼 난이도와 하드 난이도를 고를 수 있는데, 난이도 간의 격차가 꽤 크다. 단순히 힌트 좀 주고 안 주고의 차이가 아니라 해야 할 것들이 배로 늘어난다. 게임의 플레이타임이 체감상 1.5배 정도 늘어난다고 보면 된다. 그래서 반대로 하드 모드를 한 번 클리어하고 캐주얼 모드를 다시 해보면 허무할 정도로 게임이 짧고 단조롭게 느껴진다. 이런 클래식 어드벤처류가 익숙하다면 하드를 고르고, 그게 아니라 체험만 간단히 해보고 싶다면 주저없이 캐주얼로 골라서 플레이하길 추천한다.

게임 전반에 보이는 등장인물들 간의 유쾌한 입담과 차고 넘치는 패러디, 그리고 짜임새 있는 줄거리가 매우 돋보인다. 주연부터 조연들까지 캐릭터들의 개성도 충만하며, 줄거리의 구성이 아주 좋아 잠시도 쉬어갈 틈이 없다. (특히 욕쟁이 광대 랜섬은 주연 치고는 비중이 조금 적지만 존재감 하나만큼은 정말 압도적이다. *삐이이이*) 줄거리의 설득력과 몰입도가 상당한 게임이다. 영어가 어느 정도 가능하다면 단 한 번의 대사 스킵 없이 모든 대화를 재밌게 즐길 수 있을 것이다. 

게임이 진행되는 과정에서 충격적인 설정과 전개가 자주 보인다. 전반적인 분위기 자체가 유쾌하고 나사빠진 듯이 진행되서 그렇지 지금 시점에서 봐도 꽤나 파격적인 설정들이다. 엔딩 역시 (지금와서는 조금은 익숙해진 클리셰가 되긴 했지만) 꽤나 충격적인 결말을 선보인다. 조금은 허무하면서도 여운이 꽤나 남는 엔딩이다. 적어도 후회나 자괴감이 드는 엔딩은 아니다.

이건 단점이라기보단 장르상의 한계일텐데, 팀블위드 파크라는 게임 자체가 정말 많이 편하긴 해도 근본적으로는 조금 불편함을 감수해야 하는 장르이다보니 현시대에 플레이하기엔 불편하게 느껴지는 점이 여전히 많다. 게임 상에서 단축키가 존재한다는 걸 제대로 알려주지 않는 듯 한데, 이 단축키를 활용하지 않는다면 각 명령어들 활용하는 게 꽤나 번거롭게 느껴진다. 게다가 자신이 모든 걸 직접 찾아서 진행해야 하는, 탐색과 수색(나쁘게 말하자면 맨땅에 헤딩, 허공에 삽질)이 극대화된 게임이다보니 공략이 없다면 진행이 매우 어렵게 느껴진다. 이것에 익숙하지 않다면 플레이타임이 정말 극단적으로 늘어날 수도 있다.

.
.
.

"어느날 당신이 먼지가 쌓인 낡은 서랍장을 열었는데 거기서 한번도 플레이해보지 않은 루카스아츠 어드벤처 게임을 발견한 기분을 주겠다." 

팀블위드 제작진이 처음 게임의 제작을 발표했을 때 했던 말이다. 그리고 팀블위드 파크는 저 문구를 아주 정확하고 완벽하게 충족시키는 게임이다.

http://blog.naver.com/kitpage/220975921837

30929455.review:
Normalmente muy pocos juegos suelo comprarlos el día de su lanzamiento, tienen que interesarme mucho, y este era el caso, además de un precio totalmente adsequible por el que no me arrepiento nada.

Soy jugador de aventuras gráficas desde 1994 cuando apenas tenia 7 añitos, me crie con los maniac mansion, monkey island, Indiana Jones, sam y max, aventuras de sierra, etc... Por lo que este proyecto llevaba siguiendolo desde hace un largo tiempo. Para aquellos amantes de las aventuras gráficas este juego no decepciona nada, y su aspecto retro lo hace revalorizarse mucho más.

El juego se considera el sucesor espiritual de Maniac Mansión, aventura gráfica en la que manejabamos 3 personajes (algunos con habilidades unicas) en una casa sin mucho movimiento de escenarios (a diferencia de otras aventuras gráficas donde vas avanzando la historia), este juego imita en parte al Maniac Mansión, desarrollandose en un pequeño pueblo y sus inmediaciones (aunque no tienes un acceso completo desde el principio y se va desbloqueando según avanzas).  

La historia comienza con un asesinato cerca de Thimbleweed Park, donde dos detectives (que recuerdan a Mulder y Scully de Expediente X), Reyes y Ray deben investigarlo, pero ambos esconden otras motivaciones que le llevan aquel pueblo.  El juego tiene un gran sentido del humor (no es un juego precisamente serio) y esta lleno de easter eggs relacionados con Maniac Mansion, Monkey Island y en menor medida indiana Jones y la última cruzada.

El juego al igual que ocurrio con el monkey island 2 y 3, tiene dos modos, uno sencillo y otro dificil donde los puzzles son mucho más sencillos, mi consejo personal es que jugueis mejor directamente el dificil ya que se van a ver muchas más cosas que simplemente el sencillo, si hay algun  momento que no avanzais podeis consultarme por privado o seguro que poco a poco ya habria videoguias en youtube.

Recomendado para los amantes de las aventuras Gráficas.

30928350.review:
I'd like to recommend the game, but it has a LOT of usability issues that make playing the game a chore, and in it's current state it is diffucult for me to recommend it. Maybe if the devs spend enough time fixing these issues it's playable and I can change this review.

The devs really have spent too much time reminiscing about what was so good about the good old days, and too little learning about how modern point & clicks have evolved.

Here's my long list of complaints, some of them bigger, some of them smaller, but the sheer number of them is the most worrying thing. Mostly they are usability issues, things making the game more clumsy and annoying to play, but there are a few issues with the game writing, voice acting, etc. as well.

Roughly in order of most to least annoying:

---

It feels like the game regularly fights against you, you know what you should be doing, but the game just refuses to acknowledge you're even trying the right thing. Then it turns out some really uninteresting detail to the player is the key to progressing.

Seriously, this is bad. The *ESC* key does not open the menu. Ctrl+O does. This has to be a bad, sick joke. Right? Ha ha, april fools is gone. Fix this. Now.

The game depends on you retrying the same thing multiple times - INCREDIBLY bad adventure game design.

You have to open each and every drawer separately, to the point where you just repeatedly hear "Nothing." and go on autopilot, and fail to notice that some of them actually had contents in them.

All machines supposedly have a speech interface (you can TALK to them), except the only one you really want to use. It doesn't seem to be possible to use the machine until you need it, even though you can find it, and only after you need it can you activate it using the USE verb.

The game seems to make jokes about pixel hunting by having "specks of dust" littered around, and then uses pixel hunting as an actual necessary mechanic.

At one point you have to go through *10* identical scenes in order to find the one with the thing you need. There is no reason given for this, or any hint as to where you might find your thing, or even a reason for you to go searching, you just have to do it to progress.

Most of the time the characters are not dumb enough to e.g. require you to USE stairs, you just walk to them, but there is *ONE* exception where the game requires you to use the USE verb at the bottom of the stairs to climb them. You aren't even required to activate the verb to get back down. These are not the first stairs you encounter.

There are regularly sound volume issues, some sounds are very loud, sometimes they play really quiet.

There are multiple long winded scenes that seem to have been made just to waste your time. Long sections of manual walking with exactly NOTHING to interact with or anything to see. It's like the devs just had a brainstorming session about how to waste the most player's time.

The game backseat games itself with "I should really be ..." -timed dialog lines, worst of all it's done when the player is not stuck. Quickly becomes incredibly irritating.

Characters regularly interrupt each other and themselves with timed dialog lines. You try to click on something and the text + speech gets cancelled by something you really don't care at all about.

The default action for interacting with items is often intuitively "wrong", not what you'd expect or want to do.

You have to remember various things people say or you read to pick the correct choice in dialog trees, OR you might even have to just guess them (codes, model numbers, teen slang, ...).

The journal (notebook) system is confusing - different people's notebooks have mostly identical content, but some of it is different so you always have to check what everyone wrote in their notebook, and sometimes the UI controls for them are different. Things not being said or done appear only in the notebook.

Sometimes there are timed animations, e.g. a few moments after exiting an elevator the doors close. During this animation the game stops responding to your controls and even hides the cursor.

Interactable things regularly get hidden behind foreground graphics, there can literally be a door behind a giant pillar blocking your view.

Verbs sometimes just deactivate if you don't use them quickly enough.

The area edges are poorly highlighted on the cursor, easy to miss the highlight completely when moving the cursor slightly past the edge.

The characters regularly walk the wrong way and have other odd path finding issues when you're just walking on a straight line. They often complain "I can't reach that" when trying to click on an exit.

The game is made in a retro style, which is cool, but in many parts they've made it "worse than retro". E.g. even back in the early 90s the point & click games with lots of verbs had keyboard shortcuts to activate them so it wouldn't be so clumsy, Thimbleweed Park does not. You have to click on the verb every time you want to do something, which is really annoying to an adventure game veteran like myself for whom pressing P for pickup is in the backbone.

With text + voice enabled, the dialog often continues unexpectedly - you first see a few words, and when you hear the guy finishing on that you click on the next thing but he surprisingly had more things to say. More text fits on screen, so it could've been there, or they could have a "..." indicator or something for when they are going to continue.

Text in dialog mode doesn't wrap when it reaches the edge of the screen, but scrolls horizontally when you hover over it. I'd of course want to see all of the text at once.

Some of the few keyboard shortcuts the game does have stop working if you have caps-lock on, even the one on the "."-key.

It seems the writing sometimes contradicts itself, e.g. a guy mentions 3 machines, and then speaks of "the 4 machines", or a salesperson asking for a "2 character code" for a part, and then you find a 3 character code for a part of that type.

A good modern point & click should have an easy key to highlight all interactable items on screen.

Scroll-wheel doesn't work for browsing through the inventory.

Sometimes the voice actors read the text you click on in dialog mode, other times they don't. It's inconsistent.

One of your characters (an agent) keeps telling everyone to not leave town for no reason, which seems odd.

The voice acting seems clumsy at times, and the voice directing is off - often the voice acting just doesn't seem to fit the intent of the lines.

The GIVE -verb does not recognize every person as a possible target.

30928315.review:
*Beep*ing brilliant game! Highly recommended!

I was worried that this game was going to show once and for all that adventures are an obsolete genre and they were merely taking advantage of gamers' nostalgia.

The game is as good as classic adventure games in most aspects and in some is even better. The great thing about it is that probably all the puzzles in it have logical solutions.

I'm glad to report that we needed such a game and this mix between macabre and humour was really missed. I feel like a teenager again!

Thanks Ron Gilbert for bringing back the magic of adventure games.

- GRAPHICS 9/10 - more style than a three-headed monkey wearing a hat
- SONIDO 9/10 - funny voices and cool music
- PLAYABILITY 9/10 - the magic is back! Only a few games manage to make you feel the same

The game is on the same level as Monkey Island or Day of the Tentacle, and I felt invested in the characters and transported to a very zany place called Thimbleweed Park.

Highly *beeping* recommended!



Juego *Bip*mente brillante! Altamente recomendado.

Estaba preocupado si este juego iba terminar de demostrar que los juegos de aventura ya están totalmente obsoletos y se estaban solamente aprovechando de la nostalgia de los fans.

El juego es igual de bueno que los juegos de aventuras clásicos y en algunos aspectos incluso mejor. Una de las cosas que hace mejor es que practicamente todos los puzzles tienen soluciones absolutamente lógicas.

Felizmente demostraron que hacía falta un juego como este y se echaba de menos esta mezcla entre lo humorístico y lo macabro. Me siento como un quinceañero de nuevo!

Gracias Ron Gilbert por traer de vuelta la magia de los juegos de aventura!

- GRÁFICOS 9/10 - más estilo que un mono de tres cabezas con sombrero
- SONIDO - 9/10 - voces divertidas en inglés y música cool
- JUGABILIDAD - 9/10 - la magia está de vuelta! Pocos juegos logran hacerte sentir del mismo modo

El juego es igual de bueno que Monkey Island y Day of the Tentacle y me sentí interesado en los personajes y transportado a un lugar muy loco llamado Thimbleweed Park.

Altamente *bip*mente recomendado!

30924877.review:
Thimbleweed Park es prácticamente una aventura gráfica perfecta. Ron Gilbert ha creado un título con olor a añejo que se convertirá por méritos propios en un clásico atemporal inmediato tanto si eres un aventurero experto como si eres un recién llegado. Si el juego hubiera salido en 1988 en vez de 2017, a día de hoy se le consideraría uno de los grandes de las aventuras gráficas igualmente.

Porque una de las mayores virtudes con las que ha dotado este genio de los videojuegos a este pueblo de nombre impronunciable de 80 habitantes es que dejará satisfecho tanto a los nostálgicos que disfrutaron en su día de Maniac Mansion o Monkey Island, como a aquellos que no tuvieron la suerte de poderlo disfrutar en su día, cuando las aventuras gráficas eran la punta de lanza en los juegos de PC.

Casi todo en este juego raya a un grandísimo nivel. Su argumento, sus puzles, su aspecto gráfico, su doblaje, su música o su humor está a un nivel altísimo. Desde el comienzo de la aventura se despertará nuestro interés y no decaerá hasta el final de los créditos.

Además, todo está en su justa medida. El juego tiene gran cantidad de cameos con otros juegos de Ron Gilbert, como Maniac Mansion o Monkey Island, o con el mundillo de las aventuras gráficas en general, pero no abusa de ello. Tiene la virtud de ofrecer siempre la justa medida de las cosas y siempre arrancar una sonrisa en el jugador, sin abusar y sin quedarse corto, y eso aunque parezca fácil es todo un mérito. Realmente creeremos estar jugando a una aventura gráfica desarrollada en los años 80.

En el juego, sin spoilers, nuestro papel será investigar un asesinato que se ha producido en un pueblucho de apenas 80 habitantes. Para ello tomaremos el control de dos agentes federales, cada uno con sus propios intereses como ya nos advierten desde el primer momento en su diario. ¿Cuáles? Eso no lo sabemos, y es la gracia del asunto. O parte de ella más concretamente.

Con posterioridad tendremos que controlar hasta un total de 5 personajes, y ahí todo se complica. Multitud de objetos, situaciones, y personalidades que harán que tengamos que escoger a uno u otro personaje para poder seguir avanzando en la historia e ir descubriendo los secretos que esconde cada uno de los lugares y personajes de esta aventura.

Lamentablemente, este punto de aventura coral es algo que no se ha ejecutado correctamente desde un punto de vista argumentativo, y muy probablemente sea el único fallo del juego. 

Verás, durante la aventura tendremos que compartir objetos entre los personajes, pero algunos personajes no se conocen de nada y no han hablado nunca entre ellos y, sin embargo, se ofrecen entre ellos los objetos de su inventario sin ningún tipo de problema. A nivel argumentativo es un fallo bastante grande, y le resta cierta credibilidad o consistencia a la historia general y el devenir de la aventura.

Más aún, algunos personajes no se llevan nada bien entre ellos, y no tienen problemas en regalarse objetos unos a otros. Esto resulta algo bastante artificial y poco natural. Hubiera sido muy fácil solucionar este punto con un par de líneas en la que acordaran  colaborar unos con otros en pos de un objetivo común. Pero no, esto no pasa. Y en algunos momentos provoca situaciones un tanto chocantes y poco creíbles.

Esta inconsistencia también afecta directamente a la resolución de algunos puzles, muchos de ellos de hecho. Por ejemplo, sin spoiler, un personaje descubre un número de teléfono en un sitio al que solo él puede acceder, y luego tendrás que seleccionar a otro que está en otra punta del mapa para que marque ese número de teléfono. Pero era imposible que lo supiera.

En cierta manera, y desde un punto de vista argumentativo, esto es totalmente ridículo. Ya que ese personaje no podía saber esa información bajo ningún concepto. Y eso hace que aunque los puzles estén muy bien ideados, algunas veces se le vean las costuras porque no están argumentativamente bien planteados. Es cierto que al final del juego podemos encontrar una cierta "lógica" a esto, pero aún así es algo que podría haberse solucionado de una manera más elegante con un planteamiento argumentativo más comprometido con la resolución de puzles.

Sin embargo, estos son los únicos puntos negativos del juego, el resto es realmente genial. Es una aventura gráfica bastante dura, en modo díficil, y avanzar será un "suplicio" a partir de un momento determinado de la aventura. Lo bueno es que estos puzles no son incoherentes, aunque alguno de ellos sean algo rebuscados, pero siempre lógicos.

Thimbleweed Park es una aventura que vale cada céntimo que gastes en ella. Es un juego redondo, con una grandísima calidad que te hará disfrutar cada una de las muchas horas que inviertas en él, y con total seguridad no te drefraudará en absoluto. Una compra más que obligada si eres un fan de las aventuras gráficas. :)

30919760.review:
I've always been a big fan  of adventure games and thought I'd recapture some of the feelings of playing Monkey Island or DOTT through this. I was mistaken. I have just finished the game. I have just spent 14 hours or so finishing this thing and I really don't know why I did it. It felt annoying after the first hour. Here's a brief list of pros and cons:

Pros
Nostalgia satisfaction
Sometimes clever references
Some of the art

CONS
The Story - The story is disjointed, makes little sense, is intertwined in a nonsensical way, and is ultimately uninteresting. There is no real connection between the characters, nothing that really drives them at least (except for a ghost and his daughter), yet they are all working towards the same goal through you. Some of this is explained at the end, but by the time you reach the end, you will no longer be interested in the story at all. Throughout the game I kept asking myself why I was playing this. What is the point? What is the goal of the game? You only find out what the point is in the last five minutes of gameplay making the entirety of the game rely on a feeling of nostalgia and a hope that, somehow, Ron Gilbert MUST have come up with something better than this and, perhaps, if you keep digging deeper you will find it.

In other adventure games you would at least have a sense of what the goal was, of what you were trying to achieve. For example, Guybrush Threepwood wants to become a pirate and later rescue Elaine; Indiana Jones wants to stop the Nazis from getting to Atlantis; Bernard, Hoagie and Loraine want to stop Purple Tentacle from taking over the world; Even Dave and the other two tuna heads want to rescue Sandy in Maniac Mansion. Thimbleweed Park, however, has no drive.

Furthermore, the ending is extremely disappointing. There is no resolution and is exclusively meta.

The Characters - The characters are flat. They have two-dimensional motivations. One of them is entirely propelled by expletives. There is no endearing character, no relatable one.

I don't know... I'll leave it here. I'm kind of tired of spending time thinking about this game. I don't recommend it, it has been an interesting but disappointing 14 hours.

30918777.review:
J'ai des sentiments très partagés envers ce jeu.
Pour être plus précis, je trouve que l'objectif affiché de "créer un point & clic qui soit à la hauteur des souvenirs des joueurs et non pas des jeux tels qu'ils étaient" est COMPLETEMENT raté.
En effet, le jeu est très bon, mais souffre exactement des même problèmes que ces ancètres :
- Difficulté mal gérée (les chapitres 4 et 7 sont nettement plus tordus que le reste du jeu)
- Chapitres mal définis (qui cause la difficulté plus ardue des chapitres 4 et 7 : on peut tout à fait se disperser et commencer à résoudre des énigmes dont la solution ne sera accesible que plus tard)
- Enigmes dont la difficulté a été augmentée artificiellemnent (Je pense à celles dont la solution ne dépend pas de l'inventivité du joueur mais se trouve dans un livre à aller chercher. On se retrouve dans un simulateur de marche)
- Et enfin, il y a des ruptures  de ton dans l'ambiance (Je pense à une énigme en particulier dont la solution digne d'un vieux Tex Avery dénote avec l'ambiance précédente du jeu, plus axée polar)

Tous ces (petits) défauts ont généré chez moi de la frustration, BEAUCOUP de frustration et malgré l'écriture prenante et drôle, j'ai fini par jurer devant mon PC d'une manière digne de Ransome.

Du coup, à ceux qui voudraient découvrir le genre, je recommenderai plutôt de taper dans les vieux trucs comme par exemple, Maniac mansion et Day of the tentacle, les premiers Monkey island, Indiana jones and the fate of atlantis, Loom, Les chevaliers de Baphomet, Sam & max : hit the road, les deux premiers the legend of Kyrandia, beneath a steel sky... ce ne sont pas les bons jeux qui manquent et certains sont même passés dans le monde du logiciel libre.

Es ist schwer Thimbleweed Park einer Gruppe von Adventure-Neulingen zu empfehlen. Dieses Spiel trieft vor Nostalgie und Anspielungen, was es zu einem großen Liebesbrief an die Fans von Lucasfilm Games macht. Und jeder der diese Zeit live mitgemacht hat (und mochte), kann eigentlich nichts falsch machen. Allerdings bezieht das Spiel genau daraus seinen Charme. I have just finished a play through of Thimbleweed Park on the harder difficulty. I was not a backer. I thought the game was fun without a walk through but I have played many adventure games. I think the designers nailed the difficulty. When I got stuck on one puzzle I would just roll on to trying to solve a different one. This is aided by a fairly open world most of the time. I got stuck fairly hard twice but had fun reading some of the many silly books in the library or listening to a few phone messages left by backers till I thought of something new to try. In one of the cases it helped to remember something new I had just got access to to help solve the puzzle.  

I would recommend this game to people who grew up with the old adventure games in the 1990's or are interested to see some of the magic some of those games had. Beware if you hate 4th wall breaking. This game does that a bunch. I for one loved this game!

30912930.review:
Thimbleweed Park is a challenging point & click adventure - it took me over 18 hours to finish it in hard mode.

The story is great and *beeeping* funny with lots of absurd puzzles and some unforeseen twists. There are a few weird situations where a puzzle seems to be a little incomplete (Betamax? Fridge in the sewers?), but that doesn't really affect the great experience you get from playing this game.

For fans of the original adventure games by Lucasfilm and Sierra, Thimbleweed Park is a must-play! The obvious references to some of the classic titles made me laugh really hard a couple of times :)

Overall, I would rank it in 3rd place right behind Monkey Island and Day of the Tentacle on my list of favourite point & click adventures.

Definitely worth the 20 bucks and the 2 years wait after backing it on kickstarter!

30912162.review:
I personally was rather disappointed by the game, even after just a few minutes. It's been a very long time since I played the classic LucasArts like Monkey Island, Indiana Jones, Day of the Tentacle etc... But what I've kept from these after all these years was the humor, the atmosphere, the consistency of the story. In TWP I've only smiled a few times, was rarely really pleasantly surprised at a situation, rarely thought that one puzzle or another was actually wicked. There's a lot of foul language that IMHO shouldn't have been used ("crap" and "dick", for instance, aren't words I expect to be hearing, and the *beep*ing for the even fouler phrases doesn't really help). The characters are rather bland -- it's actually really disappointing that, even though you can control up to 5 characters, in most cases most of them react exactly the same way to similar situations, have the same conversation lines, etc. Makes you wonder why they give you this many, also because the stories behind each character (and the role they play in the game) are rather weak and feel unfinished. I've fallen in love with Guybrush Threepwood, or even with the hamster in DotT, but none of the characters in TWP have given me that feeling. Honestly, the best moments in this game were when stumbling across one of the ((too?) many) references to one of the olden games, and the memories these brought back ("I'm selling these fine leather jackets" :-D must've missed the three-headed monkey though!). But there's nothing of the sort I will remember from TWP. After more than two years of hope that I would relive the emotions that kept awake up for hours so many years ago, I'm feeling very empty and dissatisfied. 

Oh, and actually making me *die* (yup, with a big fat "Game over" across the screen) after telling me that dying is not possible in this game, and having me play again through several loooooong hours (because, well, no auto-save...), was *not* a fun idea.

30911213.review:
This game is worth playing. If you enjoy puzzles, weird, secretive towns, and/or old-school adventure games, I would definitely recommend it. 

It was fun exploring the little town of Thimbleweed and learning what happened to put it in its current state. The apparent conspiracy going on also kept me interested throughout my playthrough. I wondered what was going on with the "signals" mentioned by the Pigeon Sisters and others. 

[b]Here's a short look. I don't think there are any open spoilers below really, but proceed with caution? [/b]

[b] Pros:[/b] 
-Fun puzzles, just challenging enough, not too nonsensical.
-An interesting setting and premise. 
-Likeable characters (even Ransome, at least it was fun playing him). 
-Great soundtrack and nice, retro graphics. 
-Entertaining jokes. 
-I left feeling sad that my time with the main characters had ended.

[b]Cons:[/b] 
-Many NPCs seem flat (har har) and static not providing much interaction. 
-The ending may be disappointing or unsatisfying to some. 
-There are also plot inconsistencies via comments made by characters that I noticed. I won't mention them here, because they were kind of frustrating when I was trying to get into the game. If you don't notice them, that's for the best. They were minor things, but still. 

Alright, here's the essay I accidentally wrote:

I was really looking forward to this, and my playthrough just revealed so much untapped potential. It felt very flat in some ways, like my interactions with NPCs seemed to be lacking depth. I know you have to carefully consider what lines you want characters to say because they have to be recorded, but... I would have loved to seen more. More from Madam Morena, who barely seemed to feature at all. More from the Pizza guy (Chet, I think?)

Maybe I'm just being greedy. I did love the little touches, and most of the jokes, the call-backs. There were moments that made me laugh pretty hard. Think [spoiler] Franklin trying to be "hip." [/spoiler]

I went in with high expectations, but I also went in wanting to love this game with every fibre of my being. I watched the process of it being made and just knew it was going to be something special. And it is. It's definitely unusual. 

But like others have said, I felt the ending was a cop-out. Maybe that's in the tradition of similar mystery/sci-fi/x-files-esque media? Just like Twin Peaks, really.

Honestly, I almost wish you had been able to choose one character at the beginning and then stick with them. Or at least talk to the others. I wanted to see Delores interact with the agents, Ransom, etc., which never really happened. 

Thinking about it, I just wish the game would developed the conspiracies a little better. I know there are only so many avenues you can take with a plot like this, but by the end it hardly seemed like Ray and Reyes, the original characters from the Kickstarter, mattered at all by the end. It almost seemed like two games spliced together. One with the agents, and one with Dolores where the agents are just vessels to move items around and help with puzzles. (Sorry, Reyes. I still love you.)

Either way, I would play it again. I really hope it makes enough money for them to produce more and better games. The talent is there! Also, I wouldn't mind seeing Dolores again. She was a lovely character.

30906479.review:
This is a complicated game to review.  I did enjoy it.  It was more than long enough to justify the price.  It definitely felt like a good balance of oldschool mechanics and modern (superior) adventure game conventions.  Not particularly atmospheric in terms of graphics or music, but it more than gets the job done.  The characters were more interesting than I expected.

But there are problems here, particularly with the ending.  The ending breaks the fourth wall more dramatically than anything I can recall having seen before.  That's more or less fine, but it completely takes the place of a proper ending, which the game then, simply, lacks.  This is frustrating because, to make it that far, you have to really keep the goals and objectives of all five characters in mind and play to resolve them.  As a (somewhat spoiler-y) example, [spoiler]the only "resolution" which REALLY occurs is an arrest to wrap up the murder case the plot opens with.[/spoiler]  That occurs halfway through the game, and, just in case you happened to find at least that bit satisfying, the game eventually makes it clear that all you were really doing there was [spoiler]helping the villain frame the wrong guy.[/spoiler]  Further, it's possible (if not extremely likely) that you'll simply complete the game with the character who's most obviously making progress first, which will then cause the game to end without any resolution for the other four characters at all.  This seems fine at first -- the ending isn't entirely unpleasant -- but it sneaks up on you later.  "Wait.  There was no ending, really.  It's like they just tried to ship the game on time by not making one, and just repurposed what was originally intended to be an easter egg to stand in for one."

Aside from that, there are things that the game does well.  It makes very good use of the "multiple characters" puzzle mechanic (even if it frequently does so despite there being NO WAY these characters could even be aware enough of each other's problems to work together in the first place).  It's often goofily funny, which, coming from me, is high praise indeed, because my sense of humor usually has different preferences.  Puzzle logic is thoroughly sensible, even in cases where the puzzles themselves are kinda not.  Making progress after being stuck for a bit feels really rewarding.

All in all, a good experience.  You will likely want to go back and play it again because you're annoyed with it -- an odd, mixed statement of praise, but praise nonetheless.

30900483.review:
I've played plenty of games on steam but Thimbleweed Park is the first game I decided to review. 

TL;DR 11/10 would collect dust specks and watch a cursed clown apply anti-itch lotion inside his pants again.

Ron Gilbert did an amazing work of bringing back the classic and making it still fresh and enjoyable. Being a big fan of Lucasfilm, Lucasart and especially Ron Gilbert's work, I fell completely in love with this game. The 9 hours of gameplay in hard mode (I'm a seasoned adventure game player) were perfect and I loved every single minute of it. The puzzles are fun, there's plenty of stupid puns, metagaming, the pixel art is stunning and overall this is the best adventure game I played in the last 20 years.

Should you buy this game? If you love adventure games, yes. If you played Monkey Island, Day of The Tentacle, Maniac Mansion or any other Ron Gilbert's game, definitely yes! You will love it. And if you have no idea of what I'm talking about? Hell yeah. You could discover a whole new world of gaming, and if you hate it... well you will have the gratitude of all the people who love it for supporting the devs and giving them the means to make another one. My only regret is that I didn't know about the kickstarter, I would have wanted to give them MORE money!

30900016.review:
This is a wonderful love letter to the LucasArts adventure games of old.  Sam and Max holds a spot in my gaming heart.  Monkey Island will always be my favorite.  Maniac Mansion was an obsession.  Thimbleweed Park rests alongside those games, feeling like a warm cozy blanket of nostalgia.

This game is how I remember adventure gaming to be, even though there are afew more modern design elements that make this a more technically impressive package.  In a nutshell, this is a tightly crafted point and click adventure game, with multiple characters and an engrossing plot-a-boo.  There are tons of nods to the genre, to LucasArts games in particular and a metric ton of easter eggs and ties to Ron Gilbert's own games.

I cannot recommend this game enough if you are a fan of Maniac Mansion, Monkey Island or any of the LucasArts adventure game-a-renos.

30899622.review: Getting very nostalgic playing this and feel like binge playing all the previous "MmucasFlem" adventure games now as well.

30898732.review:
I've played the game for almost 2 hours and feel I have enough insight to offer a formed opinion. 

Firstly it's an excellent game in it's own right, and a brilliant adventure game and supports the genre nicely. For £14.99 I would say it's worth the money (Unless I finish within the next hour). I went straight into hard mode and I would suggest this for anyone who has played through a point and click adventure game. Two hours in and I am finding the puzzles a little on the easy side so far. However, the team behind the gamedo usually have a good dificulty curve and without giving any spoilers the way the game is designed I can see how it will (hopefully) become much more difficult.

If you are new to adventure gaming, I would suggest playing Day of the Tentacle / Monkey Island first and here's why

Cons:

- The games biggest downfall so far, it sells itself as not being a walking simulator, and i'm afraid so far that's how it can feel. I'm ploughing through puzzles but scenes such as the cemetary are stupidly long- winded and drawn out. Although you can double- click to run it does make my have to take a deep breath to continue playing it. Compared with Tentacle which is set in one area with scenes quickly accessible. I would worry that new comers might get bored of all the walking.

- As mentioned, so far the puzzles haven't been as challenging as i'd hoped (so far!)

- A minor gripe, a couple of the characters really grate on you after a while, you'll know who I mean when you play.

- So far I haven't actually found it too funny.

Pros:

- Great voice acting
- Amazing visuals (mimics classic PaC's of the 80's/90's
- Brilliant story which draws you in
- HUGE scenes and levels which as mentioned above is both good and bad
- Puzzles although simple so far, make sense and are smart. There's none of this 'Take the apple and mix it with the hair of a badger to make a stuffed toy' nonsense (not a real puzzle)

The pro's outweigh the cons for me, and you can tell straight away that a lot of love has gone into making the game. It's not easy to square up against monkey island or tentacle and this game manages it, falling short in only a couple of minor areas.

I would recommend to anyone - 9/10

30898731.review:
After finishing the game, overall I would say the game was pretty good. Puzzles were nice, but I was hoping there would be a bit more humour in the game like in the Monkey Island. Although unlike in Monkey Island, I would say that every puzzle in the game made sense and the solution was reasonable. I liked the graphical art style, it really looked good, how there were some new stuff used for old style pixel art and the music was good as was the voice acting. I did also like the references to other games.

I found it awesome that even the keyboard shortcuts for the commands were still there, like I remembered back in the days of old school point and clickers, such as q,w,e,a,s,d,z,x and c.

Still though it is not a perfect game and here are some of the cons I had: 
[list]
[*]Some huge issues for me were, the talks were unskippable, or at least I never found a key (which I figured would be esc), to skip any of the talks. Only in some minor parts you could skip cutscenes with esc-key. Talking the 6th time to same person and waiting for 20-30 seconds before you get into choosing dialogue is not something I really enjoyed.
[*]Another thing which in my opinion should be in the game is actually support for mouse wheel. I can understand that maybe it was in a sense trying to mimic the old inventory system, but for real no mouse wheel support for scrolling inventory in 2017?
[*]Third thing that I honestly wished the game didn't have is one puzzle that kind of requires you to do some pixel hunting. For myself I was kind of lucky that I actually accidentally spotted this, but I can honestly think there will be some people who will be stuck because of not having spotted this one item. A spoiler the item is:  [spoiler] Chainsaw [/spoiler] 
[*]And finally fourth issue I had was that I actually got into a situation where I had to load a save file because I did something and got into a dead end, where I couldn't finish the game, despite this being advertised so much in the game that you can never lock yourself up. Luckily a) I had a save file 1 hour back, and b) I could guess what one was suppose to do instead of being stuck forever. I sent a bug report to support for this issue, so hopefully it will be fixed. The bug/deadend was: [spoiler] At least with Delores while wearing the hat, you can give it away to at least Ken Thien, but only if you are actually wearing it. [/spoiler]
[/list]

Still overall I do think it is a great game even with the small quirks, and hopefully some patches will be made for example being able to skip some texts and maybe the less minor issue of no scroll wheel support.

30895626.review:
This game is simply brillant. 
It is the retro game per excellence.

Why?
You have the graphics, the puzzles et cetera.
But, what makes this game really outstanding is the meta=humor.
At first I was a little bit annoyed, because every opportunity for references was used. Really nearly every opportunity. 
After I got used to it, I started to enjoy.
And now, after I thought a little bit more about it, I find this game simply to be a piece of art.
No, it is not trying to be Monkey Island, it is not trying to be Maniac Mansion. 
If you are able to accept that and see, what the devs have done here, you should be more than amazed. The humor creeps more slow and grabs you from behind, as because of its absolute absurdity; destroying the fictive barrier between the player and the game. A game reflecting on the player and itself, yes, getting the player to reflect on the game and himself.
In my opinion, it is perfectioning the genre of a tribute and reference game.

As I said, for me it is the retro game per se per excellence.
And it is really fun to play, too.
Even without thinking too much about it.

30894683.review:
This is my first review ever I believe, but I've just finished the game I just had to do it. I'm going to be really general to avoid any experience you may encounter playing this game, so sorry if I sound vague.   

First, If you like point and click adventure games pick this up. It is amazing. The story was the best I've seen in a game in a long time. This was mostly because of the characters. The characters were all really fleshed out and memorable. The puzzles were difficult but not over the top. There wasn't really any obscure puzzles (monkey island STILL LOVE) and pretty much doable if you really think about it. There is some pixel hunting sometimes but this was few and far between.  There is also two modes, easy and hard, so if your new to the point and click genre you can jump right in. I haven't played the easy mode yet because I wanted to get the full experience, so this review is coming from that stand point. Ron Gilbert and Gary Winnick  really produced something special and you should support them so they keep making amazing games. Now only if Disney would give the rights back to Ron to make a new Monkey Island. Dreamers can dream though :)

Absolutely blew my expectations out of the water! I think this is the best adventure game I've ever played. 
At the very least, it's tied with Grim Fandango.

30891493.review:
Words cannot describe how much I love this game.  And I've only played for 5 hours and have spent at least an hour and a half wandering in circles trying to solve a puzzle.  My stream has watched my literally giggle like a schoolgirl with joy over this game.

Pros:
Humor.  This game has that Monkey Island humor and nails it perfectly.  If you liked the humor Monkey Island and Maniac Mansion you'll love this game

Great puzzles.  While some of the solutions are out there, that's typical Ron Gilbert's games (i mean shit you fed a fish to a troll to pass a bridge back in MI1).  While the solutions are out there, they don't see wtfish (like using a pie to defeat a yeti in king's quest 5).

Fun story. I'm not to far yet but I'm loving the story and the characters

Made by the legendary Ron Gilbert.

There is definately a joke every 2 minutes

You'll finally learn the true secret to Monkey Island. But it may not be what you expect.

Cons:
It's really good. And like they say. All good things come to an end.  I wish this game would never end.  I could literally play it forever.

For 20 bucks this game is more than worth it!  If you grew up in the 90s playing these point and click adventure games then you will love it.  If you're new to the genre you'll love it as well.

30880080.review:
Da ist es nun, das lang erwartete Point'n Click Adventure von Ron Gilbert und Garay Winnick. Ich habe das spiel zwar vorab gebacked möchte das endgültige Produkt aber dennoch fair bewerten. 

Ich bin mittlerweile in Kapitel 3 und die Story ist fesselnd genug um mich weiter an den Monitor zu fesseln. Die Qualität der Sprachaufnahmen entpsricht nicht unbedingt heutiger Technik, evtl. ist dies aber auch absicht um der retro-optik gerecht zu werden.. DIe Pixel-Optik ist meistens sehr schön, manche Sachen fallen aber wiederum etwas ab (wie z.b. die Landkarte, die deutlich gröber ist). Das ist aber kein Problem und man kann problemlos drüber hinwegsehen, schließlich macht ein Spiel mehr aus als nur die Grafik (Die retro-optik ist natürlich geschmackssache, sollte aber interessenten nicht abschrecken).

Ich spiele momentan auf schwer und finde die Schwierigkeit ok, es ist zu einfach, aber hat bisher auch keine extrem um die Ecke gedachten Rätsel. Schön ist, daß die Welt größer ist und die Rätsel sich nich nur ein auf einen kleinen Bereich beziehen (da würde ich z.b.als Vergleich (das dennoch sehr gute) deponia doomsday heranziehen, welches in neuen abschnitten das inventar immer wieder nullte) sondern später die komplette Stadt erkundbar ist. Trotzdem sind die Rätsel bisher sehr logisch und nachvollziehbar und es stellt sich immer wieder das Glücksgefühl ein, wenn meine eine vermeintliche Kopfnuss doch noch geknackt. Auch scheint es für bestimmte Probleme verschiedene Lösungswege zu geben, daß kann ich jedoch noch nicht 100prozentig bestätigen, da ich noch nicht zum 2. mal gespielt habe.  Story- und Rätseltechnisch gibt es also nichts zu meckern und befindet sich am gehobenem Niveau.

Neben der Grafik weiß vorallem der Sound zu gefallen. Ob z.b. die stimmungsvolle Eröffnungsmusik (die mich irgendwie an Twin Peaks erinnert),  oder generelles sounddesign (wie z.b. die quietschenden Schuhe des Clowns) sind sher gut gemacht und machen  einen sehr wertigen Eindruck.

Ich kann nichts wirklich negatives über das Spiel sagen, was mich wirklich stören würde. Die Anspielungen an alte Lucasarts-Klassiker war natürlich zu erwarten und ich finde sie gelungen, weil sie imo nicht die Geschichte oder Story bestimmen. Man muss sie nicht gespielt um das Spiel zu verstehen, es ist eigenständig genug. Das Durchbrechen der 4. Wand gab es auch schon bei Monkey Island 2 z.b. (Telefon-Supporthotline, 20 € für ein Computerspiel, Das 'Ende'). 

Man hat manchmal an alten Spielen eine besonders tolle Erinnerung, die auch die Meinung darüber beeinflusst. Für micht ist Thimbleweed genau das alte Point'n Click Adventure der damaligen Zeit, was ich noch nicht gespielt habe. Man fühlt sich irgendwann heimelig und zurück in seine Kindheit versetzt und genau das hatte ich mir erhofft. 20€ sind hier super aufgehoben (auch wenn ich mehr bezahlt habe).

30879408.review:
This game is phenominal. 

It is a successor to the old Lucasarts style point-n-click adventure games -- Monkey Island and Manic Mansion most notably, but also things like the Sam and Max games. It doesn't entirely trade off the back of nostalgia, and there is enough new stuff here, and enough understanding of how to properly execute the old stuff, that there is plenty of value added.

There are a few places where the game is a little rough around the edges and there are a few things I could nitpick (like, the menu resolution should really be the same as the game resolution) but that is to be expected with such a small development team. Make no mistake, this game is however a masterpeice of the point-n-click genre and easily stands alongside the greats.

I really feel like this game needs to be the first in a series, because it feels like a game that is just breaking the ice on something. I know a custom engine was built for the game, and I really hope the team use it in the future to produce more games. I'd be really interested to see what kind of gameplay mechanics and puzzles they can come up with from this starting point.

Highly reccomended.

30876711.review:
Классическая адвенчура - теперь и в виде ААА-проекта!

Пожалуй, можно сказать, что своё обещание выпустить в 2017 году приключенческую point-and-click игру, обладающую всеми достоинствами классики конца 1980-х, отцы жанра Рон Гилберт и Гэри Уинник, вкупе с примкнувшими к ним не менее легендарными Дэвидом Фоксом и Марком Феррари, таки выполнили.

К преимуществам "Thimbleweed Park" стоит отнести:

* Великолепную пиксельную графику! Просто нет слов. Что фоны Марка, что персонажи Гэри - едва ли не идеал в своём классе.

* Масштабность. 10, 15, даже 20 часов игры - это вполне реально.

* Сложность. Не то, чтобы здесь было много нелинейности (в конце концов, на главы игра разбита достаточно жёстко), но открытый мир и возможность переключаться между несколькими персонажами - это вам не HOG на три экрана.

Разумеется, не обошлось и не без недостатков. Ну да ладно - у большой игры и недостатки большие:

* Не самое удобное управление. Оказывается, в игру забыли вставить экран с указанием кнопок, - но всё равно: почему в 
адвенчуре, где в настройках можно поменять режим отображения туалетной бумаги, нельзя проделать тоже самое с назначением клавиатурных сокращений? Или повесить на кнопку мышки возможность прерывать диалоги?!

* Взаимодействие между персонажами не самое убедительное. Только в конце игры четверо героев из пяти наконец-то собираются вместе и вроде бы даже признают существование друг друга. 

* Сюжет немного странен, да и концовка понравится не всем. Нет, это не спойлер - это для Рона нашего Гилберта скорее традиция...

Тем не менее, перед нами определённо одна из лучших игр года! Познакомиться с которой стоит обязательно, несмотря на внушительный (как для жанра) ценник.

Более подробная рецензия:
http://itc.ua/articles/thimbleweed-park-bolshoy-privet-iz-zolotogo-veka-advenchur/

30873016.review:
I was excited to hear there would be another Ron Gilbert LucasArts like SCUMM adventure. No that i have played 2 hours+, I dont feel excited anymore…

Yeah, the graphic is nostalgic, the interface is nostalgic, but the game ruins itself for me. It is just too much of of everything, except of itself.

[list]
[*]There is so much braking of the 4th wall, I dont even think there ever was one.
[*]The references to old adventures are so many, the actual game basically drowns in it. [spoiler] And at one point the reference was a red herring from Maniac Mansion, though it had a solution here. That might have been funny, if it had not been embedded in a Monkey Island 2 like scene while I already found the chainsaw fuel and the chainsaw and seen some appearances of characters from earlier games (there actuaylly was one in that very screen). And of course both kitchens I've seen so far have a fridge and a microwave prominently displayed and interactable. (which were only needed in one case and I doubt I can access that other screen again) [/spoiler]
[/list]

I currently feel I spent about 100 Minutes sitting through reference/inside joke/4th wall breaking after  reference/inside joke/4th wall breaking after  reference/inside joke/4th wall breaking and about 20 with things that had to with a new game like puzzling on things advancig the story.

Though the puzzles I encountered so far were pretty much obvious to me.

It is so much other stuff and therefore annoying. I wonder if they are trying to make a point here.


I'll see if I can force myself to the ending, maybe it gets better or I am just doing things in special order or something. But after these two hours, I cant recommend it to anyone.


Edit: I just wanted to point out, that this runs so freaking smoothly on my non-Ubuntu Linux box, it is really amazing… just doubleclick and it is there. No hazzles, no chooser, no loading, no crashes, no hangs, no odd behaviour on loading screens, no messing around with the window manager, just as it is supposed to. A lot of other games still have a long way ahead to get there – even if they are not using 3D.

30872674.review:
The great:
- Finally, a true point and click game after 20 years
- It's huge
- The art and mood are fantastic
- They struck the right balance between retro pixel art, and using modern rendering (the parallaxing is awesome)
- The story is great (so far, I'm in chapter 3)
- It's genuinely funny
- 4 hours in, I completed only about 20% of the game (if the achievements are any indication), without walkthrough obviously

The pretty bad to downright inexcusable from the creator of the genre:
- Many points of the game refer to, or give you puzzle solutions for, things you haven't discovered yet. This sometimes is really confusing (from the very beginning - the very first action you can do, refers to an item in your inventory that wasn't even introduced if you didn't click on it)
- The default right-mouse click action on objects is most of the times useless/downright annoying. So you're forced to pick a verb and then click the object, for things that have an obvious action (which is most objects). A number of objects are packed close together and have small hitboxes, so this is even more aggravating when you have to pick a verb and then slightly miss the object, even on a 30" screen. Can't imagine what it will be like on a tablet.
- The dolores intro/flashback scene. It brought the game to a standstill and it was my least favorite puzzles so far.
- While the game world is huge, it feels pretty empty. Most things in scenes cannot be clicked on; even just to give some humorous text (even generic, if VO cost was a concern). Coming from just playing the DOTT remake where almost everything responds to the player, this was a big letdown.
- It references maniac mansion and other LucasArts games WAY too much. Wink wink lampshading is fine, but there is way too much of it.
- It is WAY too easy so far. Not the good kind of easy; the bad kind of easy where puzzle solutions are spoiled, or are super obvious. Probably the result of too much playtesting/panicking (note: I am playing in hard mode; I can't even imagine what easy would be like..)
- The music in some parts of the game is really annoying
- I'm not sure what the point of the multiple characters is, so far. 3 chapters in, only one puzzle action required using more than one character, and it was super obvious / automatically done by the game. Everything else in the game is literally the characters saying the very same thing when you do the same action on an object.

Overall, this game is such a rare treat that I highly recommend buying it right away and trying to sip it (rather than swallow ti whole) so you can really enjoy it. A lot of things are disappointing considering who made it, but since this is such a rare entry in the genre, that makes up for the flaws, I think.

30870965.review:
"Es como si un día abrieras un viejo cajón de escritorio y en él encontrases unos diskets con un misterioso juego de aventura gráfica aún por estrenar..." así es como Ron Gilbert y Gary Winnick (los creadores) decidieron definir su proyecto cuando lo lanzaron en Kickstarter.

Ciertamente no iban desencaminados, de hecho ellos son los creadores de míticas sagas como Maniac Mansion o Monkey Island... Por lo que, si alguien es capaz de crear un juego que nos transporte a aquella época, sin duda son ellos!

Y vaya si lo consiguen! Como dirían los ingleses "back to 80's!" Porque este juego no solo transcurre en esa época (1987 para ser más exactos), sino que su estética pixelada y su estilo de juego es perfectamente reconocible para todos aquellos que vivimos nuestra feliz niñez o adolescencia entre los 80 y 90... Una época donde habían pocos juegos y cada juego se exprimía y se disfrutaba al máximo jugándose una y otra vez para descubrir todos sus secretos... 

La historia del juego transcurre en 1987 y nos situa en un pequeño pueblo de USA llamado Thimbleweed Park, un lugar donde nada es lo que parece. 

Todo empieza cuando durante una noche hombre es citado en un lugar preciso a las afueras del pueblo, tras inspeccionar la zona es asesinado por alguien (o algo)... A raiz de ese misterioso suceso llegarán al pueblo la veterana agente Ray y el Junior agente Reyes para investigar el caso.

Apenas he tenido tiempo de jugarlo una media hora y desde el primer momento te sientes totalmente familiarizado con esta aventura gráfica al más genuino estilo clásico, tanto en la jugabilidad (point and click) con el inconfundible menú de acciones a la izquierda y el menú de objetos a la derecha, al estilo del mítico SCUMM de las aventuras gráficas de LucasFilm y LucasArts. 

Debo decir que el principio del juego me ha recordado claramente al inicio del primer Monkey Island, cuando veiamos a Guybrush Threepwood descender de aquella colina para adentrarse en las calles de la isla Melee para convertirse en un gran pirata... Y es que no tardaremos en encontrar numerosos guiños y referencias a los clásicos Monkey Island o Maniac Mansion en los dialogos, algunos de los personajes, objetos, etc. Algo que por otro lado era típico en la época y formaba parte del humor de las aventuras gráficas de LucasArts.

Y de humor también nos evoca al estilo de la época, se nota la mano de Ron y Gary, ya que el juego combina el misterio con situaciones surealistas, chistes con los juegos de palabras, con las opciones de dialogos, con la mentalidad de los personajes, con los posibles usos de los objetos...

En definitiva, un juego completamente recomendable a todos aquellos nostálgicos de las aventuras gráficas de los 80 y 90, pero tambien para quienes nunca disfrutasteis de aquel género y sintáis curiosidad por saber como jugabamos y disfrutabamos los niños de aquel entonces :)

Gracias Ron y Gary! A big Thank You!


PD: Puedo decir con orgullo que soy uno de los contribuidores a que Thimbleweed Park exista ya que hará unos 2 años hice una donación de 50$ en kickstarter para que el proyecto se lanzara... En pocas semanas se había superado con creces el objetivo y el proyecto se puso en marcha. Como curiosidad añadiré que en mi donación, además de una copia del juego y banda sonora... se incluía la opción de dejar tu nombre en el listin telefonico del juego y un mensaje de voz a modo de contestador que se escucharía si alguien llamaba a ese numero del listin dentro del juego... Era una forma de sentirte parte del proyecto y de algun modo de entrar a formar parte de la magia de las aventuras clásicas quedando inmortalizado en Thimbleweed Park :)

But that aside, the game stands strongly on its own legs. The game displays humor that caused me to do everything from exhaling sharply through my nose to actually laughing out loud in a public place.

Thimbleweed Park is a perfect example of 'not judging a game by its graphics'. I'm no professional (my only credential is a minor in Game Design) but in my average-guy opinion, you should definitely buy this game. $20 is a steal!

Wow, this was an amazing throwback to classic adventure gaming. I haven't day dreamed about solving puzzles like this since Monkey Island 2. Granted there are plenty of great adventure games after Monkey Island 2, this captures the original wonder of seeing these kinds of games for the first time in the late 80's. 

I was pleasantly surprised by how engaging the story was. I've gotten so used to lackluster plots in games that I completely forgot this was Ron Gilbert and Gary Winnick we were talking about.  

The puzzle design is some of the best I've ever seen in an adventure game. Challenging, but solveable if you think about them long enough.

Bottom line, if you have fond memories of SCUMM games, this is every bit as special as those were. I just wish I could play it again for the first time.

30862466.review:
A true classic adventure. The look turns out to be not quite as retro as one might think when seeing still shots, as the game runs very smoothly, using parallax scrolling and light effects. This way the creators managed to allow a great freedom concerning what they wanted to show and what options the player has. This turns out to be a great strength.

Which leads to the main difference between this game and other games trying to appear classic: the puzzles are nifty chains of causality. Rather than having a limited number of items and hotspots, this game has lots of them. In a surpringly nonlinear way up to five characters solve puzzles alone and together, exploring a world instead of a string of rooms. One can do many things which do not advance the plot, creating the feeling of a immersive reality which has become untypical for this genre. 

The casual try-everything-with-everything strategy of most new adventures fails here. Rather than thinking what items can be used with each other, the player has to think about what he wants to achieve. This is sometimes tough, but never unfair. For players who never encountered real adventure games there is a casual mode, veterans can start directly in normal mode.

The focus lies on the gameplay. The story is refreshingly zany (but never just for the purpose of being zany) and the character fullfill their function. But the games does not spend too much time on subtleties easily missed. There is a more hands-on approach. Thimbleweed Park tries to be a first class game rather than a second rate movie. 
This game is closer to Monkey Island and Zak McKracken than to Broken Age or Blackwell, concerning the puzzle quality, but also the humour and the characters.

While there is a lot of optional dialogue, well acted by good voices, the hints are never buried in some blink-and-you-miss-it dialogue option. There is never a minute long conversation. It is showing instead of telling in the best sense of screenwriting. The solutions are not only logical, very often they are also intuitive.
The puzzles are rooted on the plot. The motivation for solving them is always clear, first comes the riddle, then the solution. There is never the situation of something having to be solved just because it looks like a puzzle, dropping a random object. Every character has a list of open tasks in their inventory, preventing from getting lost in the many open quests of the five characters. 

Highly recommended for gamers who liked Monkey Island, Indiana Jones, Maniac Mansion and Day of the Tentacle. 

(Also this game contains some lessons a lot of adventure designers apparently still have to learn.)

Definitely recommended. Must buy for LucasArts fans.

30861646.review:
Thimbleweed Park seriously feels like a lost Lucasarts classic. The tone, the writing, the graphics, the atmosphere, everything is spot on. Yet at the same time the game doesn't feel old. Gary Winnick, Ron Gilbert and their team have improved upon the formula with small quality of life improvements and general streamlining. 

The puzzle difficulty is spot on: you'll be able to think of logical solutions to most puzzles reasonably quickly, and the times when you can't, there's almost always something else you can be doing and moving the story along somewhere else. 

The game is simply a joy to play, and the story goes in some very unexpected directions. Don't miss out on Thimbleweed Park: I have a feeling it'll be recognized as a classic adventure game in years to come.

30856610.review:
The point-and-click adventure genre almost died at some point, then it came back. Sadly, it wasn't the same again... up until now. Thimbleweed Park offers the classic point-and-click adventure experience I grew up with!

The game mimics the same UI/UX as most of classic Lucas Arts games had (no surprise here, really, considering who made it), but it's missing one very important feature that was present in such amazing games as the original Monkey Island and the Maniac Mansion - they allowed to toggle commands (give/push/pull, talk, etc) with one of the keyboard buttons. Thimbleweed doesn't have that. This is the only disappointment I had, really. Otherwise, it is beautiful, it is huge, it is funny and captivating.

EDIT #1

Apparently, there are keyboard shortcuts for the verbs after all, but, unlike the ones found in the original Lucas Arts adventure games, they are not very intutitive. If in most LA quests they were just the first letters of the verbs: O - open, W - walk, U - use, and so on, in Thimbleweed Park it's Q, W, E, A, S, D, Z, X, C. WIth Q mapping to "open". There is some sense int that - as the 3x3 square of keys on the keyboard can be directly translated into the verbs displayed on the UI. Still, the original system was more user-friendly. I remember just pressing what seemed to make sense and it did what I expecte it to do. In this game I found out about the shortcuts only after finishing the whole game and writing this review.
